DEBATE.TITLE: FAMILY LAW AMENDMENT BILL 1987[COGNATE BILL:FAMILY COURT OF AUSTRALIA (ADDITIONAL JURISDICTION AND EXERCISE OF POWERS) BILL 1987]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 October, on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand it is the wish of the House to debate this Bill concurrently with the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill. There being no objection, the Chair will allow this course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Family Law Amendment Bill and the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill, which are to be debated cognately, contain some major changes to the Family Law Act. In general terms, the Bills legislate for ex-nuptial children. They redraft, and make very important amendments to, the maintenance provisions in the Act, especially with regard to children. They redirect a lot of routine work away from Family Court judges, particularly to the magistrates courts, and they provide the judges in the Family Court jurisdiction with some additional non-family law work.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills contain amendments that will have far-reaching consequences for family law and the conduct of that jurisdiction in Australia. Some are designed to reduce delays in New South Wales. I understand that the delay in Sydney for defended matters-and many of those would be property matters-is up to 2 1/2 years. That is a very long time, and the old adage is justice delayed is justice denied. Some of the provisions in the Bills are designed at reducing those problems. Some are aimed at raising the status of the Family Court of Australia and others find their origins in the concern I think we all share for children, particularly children of broken marriages.

The divorce industry, if I may use that term, has been calculated to have an annual turnover of $1.9 billion. Quite a lot of those funds are a cost to governments. The cost of running the Family Court this year, in 1986-87 prices, is estimated to be $33.3m, and a bit higher in nominal terms. The cost of legal aid this year, a fair proportion of which relates to family law matters, again in 1986-87 prices, will be around $84m. In 1986-87 prices, for every man, woman and child we spend something like $6.94 on those two aspects of divorce and legal aid. One might describe that as the cure cost.

In contrast, the moneys we will spend on prevention-that is, expenditure on marriage guidance counselling-this year, using the same formula of 1986-87 prices, will total $5.4m. That works out to be 33c per head. I must say it is a matter of regret for many members on this side of the House that that figure has declined in the 1987-88 Budget. When so many other programs simply waste taxpayers' money, one has to be concerned about a government that does not have the sorts of priorities the Australian electorate would look to a government to have. It is a matter of concern that the Government is lukewarm on marriage guidance counselling. It is no good the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) shrugging his shoulders and regretting it but in the end there not being the political will to make the right sorts of decisions. We spend 33c on prevention and at least $6.94 on the cure. The old saying is `A stitch in time saves nine' but when it comes to matrimonial matters the ratio is about 20 : 1. I ask people to think about whether that is right.

A lot of factors impinge on the state of families. Marriage guidance counselling is important but there are many other factors. Under this Government, families have had to bear very considerable increases in tax burdens. That has been the hallmark of this Government-it is the highest taxing government we have ever had in our history. Who pays this tax? The families of Australia pay Labor's taxes. I am glad that there are a few new members of the Government party in the House today. They have been told that family homes are not subject to the capital gains tax. I have taken an interest in this matter and it is not true that there is no capital gains tax on family homes. I ask honourable members opposite to look at the 19 circumstances on the Notice Paper which I have put to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and in which I have asked him to confirm whether family homes are subject to capital gains tax. After at least 12 months, if not longer, he has failed to give me a response. A letter from one of his staffers the other day said that the matter was so complicated that it was not possible to answer my question. Not only is the public in the dark; the Treasurer's own staff could not give me a definition of the circumstances in which families have to pay capital gains tax on the family home.

Before turning to the detail of these Bills, I indicate that the Opposition is not impressed by the Government's indecent haste in bringing these matters on for debate in the House. These Bills contain very major changes to family law. They were introduced last week. There are 64 pages in the Bills and 79 pages of explanatory memoranda and, of course, many pages of second reading speeches. One Bill was introduced on Wednesday. The Attorney-General's Department or office very kindly brought a copy of the second Bill to me that night because its introduction had been delayed on the Wednesday because of a printers strike. The next morning, someone very kindly came around with a second copy. I said, `Thank you very much but I got a copy last night. Are there any changes from the first copy?'. The person said there were not.

I started to compare the copies and found that the Government had been making changes to the Bill overnight. That sort of approach is just not good enough-for a major area of law to be changed this way and to be rushed and rammed through the Parliament with the attitude, `Don't worry too much. She'll be jake'. It will not be jake. Tens of thousands of Australian families will be affected by this legislation and virtually nobody has had a proper opportunity to sit down and go over the fine details. That should happen. For those reasons, at the conclusion of my remarks I will move that these Bills be referred to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

In respect of the Family Law Amendment Bill, I will include an early date by which the Committee must report back to this House. The Bill implements proposals which have been coalition policy for a long time. The Bill needs to be passed as soon as possible. We have been calling for it for years. The Government has taken years to bring it in; now it wants to ram it through overnight and will put up a complaint about the matter going to a committee. We will suggest that this Bill go to the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee for 30 days. That is not a long period. It does not involve undue delay. It simply provides this Parliament with an opportunity to look at some of the fine details.

From discussions with our Senate colleagues-I mention this particularly because I know what the Attorney-General's response might be-I am confident, despite the Senate's cut-off date rules, that the Bill will be given passage by Christmas. That is a sensible way to proceed.

Unlike the Family Law Amendment Bill, the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill contains policy proposals which have not been the subject of considerable debate in this Parliament before. In view of our proposal to refer the Bills to the Committee, we will not oppose either measure in this place. In the event that the motion to refer the matters to the Committee is lost, I give notice to the Government that my coalition colleagues in the Senate will seek to ensure that the Family Law Amendment Bill remains on the table at least until the end of the month or early December so that the community has adequate time to make representations particularly on the details of the Bill. If we see the need for any amendments we will certainly move them in the Senate.

On the jurisdiction Bill we will seek to have the issues that are raised in the Bill referred to the Senate's Standing Committee. Obviously, we would reserve our position to move any amendments in that place. However, I express the hope that the Government will accept the motion of referral to the House Committee. These are the very sorts of Bills for which these committees have been set up. It is silly that we can have a situation where the Government knocks back our proposal, sends the matter off to the Senate and with the support, perhaps, of the Australian Democrats-and I make that presumption-send the matter to a Senate committee that has plenty of things to look at. Yet in the House of Representatives we have a whole lot of backbenchers, particularly on the Attorney-General's side, who are sitting around twiddling their thumbs. They ought to do some real work to assist the Parliament in its central activity which is to look at Bills. I hope the Attorney-General will give careful consideration to that proposal.

I now turn to the more specific aspects of the Family Law Amendment Bill. The Bill should be referred to as the Durack Bill in honour of Senator Peter Durack. This Bill has its origins in the last days of the Fraser Government. I do not think there is any doubt that, if in 1983 Malcolm Fraser had been returned, a Bill along these lines would have been brought in probably in late 1983 or early 1984. Those matters were under discussion between Senator Chaney as Social Security Minister and Senator Durack as Attorney-General. When Labor come to power it had difficulties, so it set up a committee. In a nutshell the problem had arisen, particularly at the end of the Fraser Government, through the social security system's provision of the supporting parent's benefit. The benefit was no longer a mere safety net. It provided income support to sole parents-mostly women-without first requiring both parents to meet their responsibilities to their children. People act rationally in that sense, and more and more have become reliant on the state.

The Family Court of Australia, acting under the Family Law Act, was required to take into account the carer's eligibility for a pension when determining the maintenance obligations of the non-custodial parent. The ones who have borne the brunt of this system are the children and the sole parents and, of course, the long suffering taxpayer. The payments under that sole parents benefit have exploded. Studies have shown that what little maintenance has been paid has been pitifully inadequate and not surprisingly if we compare the position of custodial parents with their assets and general standard of living with non-custodial parents, say five years after the marriage breakdown, in virtually every case the custodial parent has been considerably worse off. That information has been brought forward by the Institute of Family Studies and the matter was recently looked at in the Law Reform Commission's report on matrimonial property.

The Government discontinued the requirement-a requirement upon which we had insisted-that people first claim maintenance before applying for assistance from the public purse. It is reasonable that they should do that, and that is a proposition that the Government has now finally but reluctantly accepted in the Bill that is before us today. I shall give some of the history of the matter, as it is indicative of the manner in which the Government has failed to address this essential issue. The Government waited for the completion of its inquiry, it got the results of that inquiry, but then it did nothing.

During this time, the patience of Senator Durack, not surprisingly, had worn rather thin. The coalition continued to demand action. We brought in a private member's Bill that sought to prevent the Family Court of Australia from taking into account eligibility for a pension when determining the responsibility of a non-custodial parent to pay maintenance for, usually, his children. The purpose of the first Durack Bill was basically to put a burr under the saddle. Perhaps that burr was not big enough, because the Government prevaricated and only now has it finally come to deal with the issue.

In 1986 the Government announced its intention to establish a child maintenance assessment and collection agency. In fact, the Government voted against and defeated the Durack Bill. It did not do so because it disagreed with the policy embodied in that Bill. That was patently not the reason, because that policy is now contained in this Bill. It voted against that Bill because it was put up by a member of the Liberal Party; it is as simple as that. The Government is not prepared to look at the merits of propositions put forward by the Liberal Party. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) says that the Government will admit its mistakes if it is wrong and that he wants to engage in constructive dialogue with the Opposition. The reality is that when it came to the crunch the Government voted against the Durack Bill for no other reason than the cynical one that it was put forward by the Liberal Party.

Following the election we reintroduced Senator Durack's Bill. At last, after some prevarication, the Government introduced the Bill that is before us today. Of passing interest is the fact that there were to be two stages to this process. We were to have changes effected by means of a family law amendment Bill, and the child maintenance assessment and collection agency was to be established. That was to be stage 1. Stage 2 was to be the implementation of the formula. Now we have moved to having three stages, since the legislation establishing the agency has yet to be introduced.

The Bill seeks neither to establish the agency nor to implement the formula. As I have said, the Bill that deals with maintenance matters embodies the Opposition's long-standing policy on such matters. To that extent I am prepared to congratulate the Government on implementing our policy. It is not the first Opposition policy it has implemented and I am sure that it will not be the last. However, I condemn the Government for taking so many years to implement that policy and for voting against this very proposal just because it was put by a member of the Liberal Party. The Bill also enshrines the Family Court decision in a case called Mee v. Ferguson. The Law Council of Australia and others have been calling for that to be done for months and months. Of course, the Opposition supports the principles underlying that case, and we are pleased that they have been embodied in this legislation.

The Family Law Amendment Bill also covers ex-nuptial children. That is a matter that has been debated for more than 10 years. The problem is related to the jurisdiction of the Family Court and the fact that the Australia Constitution places limits on the matter that the Federal Parliament can address in establishing the jurisdiction of the Family Court. On a number of occasions the question of custody and other matters in relation to the children of one family have had to be dealt with in different courts simply as a consequence of the limited jurisdiction of the Family Court. That matter has been referred to in many places and has been the subject of a number of reports. It was the subject of discussion at the Australian Constitutional Conventions of 1975 and 1976. It features again in the report of the Advisory Committee on the Distribution of Powers of the Constitutional Commission. Page 51 of that report, which was brought down this year, reads:

The Commonwealth Parliament's Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act 1980 recommended, among other things, that the States should, as a matter of urgency, refer power to the Commonwealth over the custody, guardianship and maintenance of ex-nuptial children and legitimate children of a previous marriage.
It goes on to note:

In December 1985, the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, in its report on `In-Vitro Fertilisation and the Status of Children', recommended that, `The Commonwealth should seek to obtain from the States the power to enact legislation to deal with all issues of the status of children in law' ''.

One of its recommendations was that the existing division of family law powers between the Commonwealth and the States should be changed. The second recommendation was that the changes should result in the Commonwealth power being extended to cover custody and guardianship of all children. There is much support for that proposal. The Opposition has no difficulty with it. I see that the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) will speak today. He was the Chairman of the Committee to which I have referred. I am sure he will advert to the work of that Committee.

As a consequence of the additional power conferred on the Commonwealth, this Bill covers matters that were previously the subject of State law, in matters such as paternity and child bearing expenses. There are quite a few detailed provisions and whilst there are no especially difficult policy matters, our proposal again to have a committee look at the details is obviously sensible.

I now turn to the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill. Its purpose is to reduce delays in the Family Court and to improve the status of the Family Court by breaking down its specialist jurisdiction. It is hoped that, by being able to offer a greater variety of work, the status of the Court will be thereby uplifted. The additional jurisdiction cases will come from the Federal Court and will be transferred as a result of a process of consultation between the two chief judges of the two courts; that is, the Chief Judge of the Family Court and the Chief Judge of the Federal Court.

The Bill still maintains the requirement that those matters be initiated in the Federal Court. The additional jurisdiction areas proposed arise out of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Reviews) Act, the Bankruptcy Act, the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Trade Practices Act. To allow the Family Court judges to take on additional jurisdiction, the Bill attempts to reduce the work load of the Family Court judges and it does so by three methods: allowing greater delegation to registrars in routine and minor contested matters; creating the new office of judicial registrar to also handle delegated matters; and by extending the jurisdiction of courts of summary jurisdiction-that is the magistrates courts-to include applications for dissolution of marriage and to increase the monetary limit within which defended property matters can be dealt with.

We in the Liberal Party in the last election, with the support of the National Party, recognised in our policy documents the need for a reappraisal of the operation of the Family Court. It was our policy position that the Family Court should not remain a separate and distinct judicial tribunal. We nominated some of the options that needed to be addressed and looked at and I think this Bill moves in that general direction.

Basically, the reasoning behind this Bill is that the specialist jurisdiction for the Family Court has not been a success. The late Senator Murphy is often credited with its creation and, with the benefit of hindsight, his concept of a specialist court has been demonstrated to be not the best way to run a judicial system. I suppose that the person who is credited with raising these matters first was former Chief Justice Sir Harry Gibbs. He made a celebrated address at the Australian Legal Convention in Melbourne in August 1985. As recorded on page 2 of my notebook, he said:
The need remains to make a complete and dispassionate assessment of the Family Law Act.
He went on to say:
It may have been a mistake to establish a separate court to administer the Family Law Act.
He continued:
The creation of that court has made it difficult to maintain the high standards in the making of judicial appointments.
Lastly, he said:
Past experience in Australia does not support the view that specialised experience is necessary to render a judge able to deal with matters of family law.
Leading up to his considered views, in September 1984 at page 17, he said:

The perceived need to create a variety of specialised tribunals may indicate a diminishing confidence in the ability of the ordinary courts to perform their functions. If so, it gives a warning to which the profession should pay heed.
In that address he referred particularly to tribunals established under legislation directed at anti-discrimination, and he mentioned the New South Wales Equal Opportunity Tribunal. He said:

To concentrate on one perceived evil may tend in the nature of things to distort its proportions and it is possible to become too zealous in the pursuit of a good aim. A specialised body set up in an attempt to eradicate one sort of objectionable conduct may find it difficult to maintain the sense of moderation and balance that is the characteristic of the common law and that the exercise of a more general jurisdiction is likely to preserve.

I am not suggesting that marriage or divorce falls within the category of objectionable conduct, but I think he goes to the essence of what our courts are all about and what we are looking for in our judges. It is difficult to put on paper, but the word that comes to my mind is the concept of wisdom. Wisdom in dealing with the affairs of man comes from an experience and a knowledge of the whole scope of human activity and the way that we are.

The Jackson Committee on the Australian Judicial System, in reporting on the Constitutional Convention, again looked at this need to create a sense of balance. It referred to the fact that family law matters can involve tax, superannuation, trusts, and property law-certainly a very wide gambit of human conduct. The Jackson Committee favoured renovation but did not come to a final view about integration within the Federal Court of Australia. It called for a closer review of the issue and that is a fundamental matter that I think the House of Representatives Committee should address. It would be only sensible to have a firmer view of the ultimate future of the Family Court. That is why I think we ought to send this matter to a committee.

I think that there are merits in the proposal and I say that publicly to give the Attorney-General an indication of the views of a number of us. However, it is not surprising that there are different views around the place. There are two competing views within the Law Council. Again, I think that just emphasises the need to look at these matters very carefully.

I note that the matter of robing was apparently the subject of some discussion in the Caucus. The Attorney-General has my support for the position he put. I understand that Caucus took another view about that but if we could get some sensible discussion going in the Committee again we might persuade Caucus to come to its senses. I am not terribly optimistic about that, but it is another basis upon which the Committee would have an important function to fulfil.

The proposal for greater capacity in the Registrar and the creation of judicial registrars is less controversial; I do not think there is any doubt about that. I am not sure whether the Law Council initiated this proposal but it certainly initiated the proposal in regard to judicial registrars, and it calls them masters. The term `master' is another point with which I think Caucus had a few problems. I understand that there is a female master in Adelaide, and a good one at that. I do not have any problem with the word. The reality is that, when we are talking about status and traditions, that is a concept known in the law and a position of status within the law, and I really think we ought to stick to it. But again that is a matter that the Committee ought to have a look at.

The more difficult areas relate to the additional jurisdiction for the magistrates courts. On defended property matters the limit has been $1,000 in nominal terms and, as I understand it, translated into today's money that is about $3,500. There is a lot of controversy about that issue. The Law Council, the Law Institute of Victoria and the Australian Council of Social Service have written to the Attorney-General all opposing it and they have said, `By all means look at means by which we reduce the costs of family law matters in litigation but let us not forget that in a lot of cases we are not dividing up property, we are dividing up poverty and those people ought to have access to the best possible specialists in this jurisdiction that we can obtain'.

That matter, and of course, very briefly, the matter of whether divorce applications for dissolution ought to be heard in the magistrates court, are also matters of great controversy in the community. The Attorney-General shrugs his shoulders, but the reality is that very few people know about the proposal. The legislation was introduced last week. I have sent out a few copies, but I do not think enough people are aware of its implications. We simply say that these are important--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is referred to in the report of the Advisory Committee to the Constitutional Commission. It is a matter of public knowledge.

— But not everybody reads the reports of the Constitutional Commission's Committee. Of course, the Committee itself did not have a considered final view of the integration question. There are many matters of controversy and they ought to be the subject of further debate. I move an amendment in relation to the Family Law Amendment Bill in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: That all the words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
``the Bill be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for inquiry and report by 7 December 1987''.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will second the amendment.
—I foreshadow an amendment in relation to the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after ``that'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
``the Bill be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for inquiry and report by June 1988''.

TALK.START.PARA: — I second the amendment.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak in support of the Family Law Amendment Bill and the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill. Obviously, I am against the amendment moved by the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith). This morning I wish to speak mainly to the Bill which confers additional jurisdiction on judges of the Family Court of Australia. This is a serious area of the law. It is one that I would have thought the Opposition would not have trivialised by trying to score cheap political points. I found it somewhat amusing that the honourable member for Flinders spoke about robing. I would hardly think that litigants in the Family Court who have gone through a traumatic experience would be concerned about whether the judge was wearing a wig, a gown, or whatever. I think that would be the furthest thing from their minds. That is another example of the Opposition trivialising what is a very important and serious area of the law.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) for his approach to the problem. It is a problem area of the law which seems to attract, at times, irrational behaviour from the public, some litigants and now even the Opposition. The Opposition whinges about the Government's attitude in this area, but it was a Labor government that introduced a jurisdiction to be covered by the Family Court. I suppose the Opposition would like us to go back to the old days of the Matrimonial Causes Act when the delays were even longer than they are now. The situation regarding expense and delays in litigation was very bad. In 1972-73 it cost more, in actual money terms at that time, for a litigant to get an undefended divorce than it does now. I suggest to the Opposition that, instead of whingeing about this, it should at least acknowledge that the Government is doing something about trying to make this area of the law a lot smoother and cut down the delays.

The main thrust of the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill is that it will give jurisdiction in certain areas of the law to Family Court judges, but only by specific reference from the Federal Court. It will also create the office of judicial registrar, which is similar to the office of masters of supreme courts in the States. It will also empower Family Court judges to delegate to judicial registrars functions which have been handled by them up until now. In addition, it will extend the functions of registrars of the Court. At the moment, registrars simply attend to minor procedural matters, such as regulation 96 conferences. The Bill will also extend the jurisdiction of courts of summary jurisdiction which presently handle minor family law matters, such as maintenance and very minor property matters up to a limit, I understand, of $1,000.

The Bill gives power to the Federal Court to refer matters to the Family Court under the following categories: matters involved with the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, the consumer provisions of the Trade Practices Act, the Bankruptcy Act and the Income Tax Assessment Act. The additional jurisdiction and the appointment of judicial registrars which can now be conferred on the Family Court will, I am sure, be welcomed by the Family Court, by the judges and also by litigants and the public for the following reasons: first, they will reduce the substantial delays that have been experienced by litigants in the Family Court throughout Australia. In my State of Queensland contested custody, maintenance and property settlement applications can take years to finalise because the work load in this, regrettably, growing area of the law is increasing at an alarming rate. Whilst many of us in this House are happily married we have to agree that there are many people who are not. They find after a certain time that there is an incompatibility. Unfortunately, they end up in the Family Court. That is a fact of life which the Government is addressing.

At the moment, simple applications for undefended divorces and requests for adjournments are being handled by the judges. Simple matters such as allocating dates of hearing are being handled at call-overs, again by judges. These matters will now be handled by judicial registrars, thus freeing up the judges for the more complex cases involving custody of children, maintenance and property settlements. Federal Court backlogs should also be reduced because that Court will be able to divest itself of cases in certain jurisdictions. This will benefit the Federal Court and the Family Court. This initiative by the Government and the Attorney will have a flow-on effect and will reduce the backlogs that are experienced by legal practitioners and litigants in these areas.

Mr Deputy Speaker, one of the areas that I am sure the Attorney was considering when he was preparing these Bills was the problem in obtaining experienced members of the legal profession to become Family Court judges. Family Court judges will at least now have some variety in the work that they do. Whilst the Family Law Act can and does have a wide-ranging implication in the field of family law, it is still only one Act. Even magistrates in the courts of summary jurisdiction administer hundreds of Acts, but the Family Court judges administer only that one Act. Therefore, they are doing the same thing day in and day out.

In my home town of Brisbane there are a number of top Family Court judges who were highly regarded at the Bar and as leading solicitors before their appointment as judges. Whilst, obviously, no one forced them to take up their appointments, I am sure that many of them have regretted the decision to take up appointment after enduring countless days, weeks, months and years of listening to the same thing-`the husband contributed that; the wife contributed that; she is to blame; the kids want to come with me', and so on. It is the same thing day in and day out and these Bills will give some variety to these judges: they will have the opportunity of being able to decide cases in other jurisdictions.

TALK.START.PARA: —But are a lot of them qualified--

—I do not think the honourable member for Gippsland knows much about family law so I will not bother answering him. From my knowledge, one judge went from being one of the most popular barristers in town to gaining the reputation of being a nit-picker who took particular pleasure in pointing out typographical errors on application forms to legal representatives appearing before him, in an obvious attempt to humiliate the lawyers in front of their clients-presumably to relieve his boredom. Whilst many lawyers despised him for this attitude for many years and probably still do, I can understand how he must have felt. By the way, I was one of the lawyers he humiliated on a number of occasions. Hopefully, if he is not already too far gone, he might get some of his old friends back because these Bills will at last provide the variety that I am sure Family Court judges will welcome.

SPEECH.PARA: The appointment of judicial registrars is a very good provision in this legislation because there is no need to have judges handling these undefended simple divorce applications. They are simply a matter of paper shuffling. By the time the applications get to the Court the applicants have already made up their minds. Marriage guidance counselling would have occurred beforehand and the marriage is usually too far gone in 99.99 per cent of cases. It is only a matter of paper shuffling in many respects. As I said, the judges look through the applications, they get evidence from the applicants and, if all the proper points have been proven in accordance with the Act, the applicants will get their divorce. There is no need for highly qualified judges who have been top lawyers in a number of fields to do this sort of thing, given that there are so many more important contested matters in which they have to take note of evidence and decide on questions of credibility. I think there is no question that most people will agree with the Government that their time would be better spent in handling those contested matters. Of course, the judicial registrar will, in effect, handle those more mundane procedural types of things. That will save a lot of time.

The courts of summary jurisdiction will have some further powers extended. I note that the honourable member for Flinders made the point at the beginning of his speech that magistrates would handle most of the matters that were previously handled by Family Court judges. That is not correct. He tried again to trivialise the matter by saying that the Bills will hand over a lot of the jurisdiction to magistrates. That is not the case. Some matters will be handed over to the courts of summary jurisdiction, but only those in which the parties are in agreement that, for the sake of convenience, the matters will be dealt with by that court. That will obviously save them a lot of money and time. Surely, that is a good thing. It is something which I think the public and litigants will welcome. I am sure that that is one of the areas of the legislation that must be commended. I notice that registrars will be given additional functions. Again, that will cut down the delays and generally streamline the operation of the Family Law Act in practical terms.

I confirm what I have said previously-that these Bills provide a sensible and practical means of alleviating some of the problems experienced by the Family Court throughout Australia. I commend the Bills to the House, and I congra-tulate the Attorney-General for his foresight in introducing them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, thank you for giving me an opportunity to speak in the debate on the Family Law Amendment Bill 1987 and the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill 1987. I regret the way in which the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca) endeavoured, I suggest, to malign the Opposition spokesman, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), by commenting that he was endeavouring to score cheap political points and that he had trivialised the debate. It seems to me that the comments that the honourable member for Flinders made were spot on. In fact, when the honourable member for Bowman reads the transcript of his speech, he will notice that one of the matters on which he commented was the remarks of the honourable member for Flinders about delay and the problems of delay. Of course, the honourable member for Bowman in his speech substantiated that by referring to the delays in his own State. So far from trivialising it by raising the question of delay, I think the honourable member for Flinders put the matter very clearly in a proper perspective.
—What about the wigs and gowns?

—I will come to the wigs and gowns question. The matter of robing was addressed by the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act in which a number of present Ministers, including the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), in their capacity as private members, deliberated, along with me and other members of the Parliament, on that very question. It was seen as a substantial question, deserving of being addressed. It was not a matter of trivialising this debate to make the comment that this matter was thought important enough to be addressed by Labor Party members in their own Caucus.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to spend all my time rebutting the remarks of the honourable member for Bowman, except to say that his own abysmal knowledge of this area was highlighted by his comment that judges would spend a lot of time dealing with the question of blame in divorce matters. In relation to the question of divorce-and it is still the case in maintenance and custody matters-I understand that the question of fault is not an issue. Even a most superficial knowledge of the Family Law Act would suggest that the honourable member's comments to my friend the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) were quite inappropriate.

This is a debate about two important Bills. I want to make a number of simple points in relation to them because I see the reforms as being largely worthwhile, and ones which the Opposition broadly support. But we believe that the detail of the legislation, in each case, requires a little more work. One cannot be blamed, I do not think, for suggesting that this ought to be the case. The Attorney-General, in his own speech, when he introduced the Family Law Amendment Bill, said:
For 11 years the Commonwealth and the States have been negotiating for a reference of powers from the States in respect of family law matters.

I acknowledge that those negotiations have been going on for that time. We now have the result of that 11 years work. We have been given an opportunity to look at the result of that 11 years work in a period of eight days. That is the reality: eleven years work has brought forward a Bill which deals with a range of other matters as well, and are being asked to look at the detailed approach that the Government has brought forward, and to give it carte blanche approval in this House in one week and one day. The first piece of legislation was introduced last Wednesday and, in the case of the second Bill, on Thursday. Here we are, in the following week, looking at these Bills. As one who has an interest in this subject and one who invites other people to give me the benefit of their views, I have not had an opportunity to get the benefit of those views to enable me to contribute to this discussion today; notwithstanding that I have sent out copies of the legislation. I do not think that very many other members will have had that opportunity.

I make the point, very strongly, that there is established a new legislative committee on legal and constitutional affairs which, at this point, has no references before it. If it is to perform any useful role, matters must be referred to it by the Parliament or by the Attorney. The fact is that this substantial Bill, involving 11 years work, according to the Attorney's remarks, requires consideration by the Parliament in a detailed and comprehensive way if it is to be dealt with adequately.

Let us understand what these Bills are dealing with. The Family Law Amendment Bill, first, implements references of powers from New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania relating to the maintenance and payment of expenses in relation to children or child bearing, to include a wider range of children than the Family Law Act is presently able to deal with-essentially, those children who are born out of wedlock. It also extends the custody, guardianship of, and access to, children in those States and to apply the Act, as amended, to Territories in which the Act presently applies-that is, to the wider class of children.

The second matter, in furtherance of the Government's proposals for child support, announced in the Parliament on 24 March, amends the child maintenance provisions of the Family Law Act to ensure that children receive a proper level of financial support from a reasonable and adequate share of the income, property and financial resources of their parents. I emphasise that this involves both parents. All of us know of situations in which children are left in circumstances where one parent carries that responsibility, the other parent walks away from that responsibility and, very often, picks up the responsibility for other children and another family. To this point, the second family is given priority for maintenance over the first family. Of course, there is then an expectation that the community will provide additional resources to enable that family that is broken, divided, to be able to live in two separate households. They are given greater resources from the State than the families that continue to live together in one household. In fact, those families have to subsidise the others. The injustice in that is patently obvious.

Some 11 years or so after these matters were highlighted following examination by the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act and after Bills were introduced by Senator Durack and Senator Chaney to deal with this question, we now have the Government's different approach to the same subject. It is a comprehensive approach but one that deserves to be examined and if it achieves its objective, supported by Parliament. The way in which the Government seeks to do it is a matter that ought to be examined in detail.
The third object of the Family Law Amendment Bill, as set out in the outline provided, is:
. . . to require that an entitlement of the applicant for maintenance to an income tested pension or benefit is not taken into account in awarding spousal and child maintenance;
In the detailed explanations before us we are also told:

The implementation of the reference of powers means that the provisions of the Act relating to the custody, guardianship and maintenance of children may now cover ex-nuptial children within the limits of the enlarged legislative power of the Parliament resulting from the referral of powers.
But the explanation goes on to say:

However, State courts of summary jurisdiction-which have traditionally dealt with these matters-in the referring States and Territory courts of summary jurisdiction will continue to have jurisdiction in these matters.

The explanatory memorandum further explains that all maintenance cases and applications for payment of expenses of child bearing may be brought in a court of summary jurisdiction. I raise this matter in this context because the Joint Select Committee had some comments to make about these very questions. It proposed a slightly different method of dealing with the matter but I note that the Committee was broadly in support of the approach the Opposition advanced and which the Government says it is introducing in this legislation. The Committee had this to say:

The Committee has concluded that the continued existence of the compulsory maintenance provisions has undesirable consequences for the administration of Family Law. They are the source of quite unnecessary complexity and confusion in this area and should be repealed as a matter of urgency. In reaching this conclusion we are not to be taken to support the proposition that the obligation to support relatives should be transferred from the individual to the State. On the contrary, we consider that that obligation should be made quite clear and enforced more effectively than it is now being enforced.

The welfare systems should be self-sufficient. To the extent that it is necessary to proceed against the spouse of a social security client to obtain a contribution towards the support of that client, then the Department should be in the position to institute proceedings under its own legislation.
The Committee went on to recommend:
. . . that the Social Services Act be amended to delete section 62 (3) and 83 aad with a new provision to be inserted that would have the effect that:

(1) the Department of Social Security will assess the means of the liable relative and determine what it is proper for him to pay the Department in or towards satisfaction of the money they have paid out;

In other words, we were saying that the Department of Social Security should be able to pursue the defaulting parent and recover for the Crown maintenance or social welfare paid in certain circumstances to children or to a spouse. This scheme picks up that recommendation-admittedly through a different method. In accordance with the Government's March announcement we do have a more detailed scheme which gives effect to the recommendation of the Joint Select Committee. To that extent they should be supported.

I shall deal with the courts of summary jurisdiction when I deal with the second matter because it is also relevant to the cognate Bill, the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill. According to the outline provided, the purpose of this Bill is:

(a) to provide for the Family Court of Australia to exercise jurisdiction in certain proceedings under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, the Bankruptcy Act, the consumer protection provisions of the Trade Practices Act and in taxation appeals under the Income Tax Assessment Act;
(b) to create an office of Judicial Registrar in the Family Court of Australia;
(c) to empower the Judges of the Court to delegate functions to Judicial Registrars and to extend the range of functions which may now be delegated by the Judges to Registrars of the Court; and
(d) to extend the jurisdiction which may be exercised by courts of summary jurisdiction under the Family Law Act.

In other words, it is to provide a more flexible arrangement for the consideration of Family Court matters to ensure that the capacities of highly skilled, highly paid and highly competent Family Court judges are better used in the more complex and detailed matters that are often in dispute in Australia's Family Courts. I must say I support the direction in which the Government is moving. It is an advance on the approach that the Joint Select Committee proposed in its own report. When the Committee considered the matter, back in 1976-77 or perhaps a little later in that decade, it had before it a number of submissions which drew attention to the anomalies in the creation of the Federal jurisdiction in family law exercised by judges appointed to a more junior level than that of their brethren in the Federal Court. The Government is desirous of moving to a position which the Select Committee did not support, but I want to put on record that I personally see it as advantageous. Ultimately we should move to a position where judges are of a capacity and ability to be able to serve not only in the Family Court, dealing with family matters, but also hear the wide range of other questions which came before the Federal Court. The Committee acknowledged that Family Court judges needed to be highly qualified, they needed not only to be people whose personal capacities enabled them to deal with family disputes but to be judges whose background and training in general law demonstrated that they were competent practitioners, well versed in commercial and property law. If judges are to deal adequately with family disputes they have to be able to look at the range of ways in which people organise their personal affairs. Otherwise it is impossible for them to be able to adjudicate properly on the division of assets in property matters which are very often before the Courts.

If Family Court judges are seen as junior to Federal Court judges, is it any wonder the Government is having difficulty finding suitable people for these appointments? It seems appropriate to me that we should be looking to give Family Court judges a wider range of activities to deal with and we should be giving the judges sufficient work in the variety of jurisdiction that the Commonwealth has available to it to ensure they maintain and develop their skills. Ultimately we can move to a position where particularly those judges who might suffer a form of fatigue from dealing with family matters over a long period may be transferred to other areas of Federal Court activity and their skills can be properly used there. If that is the direction in which the Government is moving, I think it is appropriate.

I want to see, and I think it is a matter the Committee itself ought to be in a position to examine, the way in which this proposal is to develop; the way in which the Act itself will operate when it is in place. Proposed additional section 15a of the principal Act provides that the Chief Judge of the Federal Court and the Chief Judge of the Family Court of Australia will consult with each other in relation to the transfer of proceedings pending in the Family Court whether generally or in relation to the transfer of particular proceedings. It seems to me that that is a proper matter in which a parliamentary committee ought to be able to ascertain that arrangements are in place for these proceedings to be properly undertaken.

The further matter I want to deal with is in relation to the courts of summary jurisdiction. The Joint Committee, of whose deliberations the Attorney-General was a part, states on page 154 that it was very anxious to ensure that courts of summary jurisdiction, when dealing with family matters `or likely to exercise such jurisdiction, should be supported by the provision of services to enable them to provide the legal services under the Act that they are expected to provide'. It continues:

Conciliation services such as counselling and pre-trial procedures should be available from these courts. In this connection our recommendation No. 46 in chapter that branch registries staffed by counsellors and deputy registrars of the Family court in remote regions should be noted.

In the time available, which is very short, I want to make the point that we saw the resourcing of the courts of summary jurisdiction as being important. In the explanatory memorandum, the Attorney-General, dealing with financial consequences, makes no reference to the resourcing of those courts to better equip them to carry out the work that is to be given to them. It seems to me that another matter deserving of proper inquiry by the committee is the way in which that transfer of matters to courts of summary jurisdiction will occur and the way in which those courts will be resourced to enable them to act properly as family courts. That is also relevant to the Family Law Amendment Bill. It is certainly one of the questions that needs to be addressed in that context.

In the inquiry I would also raise another matter that I would like to see examined and on which I would like to be satisfied; that is, the question of paternity. The Family Law Amendment Bill puts the courts in a position where, in a number of cases, they will have to determine paternity. One of the important matters that we will need to be satisfied on is that people who are required to attend the court and be questioned by the court will not be put in a position where they are offering incriminating evidence that might be used in other proceedings, such as in rape proceedings. We need to be able, in a proper committee inquiry, to satisfy ourselves as to those matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harvey Mrs E.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Family Law Amendment Bill and the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill but I intend to confine my comments to the Family Law Amendment Bill 1987. I commend the Government for its initiatives in instigating these amendments, which reflect both attitudinal changes in our community and altered economic circumstances. This Bill contains several provisions but for the purposes of the debate I will comment on only two of them: Firstly, the clauses dealing with child maintenance; and, secondly, the provisions for ex-nuptial children.

SPEECH.PARA: Section 66d of the Family Law Act deals with child maintenance and states, among other things, that in determining the level of maintenance to be paid by the non-custodial parent the court must disregard any entitlement of a child or the custodial parent to income tested pension, allowance or benefit. This means, in essence, that from the enactment of the legislation separating or divorcing parents, or judges of the Family Court of Australia, cannot simply assume that the custodial parent will receive a supporting parent's benefit, and work from there.

The prime responsibility for support of a child will be thrown back on to the parents. If it transpires that the parents are unable to provide adequate support, then and only then will the state step in with a full or part supporting parent's benefit or some other form of assistance. The advantages of this will be twofold. Presumably it will prune back significantly our burgeoning social security bill, of which much of the growth in recent years has been due to increases in supporting parent's pay-outs. Also, it will discourage parents from abrogating their responsibility for maintaining their children on the assumption that, if they opt out, the taxpayer will pick up the tab.

An essential adjunct to these provisions will be the establishment of the Child Support Agency, which was announced by this Government earlier this year and which will come into effect in a few months. The Child Support Agency will give teeth to the amendments in the legislation because it will provide the means whereby maintenance will be collected forcibly from the non-custodial parent. The social security review currently being conducted has identified families with young children as those most in need. These child maintenance amendments, coupled with the establishment of the Child Support Agency, are quite revolutionary reforms in the area of child maintenance and income support. They will assist immeasurably in the achievement of this Government's aim to eradicate child poverty.

The second part of this Bill to which I wish to speak is the inclusion, under the powers of the Family Law Act, of ex-nuptial children. This is the latest in a series of legislative steps leading to the emancipation of these children. Until recent years, ex-nuptial children were legally discriminated against. They did not have the same rights and privileges before the law as children born within a marriage. Most Australian State parliaments, over the past few years, have enacted legislation dealing with the status of these children, according them equality before the State law. However, ex-nuptial children until now have not come under the ambit of the Family Law Act. This is an anomaly which has been recognised over the years, not least by Justice Elizabeth Evatt, the Chief Judge of the Family Court of Australia. In the preface to the 1983 edition of H. A. Finlay's Family Law in Australia Justice Evatt says:

In recent years more attention has been given to family relationships which exist outside marriage. While they often reflect or are influenced by the pattern of relationships in marriage they sometimes result from an unwillingness on the part of one or both to enter into a legal relationship. For this and other reasons their legal regulation presents many difficulties. Nevertheless the existence of such relationships cannot be ignored in any treatment of family law . . . Legal problems arising from such relationships ought not to preclude the full recognition and rights of children whose parents are not married.
Justice Evatt goes on:

It is to be hoped that the division of power between the Commonwealth and States in regard to the custody and maintenance of these children can be overcome. Concern for the needs of children is a principal aim of family law whatever the legal relationship of their parents.

This Bill seeks to overcome that division of powers between the Commonwealth and the States in respect of ex-nuptial children by bringing about the referral of powers from the States to the Commonwealth. The need to include ex-nuptial children under the powers of the Family Court is made even more obvious when we look at the growing proportion of children who are born outside marriage. In 1962, 5.4 per cent of live births in Australia were ex-nuptial. In 1967, the figure was 7.7 per cent; in 1974 it was 9.5 per cent; in 1980 it was 12.4 per cent; and in 1986 16.8 per cent of live births in Australia were ex-nuptial. I will not go into the possible reasons behind this trend or comment on its desirability, or otherwise, because this is not relevant. Suffice it to say that there is a large and growing proportion of Australian children who are born outside marriage and who, hitherto, have not come under the powers of the Family Court. It is time those children gained equal footing with other children. In all matters of child custody and maintenance, the welfare of the child is paramount and should not be affected by the legal status of the parents' relationship.

One might ask why provisions for ex-nuptial children were not included in the original Family Law Act as it was passed in 1975. When one harks back to the furore which the proposed Act engendered one is not surprised. It is normal, when a Labor government proposes to introduce some far-reaching, much needed social reform, that the archconservatives and doomsayers emerge in force from conservative ranks predicting, among other things, the end of civilisation as we know it.

The effect of the Family Law Act was to drag the whole area of divorce and family law into the twentieth century. However, I well recall some of the hysteria which was evident when these reforms were first proposed. One of the more bizarre claims I remember being made by the Opposition of the time was that the Family Law Act would lead to the legalisation of polygamy; that it would allow people, therefore, to have more than one husband or wife. The Bill was passed and here we are 12 years later and I have no evidence that polygamy is practised on a large scale in this country.

There is no doubt that these reforms will have their detractors. Amongst conservative ranks there will be those who will object, because of their own various narrow-minded reasons, to the conferral of rights on ex-nuptial children. The honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) warned us that this Bill was in for a bit of filibustering in the Senate. This will no doubt give some of the more maniacal elements of that chamber a chance to do their stuff and at the same time whip up a bit of moralistic fervour in the community.

There are many people in the community who still adhere to the old pre-Christian principle that the sins of the father shall be visited on the sons. I think in this case people are more concerned with the perceived sins of the mother. It was interesting to hear statements made recently by a Cabinet Minister in the Queensland State Government. She thinks that supporting parents should not receive the benefit after the birth of their second ex-nuptial child. In other words, she is seeking to punish the children and to deprive them of equal opportunity and support because of what she considered to be the irresponsibility of the mothers. These beliefs are still quite prevalent in the community. I support these two Bills. I oppose the Opposition's amendment. I thank the House for the opportunity to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my remarks specifically to the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill 1987. It might be said that this Bill attempts to rectify some of the problems presently besetting the Family Court of Australia. And boy, does it have some problems! Is it not appropriate that we should try to address some of the problems facing that Court? It really is no great exaggeration to say that the Family Court has been a failure. As we know now from subsequent events, it really was a mistake to set it up as it was as a separate court to give it the all-embracing powers that it has. The best thing to do about the problems facing the Family Court would be to admit now that it was a mistake and take some positive steps to have the jurisdiction transferred either to the supreme courts or other major courts of the States, or to a division of the Federal Court of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: When the judges of a court are subjected to assassination attempts-in one case successful-when there is a never-ending series of very substantial complaints by litigants about the treatment they have had handed out to them in the court, when there is a never-ending series of public complaints about the way in which the jurisdiction has been handled, when there are extensive delays, when there is almost universal dissatisfaction with the way in which the jurisdiction is presently being exercised, it is not illogical to conclude that something is very wrong with that jurisdiction. Something is very wrong with this jurisdiction. It is appropriate, therefore, that we should address some method of rectifying this problem.

The Government has brought on this legislation today without much notice. Nevertheless, the Bill contains some of the Government's answers to the problems besetting the family law jurisdiction in Australia. The Bill proposes to tackle the problem from two ends. It starts with the assumption that we really have to give the Family Court judges some more interesting and challenging work to do. The Government says, `We will, in effect, dilute the work of the Court by giving it matters which have nothing whatsoever to do with family law. We will give it consumer actions under the Trade Practices Act, administrative appeals, bankruptcy cases and taxation appeals so that it will have more interesting and challenging work to do'. Given the major problems facing this jurisdiction probably that is a sensible thing to do, assuming that the consultations between the Chief Judge of the Federal Court and the Chief Judge of the Family Court-assuming that they are speaking-can result in appropriate judges being chosen to deal with these matters.

Let us assume that there is some merit in the proposal. The first way in which the Government approaches this matter is to dilute the Court's work by bringing other factors into it. It is very curious, when we think about the proposal, that we will have bankruptcy cases dealt with by the Family Court. People will ask, `Where was the bankruptcy order made? The reply will be, `It was made in the Family Court'. People will ask, `Where was the taxation appeal dealt with?'. The answer will be, `In the Family Court'. It sounds very peculiar. The only way I can justify it is to say that it is the thin end of the wedge. It is one of the first steps along the road towards doing away with the Family Court altogether. Who knows, that may be a very desirable thing to do. This is a proposal which, although not for very good reasons, has some merit. The Government says that it will give the judges some other work to do.

The Government proposes to tackle the problem from the other end. It says, `We've given the judges some other work to do and now we will take away the real work, which is divorces and related matters, from the judges of the Family Court. We will give that work to a judicial registrar-a position we will establish-and to the local court of summary jurisdictions-the local magistrates court, if you like'. It says, `We will dilute the work of the Family Court and we will look again at what is the real work of the Family Court. We will take some of that work away and give it to some other judicial personality lower down the scale'. If we are going to have the Family Court staggering along as it is at the moment, there is probably some merit in appointing judicial registrars who are non-judges but who, nevertheless, will exercise the jurisdiction of the courts. There is probably some merit in appointing those judicial registrars to do the work of the Court which is presently done by the judges. But there are two problems with that and with the best will in the world I ask the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) to look at these particular problems I am about to mention. I advance them not only because of the merits of the argument but also because they are additional reasons why, as the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), said, this legislation should be referred to a committee.

The two problems about giving the work to judicial registrars are, first, that the proposed new section 26 (i) will enable the judicial registrars to be appointed for very short terms. They can, in fact, be temporary appointments. They can be appointed for a term not exceeding seven years but they will be eligible for re-appointment. There is a very great argument going on in Victoria about the appointment of temporary judges. The legal profession and Law Society as a whole has been opposed in the past to appointing temporary judges because they do not have independence. They are in effect on a good behaviour bond. That is the reason that we have always been opposed to the temporary appointment of judges. It is of no use the Attorney-General saying in reply, as he may, that these people will not be judges but only judicial registrars, because the only way in which judicial registrars can be established constitutionally is by giving them the powers of the court so that they are, to all intents and purposes, mini Family Court judges. They should not be given temporary appointments. If there is any merit in the proposal, they should be appointed and it should be left at that.
The second aspect of this proposal that concerns me is that proposed new section 26n provides:
A Judicial Registrar holds office on such terms and conditions (if any) in relation to matters not provided by this Act as are determined . . . by the Governor-General.

So, the Governor-General will set out the terms and conditions upon which these judicial registrars will be appointed. Those terms and conditions are not those that we have been told about in this Bill. We have learned the hard way that the Parliament is not told very much these days, and this is one more example of that. The judicial registrars will be appointed on terms and conditions specified by the Governor-General, not in accordance with matters set out in the Act. Frankly, we should be having a further look at this proposal. I do not oppose the concept of judicial registrars, but I suggest to the Attorney-General that he re-examine the proposal. He should have a committee of this House examine these two aspects, among others: firstly, that the judicial registrars of the Family Court will be temporary appointments and will be on good behaviour bonds, which is bad in principle, and, secondly, that they will be appointed on terms and conditions about which we know nothing because they are not set out in the Bill.

Although it may not sound too much like it, that is the good part. Now we come to the bad part. Certainly there is an overwhelming case for a committee of this House to investigate further the proposal that, to put it bluntly, divorces will be able to be performed, carried out, granted by Local Courts, by magistrates courts. Although I agree that the whole Bill should be looked at by a committee, I must say that I am opposed to this proposal. I am opposed to it because it gives to the lowest rung of the judicial ladder, the magistrates court-I do not mean to denigrate them in any way by saying that-this quite major power of dissolving marriages. Giving that power to those at the lowest level of the judicial ladder really does denigrate the standing both of divorce and of marriage. I think that is undesirable. There must be a better way of doing it.

If we had not allowed the Family Court to deteriorate into the mess that it is at present, we would not be faced with this problem. Faced as we are with the problem, this must surely be the worst solution to adopt-to give to the Local Courts the power to grant divorces. Where will this end? I suggest that it is the first step towards having Reno-type divorces, quickie divorces. We will finish up with a set-up similar to that in Nevada in the United States of America. I do not know where it will end. Perhaps the next proposal to be put forward is that divorces be granted by--

TALK.START.PARA: —JPs.

—By JPs, and, for all I know, by post offices. Perhaps some procedure will be introduced whereby a person can apply for a divorce by sending off an application with a self-addressed envelope. What will be the next proposal? Will divorces be granted by the local office of the Totalisator Agency Board or what? If the Government really proposes to lower the standing of divorce in this way, it should have a hard think about the consequences. I have learned the hard way: I do not expect the Government to take too much notice about what I am saying about this matter. However, I am strongly opposed to it. I ask the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy), who is at the table, to inform the Attorney-General that today we received representations from the Law Institute of Victoria, for a start. There is strong opposition from the Law Institute of Victoria to this proposal, as there is from other law societies throughout Australia, and also from the Anglican Church. I am glad that the Attorney-General has returned to the chamber so that he can hear my remarks. I repeat for his benefit that the Law Institute of Victoria has told the Opposition today in writing that it is vehemently opposed to this proposal that magistrates should be empowered to grant dissolutions of marriage and to adjudicate property matters up to the limit of the magistrates court's debt recovery jurisdiction.

SPEECH.PARA: Among other reasons used is the way in which this will affect matters in country courts. The Attorney-General in his second reading speech held out this great new era that is about to be launched as being of particular benefit to the country areas. The New South Wales Law Society draws attention to the fact that that is where the problem arises. Many property matters in the magistrates court are marked `Not reached' at the end of the day's sitting. One can imagine the position of a magistrate who at the end of the day is faced with half a dozen divorce cases. He will not throw himself with renewed enthusiasm into tackling those proceedings. We all know that already there are substantial delays in the magistrates court-delays which this proposal will only make worse.

I said that it was not only the Law Institute of Victoria which opposes this proposal. The Western Australian Bar Association opposes it, the Northern Territory Bar Association opposes it and I have a copy of a letter sent by the Archbishop of Melbourne on behalf of the National Social Responsibilities Commission of the Anglican Church of Australia which, as His Grace the Archbishop of Melbourne says, opposes the proposed transfer of powers from the Family Court to the magistrates court in connection with uncontested dissolutions of marriage and contested property matters up to a jurisdictional limit of $40,000. The law societies, the Anglican Archbishop of Melbourne and the National Social Responsibilities Commission all make the points that I have made and indeed seem to echo what I have said-that one must acknowledge that marriage is significant and a solemn act, and the act of divorce and the way divorce proceedings are gone through must have a corresponding significance and standing. If one is to denigrate this process in this way by shoving it off to the local court, one will lower the standing and significance of divorce and with it of marriage. Many of us are opposed to that being done and at the least feel that the matter should be re-examined.

I emphasise to the Attorney-General the absurdity of the proposals in the Bill. I know that many honourable members-and who can blame them?-do not read legislation in detail; I know also that the purpose of Commonwealth legislation these days is to prevent people from understanding what it is on about. But the way in which this proposal will work is that divorce proceedings will start off in the Family Court and bingo, they will be moved to the local court of petty sessions or the magistrates court, where the magistrate will discover that the proceedings are defended, and when he discovers that he has on his hands a defended divorce case, lo and behold, as a miraculous piece of juggling, the matter will be transferred back to the Family Court or to the Supreme Court of a State or Territory. He might not send it to his own State necessarily, he might want to send it to the Supreme Court of the Northern Territory for all we know, but it goes back the full circle. What have we done? Where have we got since 1975? We have established a Family Court and there have been assassination attempts on the judges, the whole court is grinding to a halt, the judges are becoming tired and emotional and it is difficult to get very good appointments made to the Family Court now. There are extraordinary delays in proceedings, almost universal public dissatisfaction with the way in which the Court has been functioning and then, to solve that pro-blem, we come up with the proposal under which divorce cases will be sent to the magistrates courts. If they are defended, where will we send them to be resolved after that-back to the Supreme Court of one of the States, which is exactly where we started off in 1975. Why do we not face up to the fact that we have all messed it up? The court is a major disappointment. We really have to tackle this and acknowledge the fact that the proceedings probably should be held in a division of the Federal Court or given back to one of the major State courts-the Supreme Court or the County Court as we call it in Victoria, one or the other, because we cannot go on the way we are.

Let me just conclude-I have no choice as to whether I conclude or not, my time having almost expired-by saying that there are some thorny problems in this area. The only way this House can make a substantial contribution to resolving these problems is to have a committee look at these matters at length. Let us support what the honourable member for Flinders has proposed and have this wretched business sent off for further examination by a committee of this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose I really should commence my remarks by expressing that I have a personal and vested interest in this matter. For a moment I was somewhat concerned at the persuasiveness of the remarks of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown). He suggested that the process that we are now engaged in discussing might, by some strange process of tortured logic, by devaluing the significance of divorce, devalue the significance of marriage. As a person who on Sunday will become married and who is about to enter into a period which I hope will be a very happy and fruitful time in my life, I certainly feel no abashment whatsoever in supporting this Government's proposals, which I see as a sensible and measured response to certain difficulties which have arisen in the administration of the family law.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems a peculiar situation where we are asked to refer matters to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs of this House to examine proposals which have really not been criticised from any point of substance at all. No one has objected to the proposal to confer additional jurisdiction upon the Family Court of Australia, and no one certainly could object to the proposal to integrate the operation of the State and Commonwealth jurisdiction so that the jurisdictional tangles which have beset this area for so long can be overcome. Those jurisdictional tangles, the result of High Court decisions in cases such as Demack v. Demack and Plummer v. Plummer, are cases which have caused enormous difficulties to those who have both children of the marriage and ex-nuptial children.

My colleague the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil) will be discussing this matter and raising concerns of the one State that still stands outside this sensible arrangement to confer jurisdiction over all such disputes in the hands of the one tribunal so that there is not this endless process of appeals from one tribunal to another tribunal just on simple matters of jurisdiction, raising expense to the complete disadvantage of those who come before the system. I commend the action of my own State Government, the Tasmanian Government, for looking past what might have been a simple seemingly political objection to this legislation by dealing with it on a party basis and acting responsibly to confer the necessary powers on the Commonwealth so that this very important reform can be achieved.

As to the matters of efficiency and cost, no substantive objection has been raised to the proposal to make the operation of the courts more efficient. The increased efficiency of the system is to be achieved in three ways. The most expensive elements of the system, the Family Court judges, will be used only for those matters where their expensive and lengthy training is appropriate. Family Court judges will be preserved from the need to handle routine and generally ritualistic work so that their skills can be brought to bear on more complex matters, particularly significant disputes about custody or property where their particular legal training and their skills over a wide range of issues are appropriate. They will be saved from having to deal with a series of interlocutory or procedural applications by being able to refer those matters to judicial registrars.
