SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House commends the Hawke Government for-
(1) the steps it has taken to increase the retention rate among secondary school students following the disastrous fall in numbers during the years of the Fraser Government;
(2) its achievement in significantly expanding the numbers of places in universities; and

(3) its proposals to develop skills formations in Australia so that our education system will be better able to respond to the needs of industry and thus materially assist the development of a successful and internationally competitive Australian economy.

In so moving, I am aware of the proud achievements of the Hawke Government in education in the four years in which we have been in government. They are indeed impressive, but they are made more impressive by the appalling record of our predecessors. Back in March 1983, the retention rates in our secondary schools-that is, the number of young people finishing secondary schools-stood at an abysmal 36 per cent. Currently it is 50 per cent and we have set ourselves the goal of raising that to at least 65 per cent by the early 1990s. I would compare that, Mr Deputy Speaker, with the industrialised and technologically advanced country of Japan, where currently 97 per cent of their young people are finishing secondary school.

I suppose that there are times when we start to look at barometers by which we may measure a country's performance, a country's well-being, its economic health. Certainly we cannot use our natural resources as a barometer, because if it was our natural resources Australia, above all countries, would be very affluent, but we are not. Indeed, it is its human resources. As can be seen from the example of comparing Australia with Japan, Australia has many physical resources. What we have not done in the past is develop our human resources and that is where the Japanese have really left us standing, have really left the rest of the world standing.

It is also clear that in the past Australians really have not known the value of education. We have never really seen education for what it is-and education, as I have said, does lift a country's stocks; it does lift the well-being of a country, both in its economy and also in its society. Going back to 1983 and prior to that, the conservative governments in this country ran the education system like they ran the economy and the taxation system-very sloppily, indeed, by any measure; across the education field up until 1983, there were large areas of deficiency. I will point out some of those as I go along. In fact, the education system did mirror the economy of this country.

What the conservatives really thought was that our potential were wheat fields and holes in the ground and our education system was geared to that-`Let us dig up some rocks and send them overseas-that is really all we have to do. Do not use any intellectual input to change those rocks or to put them into finished products. Let us send them to Japan and then we will buy them back again'. That is what their whole philosophy was about. The resources boom in the early 1980s just goes to show that that was the case. As to educational outputs in the previous Government's term, about 10 per cent of our young people ended up with an undergraduate diploma. As I have said, 54 per cent of kids did not even finish high school. They were really aimed at low level jobs. There were not many high level jobs in this country and that is why only that small number of our young people were coming out of universities.

Resources given to private schools illustrate another bias in the previous Government's educational policies. In fact, from 1976 to 1983 the funds given to government schools went down by 10.9 per cent and to private schools went up by a massive 76.9 per cent, showing the bias. Also built into that, of course, was the taxation system that allowed, before the fringe benefits tax, some more affluent taxpayers to pick up some of the cost of sending their children to private schools.

Let us move on to higher education under Mr Fraser and contrast that with what we are doing now. Mr Fraser commissioned the report of the Williams Committee of Inquiry into Education, Training and Employment in 1979. I will always remember the words of Myer Kangan, who brought out the Kangan report Technical and Further Education in Australia in 1974. He said that whenever you set up a committee the committee will invariably come back with a report that matches the aspirations of the government, that meets its philosophy. Let us have a look at the Williams report and see whether that was so. The then Minister for Education, Senator Carrick, said about the Williams report that it was extremely valuable because it identified the key problems in Australian education. What did it do? An article which appeared in the National Times of the day said:
The real winners from the committee's report are Australia's 19 universities, largely elitist in their own views of themselves and increasingly fearful about their roles being threatened.

There was the grand strategy for the Liberal Party for the future and the Education Minister of the day said that it had addressed the problems. What did the report say? It said protect the universities, those elitist structures; in fact, make sure that they cannot be threatened; do not expand them, do not make sure we get more people through them, but just maintain them at the present level. That gives us an indication of what the previous Government thought of higher education.
What about youth support? Here are a couple of views from two vice-chancellors, and I will read from the Australian Financial Review of 26 August 1981:

Describing last weeks Federal Budget as a `heartless' one for tertiary students, chairman of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, Professor Don George, renewed the AVCC's call for an inquiry into all aspects of student financing. He said the Budget suggested the Federal Government-
that was the Fraser Government-
was out of touch with the needs of young people and would confirm the `widely held belief' that the Government had no coherent policy on student access.
Here is another article on Mr Williams, the guy who brought down the report. It states:

The terms of reference of that inquiry instructed it to have regard to the Government's policy commitment to a widening of educational opportunities. `This Government has not lived up to its declared commitment.' He said that since 1975 there had been a 30 per cent decline in the number of undergraduate students receiving some form of government financial support.

There you have it. In higher education the Fraser Government supported the elitist structure that was always there, but would not support the young people who needed assistance to get in there. Let us contrast that with what this Government has done. I would like to give an example of a family of three children, one at each level of educational assistance. Let us say that there is one in tertiary education, one over 16 years and another aged 14 years and, therefore, not eligible for Austudy. The family income, we will assume, is $300 per week. In 1988 this family will receive family allowance of $5.25 per week, a family allowance supplement of $28 and Austudy payments of $50 a week for the senior secondary child and $60 a week for the child at a tertiary institution. The total is $143.25.

In 1983 the same family, at the same level of weekly earnings, would have been earning $199 a week. The total help they would have then received would have been $69.28, which when adjusted up to 1988 dollars would be $101. From that illustration it is clear that, under this Government, the assistance given to that needy family has gone up by 40 per cent in real terms. Let us go a little further than higher education and see what the former Prime Minister had to say about the link between education and employment. This is very illuminating. A report in the Canberra Times in March 1982 said this, when quoting the then Prime Minister:
Young people who have not done well at high school should not leave with a sense of failure, the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, said yesterday. He said it could be that the school system had failed them.
Further on it quoted Mr Fraser again:

`Not being able to master the academic courses, they quite wrongly got a sense of being failures and this sense compounded the difficulties of many students who found it harder to get a job when they left school.'

There he is getting stuck into the schools and blaming them for the fact that young people could not get jobs. He went further. He went to a talkback radio show in Esperence, and you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, it is a long way from anywhere down to Esperance so maybe he thought he could speak a little more frankly down there. A newspaper report stated:
The Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, yesterday criticised the school system for helping create unemployment among the young.

He was going a bit further there. What the former Prime Minister tried to do was to make a link between the education system and his failure to provide the jobs. Let us see what the reaction was to that. The Acting General Secretary of the Australian Teachers Federation, Mr David Widdup, said that the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, should realise that a great many people, including many teachers, were better educated than he was and would not accept unquestionably his decisions on the economy. Mr Widdup said that Mr Fraser could look forward to strong criticism when he, or anyone else, tried to shift the ills of the economy on to schools.

Another spokesman for the Australian Teachers Federation said that the Government had to create jobs because education could only shuffle the pack in the dole queue. In Adelaide the Acting Director-General of Education had this to say about the Fraser Government:
One of the fundamental failures of the Federal Government was that it had not provided enough jobs for young people and the sense of identity that went with the jobs.

Here we have the Prime Minister of the country at that time blaming the education system for the fact that there was a rising level of unemployment. The main reason, of course, was the shabby state that his Government left the economy in. In the last year of that Government 270,000 jobs were lost. The way it ran this economy was absolutely tragic and to try to shift the blame on to education does not do it much justice.

Mr Deputy Speaker, since the 1983 election the Hawke Government has dramatically increased student participation, not only in secondary schools, as I have already indicated, but also in higher education. I had a look at some numbers last night and comparing like periods-that is, the last four years of the Fraser Government with the first four years of this Government-we find that in universities there has been a 185 per cent increase in the number of young people. In colleges of advanced education there has been an increase of 172 per cent and in technical and further education there has been a massive increase in participation of 266 per cent. So that not only in our secondary schools are the retention rates going up but in higher education the participation rates have been significantly increased by this Government, as they have in apprenticeships.

The dramatic decrease in the number of jobs in the last year of the Fraser Government also affected apprenticeships. They went down to 36,000, just about an all-time low. We have lifted that to 54,000 and it would have been greater had there been a greater intake in the last year of the previous Government because of the fact that apprenticeships are spread over time. We have increased the number from 36,000 to 54,000. This Government has also created the traineeships to pick up an area of training that was always denied to those people who left school at 15 and either did not get an apprenticeship or a job, or did not go on to higher education.

I can say from experience of speaking at some of the traineeship graduation ceremonies that industry values them, the students value them, industry benefits, the students benefit and so does Australia because the stock level of the skills in this country is lifted by having the traineeships in place. It might seem inconceivable to anybody from anywhere else in the world that prior to 1983 there were no direct links between industry and our universities. The former Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, set up two committees-the Standing Committee on Industry and Education Links and the Industry Reference Group which comprised unions and industry. There were no public servants on that particular committee but they did give advice and valuable feedback on where education was going in the higher education field to try to make it more relevant to the education system.

Even though we have gone a long way, there is a long way to go and there are some challenges we really have to face. One challenge for the future is that we have to increase our research efforts in this country. The present Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) has for the first time set up a body that can bring all those areas of research together to co-ordinate them in a more meaningful way. We have been supported by the efforts of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, and his Department to make sure that the research effort in this country is lifted significantly. We also have to increase the participation rates. We come close to the bottom of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries in the number of graduates we get through higher education. Under Mr Fraser it went from 11 per cent back to 9.6 per cent. It is currently about 11.5 per cent. That is an all-time high but it is not good enough; we are going to have to lift that further.

We will have to change attitudes to education and I believe that is happening. It is reflected in the participation rates in our high schools and the number of young people who want to get into our higher educational institutions. We also have to find the resources for the expansion of higher education because, if we do realise our ambition of achieving 65 per cent or more of our young people finishing secondary school, a lot more of those people will have to go, or will want to go, on to higher education.

Our present policy of funding higher education, I believe, and I have said in this place before, is the wrong one. I no not believe our higher education should be funded totally from the Commonwealth Budget. I believe in many ways it is doing Australia harm in that we cannot get everybody into an institution who wants to gain a place. Depending on the numbers used, about 13,000 to 20,000 missed out this year and that is a tragedy. So the resourcing of education and the expansion of education are one of the challenges this Government has to face. Certainly we have to broaden the resources that come into higher education. Maybe industry can help out there, but maybe so can the students themselves. I will quote from Skills for Australia put out by the Minister. On page 19, talking about resources for skills, it says about higher education:

Finally, there is a need for more diversified sources of finance for education and training. Governments alone should not and cannot carry the full financial burden of improvements in our skills formation arrangements. Corporations and in appropriate cases, the individual beneficiaries of training, will have to carry more of the load.

That is another challenge this Government will have to take because it is one of the problem areas. It is also a highly political one, as we saw in the last election when Opposition members could not bring themselves to spell out how they were going to resource their educational effort. Certainly the educational achievements of the Hawke Government have been considerable. In our third term we are going further. We have established the Department of Employment, Education and Training. We are seeking to rationalise and streamline the advice given to government so that Australia's economic and social objectives can be addressed. There will be further reforms in higher education. Reform of education is an important component of the Government's strategy of moving Australia away from the agrarian society to an industrial and technological society.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I will not go further because I would like to leave some time for the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon). In conclusion, all I can say is that there will be a lot of tough decisions that have to be made. Certainly our past record has shown that when those tough decisions have to be made we have not shirked them. I believe that, as in the past, Australia has benefited from those decisions and the decisions we will make on education in the future will, I am sure, lead Australia to be a much better place than when we inherited that messy old economy back in 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the problems about this chamber and the reason it tends to be in some disrepute with the general public is that speeches of the kind made by the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) are all too frequently heard. There are paeans of self-praise for the Government and, of course, an attack of a particularly tendentious nature on the Opposition and on the previous Government. It does not really do much for the standard of debate for things to be conducted in this way. Samuel Butler said that the advantage of doing one's praising for oneself is that one can lay it on so thick and exactly in the right places. This is precisely what the honourable member for Canning has done.

SPEECH.PARA: There were three areas of self-congratulation in his speech: firstly, the question of retention rates of secondary students in our schools; secondly, the availability of university places; and thirdly, the proposals by the current Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) to develop skills to meet the needs of industry. These areas of self-congratulation were accompanied by huge dollops of propaganda against the Fraser Government and against the Opposition. There is a need to get some balance into the debate. I am not going to say that the present Government has done nothing good in the area of education. A number of its objectives and proposals are worthy of support and a number of its achievements are worthy of our attention. But let us look at some of the things that the honourable member for Canning said about retention rates and put them into some sort of perspective.

It is just simply not true that the lift in secondary retention rates is wholly the work of the Hawke Government. Retention rates have certainly improved in recent years but the major improvement began under the Fraser Government. The table on page 57 of the Commonwealth Schools Commission report In the National Interest shows that because of the transition education program which commenced under the Fraser Government in 1979 retention rates for students went up quite substantially. Taking the main points from that table and taking the whole period of the Fraser Government, first of all retention rates for secondary students went from 34.1 per cent in 1975 to 40.6 per cent in 1983. Again in 1984, where one could hardly say that new Hawke Government initiatives had taken hold, the retention rates went up to 45 per cent. So they went up from 34.1 in 1975 to 45 per cent in 1984 and that was essentially under the policies of the Fraser Government. In 1986, the last year noted in this table, the figure rose to 48.7, certainly an achievement for the Hawke Government which has to be applauded, but noting that the main lift occurred under policies initiated by the Fraser Government.

Looking specifically at female retention rates, these went up from 33.6 per cent in 1975 to 43.9 per cent in 1983, over a 10 percentage points rise; in 1984 they rose to 48 per cent; and they have gone since then only up to 52.1 per cent in 1986. So the main lift in female retention rates occurred under the Fraser Government and the upward curve began from the transition in education program of 1979 of the Fraser Government.

I turn to the question of retention rates for Aborigines. In Aboriginal retention rates between 1977 and 1982-the figures I have are from a different source-there was a 50 per cent increase because of the very great efforts of the Fraser Government to try to improve the very dismal performance in that area. But the main lift in non-Aboriginal retention rates began with the transition in education program of the Fraser Government in 1979. It continued under the policies of the Hawke Government and State governments.

We all agree on the need to improve retention rates in secondary education. I think it is silly to suggest that only one government has all the positive points in this area, but the serious question to be raised, which was not even raised by the honourable member for Canning, is what happens to the students who are retained in the schools. I have had occasion over the last three or four weeks to interview a number of teachers from the schools-the teachers who have to deal with the students who are now there and who were not previously there-and there is a very serious situation in the capacity of the schools to deal with these students. Coming from primary into secondary education are students who cannot read properly, whose basic mathematics are not satisfactory and the management systems and resources and arrangements in the secondary schools are simply not there to deal with them.

So there is the terrible situation of a whole lot of students in year 7 who can barely read or write and who cannot add up their sums. They go from year 7 to 8 to 9 to 10 and, heaven forbid, under increasing retention into 11 and 12 and they still cannot read or write properly because the management systems, the resources and so on are simply not available there. So, if we are not tackling that side of the equation as well as the mere number retentions, we are failing those students in a very serious way and I have had direct evidence in recent weeks of that problem.

Let us go on from the secondary education area to the question of university places. Again, the honourable member for Canning diminished his argument by overstatement. He was boasting about the achievement of the Hawke Government in increasing the number of university places but I suspect that his arguments were designed more to hide the Government's embarrassment over the fact that in 1987 20,000 Australian students who were qualified to have places in higher education were unable to gain a funded place. And, in the higher education statement made to the House earlier in this session, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training said that by the end of the century, without major changes in policy, some 75,000 qualified students would be denied entry into higher education.

The fact of the matter is, despite the selective use of statistics by the honourable member for Canning, that the Hawke Government has not done any better than the Fraser Government in terms of available places. The Budget Papers, published by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) a few weeks ago, show the increase in full time equivalent places in higher education; that is, taking into account the difference between part time and full time and the equivalent full time places, which is a measure of the basic availability of educational space in higher education, the increases each year at the moment are lower than they were when the Fraser Government left office.

When the Fraser Government left office in 1983, the increase in full time equivalent places in higher education was 2.9 per cent. In this current calendar year, the increase is 2.6 per cent; it is lower than it was in 1983-I remind the House that 1983 was a recession year-and for 1988, the projection in the Budget Papers is 2.1 per cent. So the increase in full time equivalent places for the Fraser Government was 2.9 per cent in 1983, and for the Hawke Government in 1988 is projected at only 2.1 per cent. It is not surprising that, with those figures, there are 20,000 qualified students knocking at the door of higher education and unable to gain admittance.

The Government has a real problem that the honourable member's noise is designed to hide. Where will the money come from to provide the additional places for qualified students? If indeed we have to increase the resources going into higher education-and I think we all agree that we are falling behind the rest of the world in a number of ways; we agree with the Government on that analysis-where will the money come from to expand resources for higher education? The tax dollars are simply not available. Taxpayers are already complaining about the excessive cost of government and excessively high tax.

We are also going into a period where a lot of the remarks of honourable members opposite about the economic performance of the Fraser Government are going to be placed in a most interesting context. If we are entering into a period of recession, and all the signs are that we probably will be, unfortunately, the number of tax dollars from general revenue will be under even greater pressure than they have been to date. Where will the money come from? The Government does not like private universities, which are a source of private capital funds and also private fee income; but it does not like them. Senator Ryan, the previous Minister for Education, was utterly opposed to them, and the present Minister is reported as not liking them much, but, in the case of the Bond University, is just having to accept that it is there.

The Government rejected the Opposition's proposal during the last election campaign to allow the institutions to take on extra fee paying students over and above the free places. That would be a way of allowing the institutions an additional source of private money over and above what they get from the taxpayer and also some more flexibility in dealing with their own requirements and matching their resources to the needs of the students and of their own staff. So, in this area, I would ask Government members to focus on the future; the argument about how many places have been made available in the past is a sterile argument.

I have shown already quite clearly, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the assertions of the honourable member for Canning are somewhat tendentious. He has made a selective choice of statistics and I have shown quite conclusively that the increase in university and other higher education places over 1987 and 1988 is considerably lower than the increase in 1983 when the Fraser Government left office and despite the effects of the recession of that time. So let us forget about all that argument about the past. Let us focus on the future and let us combine to work out how to get those 25,000 applicants knocking on the other side of the door over on this side of the door.

The third area raised by the honourable member for Canning was the development of skills formation. I shall quote part of the motion which praised the Government for its work. It commends the Hawke Government for:

(3) its proposals to develop skills formations in Australia so that our education system will be better able to respond to the needs of industry and thus materially assist the development of a successful and internationally competitive Australian economy.

I agree with that. I commend the proposals. But they are only proposals. I remind the House that the Hawke Government has been in office for four and a half years and now we have proposals to develop skills formation so that our education system will be better able to respond, and so on. The honourable member for Canning painted this extraordinary picture of Australia under previous coalition governments of a rural and mining backwater without any educational system worth its salt. This is just a silly, ridiculous characterisation of Australian education over the last 20 or 30 years and it is grossly insulting, may I say, to all those professionals who have been working in the system over that period.

The honourable member ignored what happened in tertiary education under coalition governments since the Menzies commission of the Murray Committee in 1957, the Martin inquiry following that looking into colleges of advanced education, and the extraordinary expansion of technical and further education under the Fraser Government which was concerned with this very same problem and, in fact, was the last major push in this area up to the time that the present Minister was making his proposals. Under the Fraser Government between 1975 and 1980 technical and further education enrolments went up from 521,000 to 702,000, and on a different statistical base, from 1981 to 1983 the number of students in TAFE went up from 692,000 to 793,000 and the numbers have not advanced all that much since then.

We welcome the new-found interest of the new Minister for Employment, Education and Training-the previous Minister for Education did not address this problem satisfactorily at all-and we certainly do join with the honourable member for Canning in commending the Minister for his proposals. We shall be looking for results and the results will have to be a jolly sight better than the Government's results under the Priority One program for youth, for example, where there was a wonderful set of proposals but absolutely no performance. We will be watching very closely for performance.

We will support the Government where we believe its proposals are sound. We will give it due credit where it has done good works but we reject silly and stupid debate using distorted figures to try to claim that the previous coalition governments did nothing or that Australia was an educational wasteland over the last 20 or 30 years, because that simply is not true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again from the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) we have heard considered opinions in debate and we should thank him for that. Nevertheless, it does give me great pleasure to second the motion of the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear). I want particularly to concentrate on the rising retention rate among secondary school students and on the expansion of places available in the tertiary sector.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember when I was in year 11, the old fifth form, at a suburban state high school and my mates and I would talk about what we would do in the following year. Some of us wanted to go on to sixth form to try for our matriculation. Some had no desire to go and others simply had no aptitude or student ability to continue that far in the academic stream. I was shocked, though, that some of the best and brightest students, many of whom were girls, told me that they would not be going on, that they would be leaving school that year. They were not going on to study at a technical and further education (TAFE) college-there were none then-or at its equivalent, the technical school, which was very much the preserve of boys at that time. That realisation that the school system was not the perfect vehicle for sifting people on the basis of merit has stuck with me ever since.

Similarly, a year later, shortly before I was to sit my matriculation examination, teachers came to ask me to fill out a form for entrance to university. There was I, a successful student, living no more than three miles from one of the oldest and best respected universities in the country and I had no idea what a university was, or that it might be the next step in the education ladder. Ignorance of the system, low achievement horizons, prejudice, insufficient income and lack of encouragement are all reasons why at that time not only some of the best and brightest were left out of the education system, but also many others who deserved at least some of the education pie.

That was before the Labor governments of Whitlam and Hawke. These two governments lifted education out of the pack. Education has been given its rightful prominence by these Labor governments which have in turn encouraged and in some cases dragged State governments kicking and screaming to lift their educational performances. The crowning achievement of all the work that has gone before is the establishment of the Department of Employment, Education and Training. For the first time the concerns of the academic stream, the skills stream and of industry and trade unions and the economy will be recognised as being intimately connected.

This breakthrough has been achieved following the great leap forward in education, the enormous jump in the secondary retention rates, the enormous expansion of retraining places, the implementation of incentives to pursue further education through Austudy, the elimination of disincentive by adjusting dole rates and the great successes of the innovative programs for the disadvantaged. The breakthrough-that is, the establishment of the super-department-will prepare the education and training sector, particularly tertiary institutions, for the next step forward. A major priority of the Labor Government in this third term is the achievement of a much greater participation by children in senior secondary education.

The Hawke Government has set itself a goal of having two-thirds of our school children completing year 12 by the early 1990s. This figure represents almost double the retention rate which existed under the Fraser Government. Already the Labor Government is well on the way to achieving its goal and resolving the mess the Fraser Government left in secondary education. Secondary retention rates have increased rapidly under the present Government. In 1982 the figure was 36.3 per cent and by the end of 1986 it had risen to 48.7 per cent. By the end of this year the figure is expected to reach 50 per cent.

The retention rates have risen dramatically in the government school sector from 29.6 per cent in 1982 to 42.3 per cent in 1986. Most important, from the point of view of a party and a government which are committed to equity, are the changes in the general socio-economic profile of children completing year 12. The goal of having two-thirds of our school children completing year 12 by the early 1990s cannot be seen simply in terms of the determination to upgrade the educational base of Australia's work force, nor can it be seen merely as part of the wide range of programs such as the Australian traineeship system and schemes for Aborigines and other disadvantaged students which are designed to improve the skills and employability of students who are unlikely ever to go on to higher education.

There is another branch to the retention rate goal which has always been present in Labor's education policy and which has begun to bear fruit. I refer to changes in the general socio-economic profile of children who are completing year 12. Recent research indicates that year 12 completion among the lowest socio-economic groups has been growing at a quite dramatic rate in recent years. Importantly, the research revealed that children from the very lowest socio-economic category, the most underprivileged 10 per cent, were by 1985 completing their full secondary education in almost the same proportion as that great bulk of children in the middle range of socio-economic measurement. Only towards the very top of the scale did participation rates take off to figures well above 50 per cent.

It appeared that from 1982 to 1985 the number of children from that lowest group completing year 12 increased at an average annual rate of around 10 per cent in Queensland and in other States. Nationally 35 per cent of children in that lowest socio-economic category were completing year 12, not far below the then national average. It appears to me that this phenomenon owes a great deal to State and Commonwealth Government efforts to provide special assistance to students, families and schools with the greatest needs.

Even more recent evidence suggests that quite apart from special programs for identifiably disadvantaged groups, participation beyond compulsory schooling by the children of the poorer sections of our society is continuing to rise dramatically. One of the main reasons is the success of the reforms to Austudy. Of the 215,000 Austudy applicants approved for payment of allowances so far this year there were no fewer than 94,000 secondary students. This is 24,000 more than last year and nearly twice the number who were receiving equivalent allowances when we came to office in 1983. The numbers can confidently be expected to rise again next year as the community learns of further increases in rates and more people accept that student allowances are a much more attractive proposition than the unemployment benefit.

The significance of the trend cannot be overstated. I am suggesting that at last we are moving towards the real breakdown of the old socio-economic barriers to entry into tertiary education; barriers which, at most, have been marginally lowered by the abolition of tertiary fees by the Whitlam Government. At the very least these figures confirm that parents and children across the economic spectrum now recognise the increasingly strong link between achievement in the education system and prospects in the employment market. The recognition of that link is wasted, however, unless families are physically able to support the educational efforts of their children. In that regard, a combination of Austudy and other family support measures by government becomes relevant.

I want now to demonstrate with a brief comparison how this Federal Government has improved the educational opportunities of the less fortunate. Using an example similar to that used by the honourable member for Canning, take the case of a family entering the new year with three children at home; one in tertiary education, one over 16 and in secondary school and another aged 14 and therefore not eligible for Austudy, in junior secondary school. The family income is $300 a week. In 1988 this family will receive family allowance of $5.25, family allowance supplement of $28 and Austudy payments of $50 a week for the senior secondary child and $60 a week for the child at a tertiary institution. That is a total of $143.25 a week towards the support and education of the children.

In 1983 the same family at the same level on the weekly earnings ladder would have been earning $199 a week. Without canvassing the details of the family allowance, the family income supplement, secondary allowance and tertiary education assistance, the total help they would then have received from government was $69.28. I am not claiming that assistance of this kind has therefore doubled since the Hawke Government took power, but after allowing for the intervening effects of inflation, that 1983 figure becomes $101.18 in 1988 dollars. In other words the assistance available to this low income family will be $43.07 more in 1988 than it would have been had pre-Labor arrangements continued unchanged. This is an increase of more than 40 per cent in real terms. I think these figures provide a telling explanation for the most encouraging movement in participation rates among what might be called the ordinary battling family as opposed to specifically disadvantaged groups.

Turning to the overall picture, government schools programs received a real increase in funding in the recent Budget. Funding for schools has been framed to support that key objective I mentioned earlier. Two-thirds of Australia's students will be completing secondary schooling to year 12 by the early 1990s. The impetus for the Government's success in this area will be maintained in 1988 by, among other things, a further increase in per capita rates for general recurrent grants.

Funding for teaching English to newly arrived students from non-English speaking backgrounds has been doubled to $24m and the special education program will receive an additional $0.7m for the support services element. All the other ongoing school programs will be maintained at the same level in real terms as in 1987. In times when it is necessary to exercise continuing economic restraint, and indeed when we achieve the first balanced Budget for more than a decade, this Budget outcome shows the high priority the Government affords to schools funding.

The second area of achievement by this Government is its considerable achievement in lifting the performance in the higher education sector. I draw from the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission's document, Selected Higher Education Statistics 1987. It is clear that there has been a marked increase of 56,176 in the number of full time students over the period 1980 to 1987. The big jump was in 1983 and the ensuing years when increases were recorded year on year. In particular, there has been a significant increase of 18,909 from 1986 to 1987, almost 9 per cent. Moreover, the figures for participation rates in higher education for 17 to 19-year-olds reveal starkly the record of this government.

The figures clearly demonstrate that participation by this key age group has recovered from the trough of the early 1980s and has surpassed the previous peak of 1976. The peak in 1976, based on the last Whitlam Labor Budget, was 95 per 1,000 which dropped away under Fraser to a low of 78 per 1,000 in 1981 and has now been restored to almost 100 per 1,000. This overall performance belies participation rates in tertiary education for different States. For instance, Queensland has below average participation in the three tertiary sectors-university, advanced education and technical and further education. Most notably though, participation in Queensland in TAFE is more than 20 per cent below the national average. I would remind the House that opportunities in TAFE are, of course, primarily a State responsibility. The participation rate for Queensland in universities is 16 per 1,000 compared to 18 Australia-wide; 20 in advanced education compared to 21; and 67 in TAFE compared to 87 in Australia as a whole.

There is obviously a need for action to increase higher education opportunities and TAFE opportunities in Queensland. For the Commonwealth's part it has already taken action on higher education. In the last few years Queensland has experienced above average growth in the higher education load relative to population. Between 1983 and 1986 the number of students in universities in Australia rose by 6.1 per cent. In Queensland they rose by 9.3 per cent. In the area of colleges of advanced education, Queensland increased in the period by 18.6 per cent with Australia rising at 11.8 per cent. That participation in higher education in Queensland is now so close to the national level due, in large measure, to the significant emphasis given to providing new places in Queensland in recent years by the Hawke Government.

The next great step in tertiary education has been heralded by the Green Paper recently released by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins). This Government has played many of its fiscal cards and has lifted the participation rates in higher education magnificently. But the next step must break new ground. I commend the Hawke Government for its efforts in education and I look forward to participating in the next great leap forward that will see higher education rates surge to the great benefit of the Australian economy and all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in this General Business debate with a feeling bordering on despair. The honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) just mentioned the Austudy scheme. Certainly if the Austudy scheme was working it could prove a very great benefit to students. I can tell the member for Petrie that the delay in the payment of those Austudy payments is causing great concern in my electorate. The students have to wait months and months and then, of course, it has another effect on those hostels in rural or isolated areas which rely on that money for their very existence. They are finding it very hard to remain in business.

SPEECH.PARA: I further despair when I learn that the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear), who moved this General Business motion, is a former teacher in technical education, an area of education that has had its funding severely decreased by 5.4 per cent this year, or an amount of $20.9m. The Government, of course, would agree that this loss has been offset by increases in funding for the various labour market training programs, but, of course, we all know about Priority One which was going to create many thousands of jobs for young people and has turned out to be another very expensive Hawke Government flop.

Mr Deputy Speaker, can you imagine an educationist, particularly in technical and further education, raising this subject as a General Business item? He obviously is much younger than I am and does not remember the very poor situation that existed in the late 1950s and the 1960s when technical colleges that were training tradesman were the cinderella institutes of the education system. The Fraser Government, of course, raised their profile and things have improved dramatically since those days, but in its usual stop and start motion this Government appears determined to take money from this section to fulfil its other political promises. Heaven help us if we return to the bad old days in technical education.

I notice also that the honourable member for Canning has a bachelor of education degree. I wonder how he feels about his colleagues now studying a few tertiary subjects who are caught up in the $250 fee payment for that privilege even though they are studying only part time. Most of them are studying to improve their teaching skills and also to increase their chances for promotion and in so doing obtain an increase in salary. Like the member for Canning, I have had some experience in technical education teaching and I can understand the situation those teachers now face where many who were studying can no longer afford to do so. Of course, this applies in the general education sphere also.

Like many others, those teachers are realising that the Australian Labor Party has forsaken its traditional base and is now interested only in big business, big unions and big government; in other words, the corporate state. There is no place there for the little Aussie battler. The honourable member for Canning spoke about the steps the Government has taken to increase the retention rate among secondary school students following the Fraser years of government. Certainly, no one could argue that the retention rate in high schools, particularly for year 11 and 12 students, has increased, but no one could prove that this is due to positive government action.

One reason for the improved retention rate is that, under this Government, young people are finding it ever more difficult to obtain work and they have, therefore, found it more beneficial to remain at school. More recently, in a move that I totally agree with, unemployment benefits ceased for 16-year-olds and this has forced many of them back into the school system. Unfortunately, while the idea to retain students in year 11 and 12 is admirable, there is truth to the saying that teachers may give lessons in reading, but whether the student is learning to read is another matter.

There appears at the present moment, as always, to be a debate about where education is going and we have certainly seen many changes occur over recent years. On the one hand, some say education has moved too far to the left, being too socially orientated, while on the other hand, if senior students are to be retained, for various reasons alternatives to the generally accepted school subjects must be provided. What it boils down to is that decisions on education seem to be made in the short term as a result of just about every minority group exerting pressure, and the Government trying to appease them. Whether it be the social welfare group, affirmative action, reduction of sexism, ethnic orientation, Aboriginal studies, sex education in schools, peace studies, the list goes on and on, and all this is on top of trying to prepare some students for further discipline studies in technical and further education, in advanced colleges or in universities.

All this is expected to be provided without really saying what resources are to be made available. Some educationists have informed me that, in the state school system, there are many good schools existing in this nation, but there are some very poor ones and the gap between the very good and the very poor schools is widening. Apparently, there are some schools where it is neither physically nor emotionally safe for many of the students or the teachers. This can be seen in some high levels of absenteeism in particular schools. In my opinion, most schools of which I am aware in my electorate can do anything, but they cannot do everything.

What needs to be done is for a cross-section of the community, including parents, teachers, industry and commerce and government representatives, along with anyone vitally interested in education, to get together to decide exactly what we want from our education system, how much it will cost, and then give that system priorities based on how much can be afforded. It does not matter if that inquiry takes some time, but let us get it right this time and let us have a clarity of purpose that is presently lacking.

The honourable member for Canning has suggested that there has been some achievement in expanding the number of places in universities. I would like to remind him that one of the problems facing tertiary institutions has been the dramatic cuts in funding over the past decade, with a Labor Government having been in office for nearly half that time. Despite a funding decline between 1975 and 1985 the system produced 33 per cent more graduates and, according to William West in yesterday's Australian, the strain on the system has increased since then. The capacity of universities and colleges to absorb further real funding cuts has been exhausted. Any further cuts would lead to reducing either access to higher education, or educational standards or both.

According to a survey by the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee and the Australian Committee of Directors and Principals, between 13,000 and 20,000 eligible students missed out on getting into higher education this year. This was 20 per cent more than the 11,000 to 16,000 who missed out last year and next year, of course, the situation is going to get much worse. As I stated earlier, a big contributing factor to the numbers wishing to enter tertiary education is the Government's wish to keep students at school until year 12, in a bid to reduce unemployment. So on one hand we have more students expecting a place in tertiary educational institutions and, on the other hand, the institutions themselves with not enough funding.

The third matter raised by the honourable member referred to proposals to develop skills formations in Australia that will enable the system to better respond to the needs of industry and thus materially assist the development of a successful and internationally competitive Australian economy. This, as the honourable member for Canning has stated, partially refers to new initiatives by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), and he is accepting advice, of course, from the so-called purple circle in relation to tertiary education.

The actions of the Minister have met with a mixed response from academics throughout Australia, with sustained argument from people such as the Vice-Chancellor of Queensland University, Professor Brian Wilson, and Wollongong University's Professor Ken McKinnon. Amongst those to welcome the Minister's action is Professor Mal Logan of the Monash University, who is himself a member of the so-called purple circle. The Australian Committee of Directors and Principals has aligned itself with the Minister also.

What is the Minister's new direction for tertiary education? According to Professor Logan, under the new directions tertiary education institutions are being forced to adopt a new approach characterised by leadership, efficient management and priority setting, client orientation, accountability and service. The purpose of all this is to lift Australian participation rates to a level comparable with that of its main trading partners and, heavens knows, that is needed. Whilst I agree with the general thrust of the Minister, I should remind him that he could be placing under threat the whole concept of what a university is. William West states:
Universities are communities of scholars dedicated to pushing back the frontiers of knowledge as well as imparting it.

Universities cover the whole range of disciplines from the humanities to professional studies and the social and natural sciences at a very high level. Universities are about turning out educated people, not only those schooled in the skills that will earn them a living. I would remind the Minister of the six criteria that a team from the Harvard University has come up with that define the education of a man or woman. A summary of these criteria was given earlier this year by the Chancellor of Queensland University, Sir James Foots. Members will recall that Sir James had a distinguished career in the mining industry which included periods in Broken Hill and Mount Isa. If anyone would be inclined towards obtaining technical skills, he would be.

He is highly educated and a great man, a great Australian; he reminds us that an education must equip a person first to be able to read and write English. On this point I am afraid our school system has let us down badly. I do not blame the teachers for this but I certainly blame the policy makers. Many students today cannot write legible English because of the continuing changes in scripts taught over recent years and in some cases that I have come across, the spelling and grammar are atrocious. For example, this week I received a letter from a student who has been accepted as an exchange student. He wrote and advised me that he had been `excepted' as an exchange student. Does this mean he is an exception as an exchange student and will not be going overseas? No, I am sure he has been accepted. He finds difficulty in spelling because the system has let him down.

This is no isolated case in my general experience and how very important it is that we should all be able to communicate with each other. I once received a letter from a primary school teacher that I could not understand because I could not read the writing. The second criterion suggested that an educated person should have a critical appreciation of the ways in which knowledge is gathered through the sciences, the social sciences and the humanities. It is my hope that the Minister's blitzkrieg does not interfere with that process.

The third criterion suggests that a person have some rigorous thinking through a study of history and philosophy about moral and ethical problems. The next criterion is one on which we badly fall down if reading student magazines is any indication. This is that a person should have good manners and high aesthetic and moral standards. While the majority of our tertiary students would have those values, they are apathetic enough to allow those people who create an image for them through university magazines and other media outlets to depict them as bizarre, sex-crazed, uncouth booze artists with little respect for authority or anything of value.

Finally, an educated person should have some depth of knowledge in at least one field, whether it be history, economics, law or whatever. In principle, universities see no problem in helping the manufacturing industry solve its problems but they fear that if the emphasis is placed on technological skills without building up the whole system, the university system will fail.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I thank you for allowing me the opportunity to say a few words on this important subject raised by the honourable member for Canning in General Business today. There are many other issues that I would like to touch on in the education system, such as the provision for handicapped persons, particularly in New South Wales where the Government has a policy for those people who are handicapped to come into the mainstream of education. While that is its policy, of course, it does not provide the funding and there are a number of students in my electorate who will not be able to go on to high school education because of that problem.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 1.45 p.m., in accordance with standing order 109 as amended for this session, the debate on the motion is interrupted.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Mrs Kelly) agreed to:

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I hope that the honourable member for Canning, as a former educator in a very important area, is not fooled by his own Party's rhetoric and sees the present situation as it really is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks) for his contribution.
—It was a good contribution.

—It was a fine contribution. Unfortunately he was in error in some areas and I hope to point them out. I would also like to thank the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) for his contribution and to highlight the contributions made by the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) and the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns). In addressing the House in this debate, I would like to point out that, like the member for Riverina-Darling, I too have a background in education as has the honourable member for Canning.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that both the honourable member for Riverina-Darling and other educators who have come to this place can share a common concern and a common interest in the question of education because it is my view, and I am sure that it is a view which is accepted by all honourable members of this House, that unless we have a joint approach and adopt a very progressive attitude towards the educational needs of our society, we will not be able to compete in the international arena as we would hope to do.

However, Mr Deputy Speaker, my purpose in speaking today is to address the first part of the debate, the first point that is raised in the motion, and that is the steps that this Government has taken to increase school retention rates. It is my view that the steps the Government has taken in this area leave the Opposition flushed with shame, despite what the honourable member for Mackellar has had to say. During the years of conservative governments that this country has had to bear, our greatest resource, our young people, was constantly neglected. This Government has done something that the Opposition, when in government, was not capable of. This Government has fulfilled its promises in regard to rebuilding retention rates in secondary schools. Since the Hawke Government has come to office, secondary school retention rates have soared.

I would like to reiterate the points made by the honourable member for Petrie. At the demise of the Fraser Government, secondary school retention rates were a shade over 36 per cent. By the end of 1986, this figure had leapt to almost 49 per cent, an increase of 13 per cent and a concrete demonstration of this Government's commitment that I have mentioned earlier. However, because of the paucity of vision and all those unfortunate years of conservative government after World War II, Australia has found itself left with one of the lowest secondary school retention rates among the developed nations of the world. For example, in comparison with countries like the United States and Japan, we lag considerably. In 1982 in the United States, 78 per cent of 17-year-olds were still at school and in Japan, 94 per cent of 17-year-olds were remaining at school. These figures demonstrate the legacy of educational malpractice indulged in by the conservative governments that ran this country for great periods of time since 1949.

This Government, aware of the fundamental importance of education to the development of this nation's human and material resources, has made a commitment to have a 65 per cent retention rate to year 12 by the early 1990s. May I say that, given the record of this Government so far in this area, one would expect that it would in fact exceed that target figure.

A new affirmative approach to making the final years of secondary schooling more attractive and more relevant to our secondary students is the basis of this increased retention rate. This Government is taking major steps towards increasing retention rates among secondary school students following the disastrous performance of the Fraser Government. However, this cannot be done without money. I would like to quote from the Budget night address of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) and his Budget night Press material that effectively demonstrate how this Government follows election commitments with direct action. The Minister said:

Overall, general recurrent grants will rise by almost $60m, a real increase of some 4.8 per cent over 1987. The budget for schools has been framed to support the Federal Government's primary objective that by 1992 two-thirds of Australia's school students will be completing their secondary schooling to year 12.

He also said that the Government would maintain this impetus by further increasing the per capita rates for general recurrent grants amounting to a total of $1.3m; by doubling funding to $24m for teaching English to newly arrived students from non-English speaking backgrounds; by funding a $1m curriculum development project aimed at encouraging girls to study maths and science in senior school; and by maintaining the level of capital grants at $220m.

No conservative government ever demonstrated this sort of commitment to public education in Australia. No conservative government ever cared enough for our young people to make this sort of commitment. No conservative governments would be capable of this because their policies are now run by those New Right think tanks who run off at the mouth about education as a labour market commodity. Their education policies are not relevant or appropriate and that is yet another reason they were rejected by the people in the July 11 election.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I have read recently in an article called `Youth in Transition' by M. E. Poole from the Review of Recent Research in Australian education that key educational changes during the period 1978 to 1982 were to halt the previous period of expansion which one would assume was during the Whitlam years and to cut back on educational spending. Real public outlays on education declined in 1979-80 and remained at a low level in 1980-81 and 1981-82. It is no small wonder that there was not the improvement in retention rates in the Fraser years that was required by the people of Australia, and no small wonder that the previous Government's policy has once again been soundly rejected by the Australian community. The Fraser Government had one of the most short-sighted policies this country has seen. Instead of investing in our future and supporting education it hacked away at it. In the Fraser years the interest was in building tax shelters for business instead of futures for our children.

The Hawke Labor Government has finally broken the barrier that meant unemployment allowances were worth more than educational allowances and this must be seen as a positive incentive towards high school retention rates and educational retention rates in general. Following announcements made in the Budget the Minister for Employment, Education and Training told the House that unemployment benefits will no longer outstrip educational allowances, providing strong incentives for young people to remain in education or training. This fundamental reform, which will encourage younger people to stay at school longer instead of leaving for the larger employment benefit payment, started in 1985 as a central part of the Government's youth strategy.

Mr Deputy Speaker, from next January the Government will take the following measures which will continue to encourage young people to stay at school: a job search allowance will replace unemployment benefits for 16- and 17-year-olds. This allowance provides for a basic rate of $25 per week and an income tested supplement of up to a further $25 a week. Increased Austudy rates will equal the job search allowance. On 1 January 1988 the Austudy allowance will rise from $40 to $50 which is at the at-home secondary rate. This rate is means tested. So far this year 215,000 applicants have been approved for payment of Austudy. Of these, 94,000 are secondary students, an increase of 24,000 on last year's total. As the honourable member for Petrie pointed out, what has happened in this instance has been the targeting of the disadvantaged groups in our community.

The most disadvantaged of our socio-economic groups within the Australian community are being given direct incentives to have their children stay at school. It is a direct incentive which this Government is keen to promote and to continue to promote so that there is equity in educational outcomes within the Australian community. The Government is budgeting for further increases next year and will remove the previously available allowance for young people to undertake short term training. All these steps will provide encouragement for young people to stay at school. It is actions like these that have helped and will continue to help the retention rates at secondary schools to rise. However, it is the area of retention rates for Aboriginal secondary students that causes me some concern. The report of the House of Representatives Select Committee on Aboriginal Education published in September 1985 states:
The retention rate of Aboriginal secondary students is significantly lower than that for the rest of the community.

The Commonwealth Department of Education noted that in 1984 the retention rate to year 12 of Aboriginal students receiving Aboriginal secondary grants was 13.1 per cent. This compared with a retention rate of 45 per cent for non-Aboriginal students. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island students seem to suffer more than the rest of the population with regard to educational outcomes. In particular, in the Northern Territory, year 12 retention rates are only one-third of those for the Northern Territory as a whole. Although Aboriginal students make up 33 per cent of the 17- to 64-year age group in the Northern Territory they comprise only 7 per cent of the student population in that age group.

In the last Budget the Government increased the amount to be spent on Aboriginal student assistance by more than $7.8m. Since 1983 this Government has doubled the spent amount on the Aboriginal secondary grants scheme (ABSEG) and the Aboriginal study grants scheme (Abstudy); consequently the number of students assisted has increased from 30,000 in 1982 to 46,000 last year. Applicants for allowances under ABSEG and Abstudy will continue to be exempt from the income test, another positive incentive for Aboriginal students to remain at school. Students over 16 years of age receiving ABSEG and those over 21 years of age in Abstudy will receive higher rates of allowance if they are enrolled in employment oriented courses.

Madam Speaker, the Government's major concern is to involve more Aboriginal students in all forms of educational training which are likely to facilitate increased employment. Nowhere is this more important than in the secondary education field. It is the secondary retention rates that I am most concerned with. I would highlight the efforts of educationists in this field, the professionals who have the job in the work place to promote the retention of students by offering courses and providing professional stimulus to the outcomes of those students.

I would like to point particularly to the developments that have been made and the efforts being made by the teachers in the secondary school system within the Northern Territory. In the Northern Territory over the last two years there has been the development of secondary colleges. There has been much public debate over the development of those colleges. In 1985 the Northern Territory Government said that no secondary college in the Northern Territory would contain more than 1,000 students. What we have found, Madam Speaker, is that this year Casuarina College in the northern suburbs of Darwin-the only secondary college in Darwin-will have 1,240 students, creating severe restrictions on the ability of the teachers to cope, although they have responded magnificently, and they are to be applauded for their efforts.

It is important to recognise that whilst the Commonwealth has taken the initiative to promote high school retention rates and retention rates for Aboriginal students in particular, the State governments should take up the gauntlet which has been thrown down to them by this Government. It is very important that they accept their responsibilities to provide the resources which are required if students are to remain at school and provide the incentives that are required for those students to stay at school. That means providing courses which the honourable member for Riverina-Darling was not quite sure were appropriate. It might well mean that not all students want to do maths and science at year 11 and 12 levels.

It is important to recognise that those students' needs must be recognised by educationists and by the school system. It is very important to recognise that if we want to manage our human resources in an appropriate and adequate way we have to provide our students with the skills that are required. It is my view that this Government has done more than any other government since the Second World War in promoting the needs of education and retention rates in secondary schools and should be applauded for doing so.
