—I address my question to the Prime Minister and in doing so I welcome him back and trust that he has recovered from his recent indisposition. Will the Prime Minister give a categorical assurance that, beyond the survey conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, which is now awaiting his examination, there will be no inquiry into wealth in Australia?

—What I have said is that I will examine the report that has been given to me. I will be discussing it with my Ministers and colleagues in Caucus. I will be announcing the decision of the Government in the light of those discussions.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. What action have the Government and/or the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody taken to ensure that the families of those Aboriginals who have died in custody are advised of their rights in respect of the Commission and in particular of their rights to appear before the Royal Commission themselves or to be represented by legal counsel? What action will the Government and/or the Commission be taking to ensure the protection of Aboriginal and other witnesses appearing before the Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. A number of members on both sides of both chambers have raised with me the points covered by the question. When the Royal Commission was announced, the Prime Minister indicated that legal aid would be made available to all families of the deceased. In September I asked the National Aboriginal and Islander Legal Services Secretariat, known as NAILSS, in consultation with the Committee to Defend Black Rights, to develop a strategy for the provision of legal aid. NAILSS is currently developing a strategy in consultation with Aboriginal legal services around the country. Most of the families and relatives of the deceased are known to the legal services; they have provided representation for many of the coronial inquiries.

ANSWER.PARA: I emphasise to all members of the families of the deceased that legal aid will be provided to them by the Government. It is an important point to make. We have stressed that point and I want it understood by all the families that they are entitled to legal aid and that has always been the case. The Government has allocated $900,000 this financial year for this purpose. The Royal Commission has also advertised its establishment widely in the Press, and in advice to the legal services, including advertising in local news- papers in areas where the deaths in custody have occurred.

Counsel assisting the Royal Commission, Geoffrey Eames and Bob Bellear, are in the process of visiting or contacting legal services in all States and the Northern Territory and where possible meeting with families of the deceased to inform them about the Commission, including how they can be represented in the Commission hearings.

The Commissioner has indicated that he considers it of paramount importance that experienced legal representation be arranged as soon as possible for persons likely to be interested or involved in the Commission, particularly the families. If anybody has concerns about their legal representation or has general inquiries about the Commission, he should contact the nearest legal aid service or call the toll free number of the Commission, 008 026374.
Opposition members-Oh, Come on!

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that after an event in this place the other day a number of people expressed concern about the issues raised by those people.
—Well, make a statement.

—I would expect the honourable member not to be interested. This is a matter of grave concern in the community and I am doing what I can to enlighten those people on what provisions have been made available by the Government. I would have thought that a little bit of silence and respect for those people would have been of benefit to everybody.

ANSWER.PARA: The matter raised in the second part of the question was the protection of witnesses. That matter has been raised by honourable members on both sides of the House. The legislation under which the Commission operates, including certain State legislation, provides the Commissioner with very wide powers for ensuring the protection of witnesses. As the counsel assisting, Mr Geoffrey Eames, outlined on radio last week, it is an offence for any person to interfere with, threaten or prejudice a witness in any way either before or after he or she has given his or her evidence.

If it appears that the protection of witnesses may be required after a hearing or beyond the Commission's life, the Commission will make a recommendation to the appropriate government or agency to ensure that means are set up whereby surveillance and regular contact and quick or unimpeded communication are available to those people. In addition, the Commissioner has very broad powers to deal with instances of contempt of court and interference with witnesses, and such actions also fall under this category. I table a background paper made available to me by the Commission, for the information of honourable members. I am really amazed that Opposition members find this funny.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. I refer the Treasurer to the disturbances in the foreign exchange market in January this year when the cross rate between the Australian dollar and the Japanese yen fell to a low of 99 on 14 January, prompting the Reserve Bank of Australia to tighten monetary policy and the Government to announce that it would bring down a May economic statement. As the Australian dollar-yen rate has fallen to about 92-well below that recorded in January-I ask the Treasurer: Can the Government maintain the current setting of fiscal and wages policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a foolish proposition! What a totally absurd predication for a question! The implication of the question is that the Government continued the tightness of monetary policy because it keyed off some cross rate with the Japanese yen at some time in January, during the European monetary system realignment. That is so ridiculous as hardly to warrant comment.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition members are giggling. I mean, really! Over a period the Government has tightened fiscal policy to relieve some of the burden on interest rates. We introduced a rapid adjustment to fiscal policy in the 1986-87 Budget, a further consequent reduction in the May statement and a further reduction in the Budget this year. We have seen interest rates decline because we wanted to see the inhibitions to higher levels of investment removed. The only way of weighting policy off monetary policy was to take an ambitious approach to fiscal policy. That is the basis of the change, not some proposition about tying the rate of the Australian dollar to the yen. If that is the best question the shadow Treasurer can ask, the Opposition is in real trouble.
—I address my question to the Minister for Community Services and Health.
—It will be better than Andrew's.
—Anything would be better than Andrew's question.
—Order! The honourable member will get on with his question.
—Will the Minister inform the House as to the benefits of a universal health insurance system and the need for retaining the community rating principle in health insurance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The health policies of the Government have been based on three basic principles: firstly, universal cover; secondly, that payments for health cover should be related to a person's ability to pay; and, thirdly, that private insurance, for those who want it, should be based on community rating. This week we learned that the Liberals had abandoned their election policy on health and were to produce a new health policy. The first thoughts on that policy-I shall not describe them as anything more than that-were widely circulated in the Press this morning. This year 1987 is rather an annus mirabilis for health policies from members of the Liberal Party. This is the third set of thoughts they have had on health policy in the one year. What we learn from the latest thoughts is that all of those three basic fundamental principles will go: universality of cover will go; payment based on relation to ability to pay will go; and community rating will go for private health insurance. Let us just look at the consequences of those kinds of decisions. First of all, if universal cover goes, we go back to the Liberal past when over two million people were without cover in health insurance.
—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. The point of order is that two million people were not without cover.
—Order! That is not a point of order. The honourable member knows that it is not a point of order. He will not raise such a point again.

—Apart from the return to the past when two million Australians were without insurance cover in this country, the result of getting rid of the system of paying according to income means that the very high costs of health impose an impossible burden for many people. Even in the area of community rating in relation to private insurance this Government supports community rating, will go on supporting community rating and will take further steps to ensure community rating because unless all of those insured are bearing that burden it means that the sick and the elderly have to pay much more.

ANSWER.PARA: What is being advocated by the Opposition is an approach to the American system of health care; that is, an open competitive system. In the United States today 12 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) is spent on health, yet costs are exorbitant, fees for medical treatment are very high and 35 million Americans are without health cover. In Australia we spend only 7.5 per cent of GDP and we have 100 per cent of our population covered. I remind the Opposition and the Opposition spokesman when he has his further thoughts on health that he should take notice of the very wise comment of his own Party's policy at the last election. It states:
Our promise to tear up Medicare disturbed the most dangerous of all political sleeping dogs. No subject is more important and we promised to alter it yet again.
A significant number of people still care about social values as well as balance sheets.
I recommend he consider the wise thoughts of the honourable member for Boothby.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Treasurer. I remind the Treasurer of the statement made in this House on 18 September by his colleague, the Minister for Industrial Relations, when that Minister said that productivity improvements under the second tier in 1987-88 would not be significant. I also refer the Treasurer to the fact that Australia's rate of wage and price inflation is higher than that of our trading competitors. I ask: Because of these facts, will the Treasurer be advising the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) that further wage increases which are not offset by productivity improvements are entirely inappropriate and that Australia simply cannot afford them? Or is the Treasurer expecting to receive from the ACTU his riding instructions about the wages policy?
—Order! The last part of the question is out of order. The Treasurer will answer the first part of the question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought it would have penetrated the honourable member's mind that an improvement in work practices and a change in productivity flows through the system over time, coming from the beginning of those changes, and that the simple idea that is in the mind of some members of the Opposition that a 4 per cent agreement on the part of some of the parties to pay a 4 per cent improvement in nominal wages has to be instantly offset by a 4 per cent productivity increase is, of course, nonsense. It has never been the Government's intention, never argued by the Government and should have been comprehended by the Opposition. What we are seeing is the capacity of the economy to keep two things in focus: that is, the growth of nominal wages and unit labour costs. That keeps the issue of productivity under focus. We now have, with the maturity of wage fixation under this Government, a wage system which has an eye on those three things-nominal wages, productivity and unit labour costs. This system is unwinding restrictive work practices put into place broadly in the years when the Opposition was in government and had no interest in the matter. Certain management practices occurred in the years when the Opposition was in government but it never saw fit to worry about them. The unwinding of these things will improve the productive capacity of the Australian economy so that we can have a higher level of nominal wage growth while at the same time being able to see a substantial improvement in real unit labour costs.

ANSWER.PARA: The proof of the pudding is in the eating, and we have seen a decline of about 10 per cent in real unit labour costs over the last 3 1/2 to four years. That is in marked contrast with the wage mayhem which existed in the years of the last coalition government, particularly in the last couple of years of the Leader of the Opposition's period as Treasurer. I can see no point in the Opposition trying to continue to mount a case in the House by implying that a 4 per cent improvement in wages has to be offset instantaneously by a 4 per cent improvement in productivity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Prime Minister been drawn to the criticism of Stalin made by Mr Gorbachev in his recent speech in Moscow? Are there any implications for Australia in this?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that the question of the role of Stalin continues to trouble Soviet politicians, theoreticians and historians. I noticed that Mr Gorbachev in his speech on the occasion of the seventieth anniversary of the Bolshevik revolution made a number of criticisms of Stalin, of the crimes committed under his rule and of his cult of personality. He announced that a new commission had been set up to study rehabilitation of the dictator's victims. Western attitudes towards the Soviet Union will necessarily be influenced by the degree to which the authorities will be able to deal objectively with the role of Stalin. No doubt the Soviet Communist Party will continue to grapple with this tragic and troubling historical legacy. It is clear that there is a very considerable way to go before we can say that justice has been done. I notice that something very similar is happening in this country in the Liberal Party of Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —This is very serious indeed. I notice that the recent Stalin figure of the Liberal Party, Malcolm Fraser, is building up his own cult of personality--

—Madam Speaker, I take a point of order. I draw to your attention to the fact that the question in no way related to the Liberal Party or a former Prime Minister. Under standing order 145 the Prime Minister should be directed to return to the first part of the question.
—Order! I trust that the Prime Minister will be relevant with his analogy.

—Madam Speaker, I always want to be relevant. I remind you that I was asked whether there were any implications for Australia in this. I noted that the recent Stalin figure in the Liberal Party, Malcolm Fraser, is in the process of attempting to build up his own cult of personality through such historical treatises as that of Dr Philip Ayres. These treatises purport to show that that former figure did nothing in his period of seven years but spread sweetness and light and deregulation.

—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. As has been pointed out by the honourable member for Farrer, the Prime Minister was asked a question about Mr Gorbachev, his recent speech and implications for Australia. Silly as it is for the Prime Minister to engage in this diversion, it is also, in my submission, clearly out of order and irrelevant. I would ask you to so rule.
—Order! I hope that the Prime Minister is answering the part of the question concerning implications for Australia. I expect him to return to that aspect.

—I had hoped that honourable members opposite would have understood that I was drawing a light-hearted analogy. I was trying to draw an analogy with the attempted rewriting of history which is going on in this country with regard to the Liberal Party. I conclude by saying that we are watching the attempts of certain people, such as the current Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the National Party in the Senate, to dissociate themselves now from what happened in that period. In regard to the period of Stalin, there was one great and morally unavoidable question which had to be asked of those people who were following him: `What were you doing at that time?'. It is appropriate that a similar question be asked now of the Leader of the Opposition and those who would now seek to denigrate the previous Prime Minister: `What were you doing at that time?'.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Shipton

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Speaker: I ask you to rule on two points. The first is that the analogy that the Prime Minister has drawn that a former member of this House and Prime Minister is Stalinist by nature is unparliamentary language. I ask for that ruling, Madam Speaker. My second point of order is that the Prime Minister should be made to withdraw his comments about the Leader of the Opposition. I refer to what Pettifer's House of Representatives Practice says on page 460 in relation to references to and reflections on members and relate that to the Stalinist nature of the Prime Minister's answer to the question. Pettifer states:

INTERJECT.PARA: The practice of the House . . . is that a Member cannot direct a charge against another Member nor reflect upon his character or conduct unless he does so upon a substantive motion which admits of a distinct vote of the House.

I believe that the matters to which the Prime Minister referred in relation to the Leader of the Opposition should be the subject of a substantive motion and not answered in the way in which the Prime Minister is doing in Question Time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I say to the honourable member for Higgins that it did not occur to me at any time that the Prime Minister was in any way impugning the Leader of the Opposition when he referred to Stalin. In regard to the honourable member's first point raised, there is no point of order. I call the Prime Minister.

—I conclude by saying that the Liberal Party certainly needs, and as quickly as possible, the equivalent of a Mr Gorbachev who can rewrite the history of the period of the last seven years. Until that is done the credibility of the Liberal Party will continue to be as it is now-in tatters.
—My question is addressed to whoever is representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, as I understand the usual two are swanning around the world at present.
—Order! The honourable member will just ask the question.

—My question is: Will the Minister confirm that the Government has almost doubled the insurance premium rate for Export Finance Insurance Corporation cover for Australian Wheat Board sales to Egypt and also reduced the percentage cover from 85 per cent to 80 per cent for the next three years? Why is the Government discouraging desperately needed agricultural exports to our third largest wheat market when there is a satisfactory repayment arrangement in place between the Wheat Board and Egypt and when our major competitor grain exporter countries, Canada and the United States of America, provide 100 per cent grain export cover, and at lower premium rates?

—I thank the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia for his question. Let me say at the outset that no action is being taken by this Government to discourage a much needed increase in wheat sales abroad; in fact, the opposite is the case. The efforts of this Government to expand our international sales and international trade and to expand Australia's efforts abroad are well known. I would have thought the honourable member would have joined in those efforts rather than seek to deprecate them in this way.
—Why is the Wheat Board considering no longer exporting to Egypt because of your action?
—Order! The honourable member has asked his question. He cannot keep on asking.

—The extent of national interest insurance cover for wheat credit sales is reviewed each year by Government. The Government has decided to continue national interest insurance cover for the sale of wheat on credit to Egypt in 1987-88. There will be a small reduction in the level of cover but this will not prevent the Wheat Board from making a sale. Negotiations with Egypt in respect of the sale will take place next week. The reduction in the level of cover reflects the increased risk of selling into Egypt. A significant proportion of Egypt's external debt is currently the subject of rescheduling, and this includes a proportion of amounts outstanding on Australia's previous credit sales of wheat. The Australian Wheat Board, under its insurance policy, will be able to make a claim on the Government for the insured portion of this debt. The Government recognises the importance of the Egyptian wheat market to Australia and it has decided that, even in the year of lowest supply, cover should be provided to facilitate the Wheat Board in continuing to service this market. However, the Government also took the view that because of the larger risk now involved in selling wheat to Egypt the Australian wheat grower should bear a larger proportion of the risk.
—On a point of order, Madam Speaker: The Minister has made no reference to the $2 1/2m extra premium that now is required of the wheatgrowers of Australia.
—Order! The honourable member does not have a point of order.
— I take a point of order, Madam Speaker. The answer I gave covered quite comprehensively the points raised by the honourable member.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not a point of order either--

INTERJECT.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —And I can say that without help from my left.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade Negotiations. I preface my question by quoting from the Sales Tax Amendment Bill 1986 debates in this place on 26 September 1986. The honourable member for Mackellar, the Opposition spokesman on economic matters at that time, in commenting on the Government's decisions in relation to tax on wine, said:

QUESTION.PARA: The doubling of the tax also runs contrary to the Government's policy of encouraging exports. This is an export industry.

Can the Minister inform the House of the impact of the tax on wine exports? Can he inform the House of the latest figures? Do the figures show that yet again Opposition economic spokesmen have been proved to be incompetent?

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for McEwen for his question. He of course has a particular interest in this matter, representing the electorate that he does. I am pleased to advise the honourable member for McEwen and all members of the House that the volume and value of Australia's wine exports in 1986-87 were the highest on record. The volume of exports nearly doubled from 10.8 million litres in 1985-86 to 21.2 million litres in 1986-87. The value more than doubled from $20.5m to $44.6m. There has been an increased acceptance of Australia's wines in key markets, particularly in the United Kingdom, the United States, Canada and Sweden. Sweden, which is the largest single market, takes over five million litres, while the United States recorded the sharpest growth, both in volume and value-a trebling-and was the highest priced market. I am pleased to advise the honourable member that exports have continued to increase strongly in 1987-88.

—I refer the Prime Minister to the impending treaty between the United States and the Soviet Union on intermediate range nuclear weapons. I remind the Prime Minister that the major remaining obstacle to this treaty is disagreement over verification procedures. Is it correct, as was reported in the Australian newspaper last Monday, that the Soviet Union is demanding surprise inspections of United States facilities or plants anywhere in the world which may be in some way associated with intermediate range nuclear forces and that it argues that these include the joint facilities in Australia? If that is correct, in those circumstances would the Australian Government allow the Soviet Union to inspect the joint facilities at either Nurrungar or Pine Gap?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the briefing that I received from the representative of the Secretary of State in Dubrovnik a couple of weeks ago, immediately following the discussions that had been conducted by Mr Shultz in Moscow, there was no indication in that very lengthy briefing that the question of the sort raised by the honourable gentleman would arise. I would imagine that, given the fact that the Secretary of State had gone to such trouble to ensure that we got a briefing as quickly as possible, if there had been any suggestion whatsoever from the discussions that had taken place between himself and the representatives of the Soviet Union, that would have been conveyed to us.

ANSWER.PARA: I can only conclude that, as is the case with so many other things that we read in the media these days, this hypothesis and speculation is totally removed from the realities of the discussion between the Soviet Union and the United States. I can only say that I hold the view that all members of the House will welcome the assiduous efforts that have been pursued by the United States and the Soviet Union in this matter. We look forward to the signing of this agreement between the representatives of the Soviet Union and the United States-that is, General Secretary Gorbachev and President Reagan-at the beginning of next month. As I say, I have no reason to believe that this quite hypothetical situation that has been raised by the honourable member for Mayo in fact reflects any realities involved in the discussions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade advise the House whether the French Government has released details of its new statute of autonomy for New Caledonia. Can he further advise the House of the Hawke Government's response?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The full details are not yet available, at least to me. However, the general thrust of what has been proposed in principle has been put down publicly on a number of occasions and variously-for instance, by Prime Minister Chirac and Dom-Tom Minister Pons on visits to New Caledonia. They seem to include expanded and modified decentralisation involving greater self-management within the institutions of the French republic; greater devolution of responsibility for internal affairs to regional and communal levels; new regional divisions; and the incorporation of characteristics of the traditional hierarchy into the new structure. What is clear, however, is that the proposed statute will not accord New Caledonia the same degree of autonomy as that enjoyed by French Polynesia. The powers accorded to the regions will not be as wide as those under the Fabius-Pisani Statute of the previous French Government.

ANSWER.PARA: It should not be concluded that the proposed statute is being greeted with universal applause in France. On the contrary, there is deep anxiety in many important areas of France about the potential implications of what is taking place in New Caledonia. Immediately after the announcement of the statute, President Mitterrand expressed great concern about aspects of it. Only last month he went on record in a major French national television interview to express more detailed criticism of the proposed statute. He said:
Distribution of land and wealth, which is so unequal and unjust . . .
He went on to give considerable detail, and then continued:

For as long as this continues, New Caledonia will remain in a colonial-type situation and what must not happen is that a statute of internal autonomy serves to set the situation in concrete, creating a sort of game preserve for those who have been the hunters for so long.
Continuing this intense criticism of what has been proposed by the Chirac Government of France, he added:

A statute that on the one hand leaves the New Caledonians in their present situation-a stand-off-that runs the risk of having dramatic consequences if the profound colonial-type inequality is perpetuated.

I stress the repetitious manner in which President Mitterrand has expressed his concern and invoked the colonial-type situation in New Caledonia. It is considered statements like that by leading statesman, public figures in France, that cause us some concern about the medium to longer term implications of this proposed statute.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: QANTAS AIRWAYS LTD: FLIGHTS TO SOUTH AFRICA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support. Is it true that Qantas Airways Ltd, which has one flight a week into and out of Harare, has decided to put on seven extra flights to Harare over the Christmas period? Will the Minister confirm that passengers destined for South Africa on these Qantas flights now connect with Air Zimbabwe or South African Airways to Johannesburg? Will the Minister also confirm that Qantas has conferred with South African Airways and requested South African Airways to put on extra flights from Harare to Johannesburg to coincide with Qantas's extra flights? If this is true, is it not somewhat hypocritical in view of the Government's frequent condemnation of the South African Government, or was the real purpose of banning South African Airways from Australia to increase Qantas's revenue from its Harare route?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not surprised that the honourable member for Parkes has asked that question, given the long history he has of support for the racist regime in South Africa. He has a long history of supporting that racist regime, as everyone knows. The situation is quite simple and I will explain it to the honourable member. It was anticipated when the Australian Government took the steps it did to stop South African Airways from continuing its services into Australia that South African interests both in South Africa and in this country-such as the honourable member-would bleat at great length about it. This is part of the continuing campaign. There is no doubt that interests who are sympathetic to South Africa will continue to be critical in a general sense and in a specific sense of Qantas's services to Harare following the termination of the agreement between Australia and South African interests.

ANSWER.PARA: Qantas is planning to operate seven additional services to Harare over the Christmas holiday period-four in December, two in January and one final additional service in February. I understand discussions have taken place between Qantas, Air Zimbabwe and South African Airways about the provision of additional services into and out of Harare. This is a normal commercial practice in which Qantas is perfectly entitled to indulge. So far as I am concerned, Qantas is well entitled to take the profits to be gained from that route over Christmas if it is able to do so.

Qantas has been operating into Harare since 1982. The passengers it picks up from Harare are not solely South African; they come from all over Africa. In the circumstances it is not un- usual to increase the number of services over the Christmas holiday season. That has been done in the past and it is being done again on this occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address a question to the Minister for Trade Negotiations. While commending him, the Prime Minister and other Ministers of the Government for their intense efforts to reduce trade barriers through multilateral negotiations, I ask: Is it a fact that no quick results can be expected with the Uruguay General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade round of talks likely to be measured in years, not months? Will the Minister give an assurance that, in the meantime, bilateral efforts will be pursued to increase Australian trade? For instance, can he do something about the Japanese non-tariff barriers? In particular, as brandy is made in former Prime Minister Nakasone's prefecture, and as he is no longer Prime Minister, can we expect under Prime Minister Takeshita to see some competitive, good South Australian brandy in Japan? As much as I would miss the Minister while he was undertaking more trips, would he do so to negotiate better bilateral trade negotiations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a matter which the honourable member has raised with me on a couple of occasions. It is true that Australia, in coalition with other medium and smaller trading nations, has placed a great deal of effort into getting results out of the new round of multilateral trade negotiations. As the honourable member quite rightly puts it, progress in multilateral trade negotiations is measured more in years than in months. Nevertheless, progress in the current round has been quite remarkable. The achievements to date are very encouraging. For countries such as Australia, it is imperative that we get fairness back into the international trading system. That has to be fairness for all countries, not just fairness for the major trading countries and not just what they consider to be fair for and between them. That was spelt out very articulately by the Prime Minister recently in Geneva.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the biggest threats we face at the moment is that the multilateral trading framework will fail unless fair rules for all are developed and adhered to. The real risk is that major players in world trade-and we should recognise that that does not include us-may develop special arrangements among themselves for access to products and may also divide up world markets with little regard for other trading countries such as Australia. While we have worked very hard on multilateral trade reform, we have also taken the opportunity to raise the types of issues which the honourable member for Adelaide is concerned about. We have taken every opportunity in bilateral discussions to ensure that our products have the best possible access to individual countries. For example, in the United States (US), as well as concentrating on that multilateral area, we concentrated on access to United States markets for sugar, lamb, wool, coal and steel. We also raised the specific matters which were being considered in the trade Bills which could affect our bilateral relations.

In Canada we also pressed, on a bilateral basis, exports in areas including lamb and horticulture. I note that in the debate earlier this week in this place on the Australian Horticultural Corporation Bill concern was expressed-and I can understand that concern-by the honourable member for Murray as to the possible effect on us if a Canada-US free trade agreement is finalised. The areas of concern to us include canned fruit, sugar and zinc. I can assure those honourable members of the House who are interested in this matter that all of those interests were dealt with bilaterally in both the United States and Canada. During my visit to North America I stressed the importance that we attached to continued fair access to the North American market on a bilateral basis. This, of course, especially applies in the case of Canada. We have arranged consultations next month, under the Canada-Australia trade agreement, with the Canadians, particularly in relation to the effects of the Canada-United States free trade agreement if it is ratified. Many of these issues were discussed at the recent European Community-Australian ministerial talks. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is currently on a visit to Japan. The exchange of investment missions with Japan is an important step in improving the bilateral economic links across all industry sectors. The same can be said for our increasingly broadly-based relationship with China.

In summary, while the efforts on the multilateral trade front have been substantial, as I indicated earlier, and have received considerable public attention, particularly because of the involvement of the Prime Minister in Geneva, I can assure you, Madam Speaker, and all honourable members of the House who have an interest in this matter-I hope most of them have-that this Government is continuing to press our bilateral interests with individual countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support. I remind the Minister that on 7 May this year the then Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation said, in response to a question, that there was no legitimate reason why the Coastwatch contract should not have been let to Amann Aviation Pty Ltd and that Amann `has a responsibility to carry out its obligations'. Is the Minister aware that on 21 May, two weeks or less after the then Minister's response, the then Minister's office expressed to the Department `the Minister's grave concern at Amann's ability to fulfil his contractual obligations'? Will the Minister concede that the then Minister grossly misled the House on 7 May? If not, will the Minister outline what occurred between 7 May and 21 May?
—I am not aware of those details but certainly I would be confident that the Minister did not mislead the House. I will obtain details of the matter for the honourable member.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOWARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, with your indulgence, I seek your guidance on a point of procedure. During Question Time the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in answer to a question from an honourable member from his side of the House, sought to draw, what he saw in an historical sense, an analogy between the former Prime Minister of this country and Joseph Stalin. I did not interject or seek to take a point of order because I guessed that the purpose of the question was directed at me, and I did not want to deny the Prime Minister the opportunity of having a go. However, now that Question Time has concluded I draw your attention, Madam Speaker, to the fact that on 31 March 1987 you reproved me for drawing an analogy between Joseph Goebbels and the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Joseph Goebbels, the House will recall, was the propaganda Minister. I drew the analogy because of the Treasurer's propensity to repeat a lie often enough in the hope that people will believe it. I was enjoined on that occasion to withdraw that reference which I did out of deference to you and out of deference to the sensitivities of honourable members opposite. I point out that there are many people on this side of the House, particularly given the splendid record of former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser in relation to Soviet Jews, who find quite offensive any analogy by this Prime Minister, joking or otherwise, between Malcolm Fraser and Joseph Stalin.

—No standing orders of this House relate to former members. I think the Leader of the Opposition would be well aware of that, as he has been a member of this place since 1974. Apart from standing order 157, which relates to condolence motions, no standing orders relate to former members. As I pointed out when the Prime Minister was speaking, I did not take his analogy to equate the Leader of the Opposition with Stalin. In regard to the point taken about the former Prime Minister, no standing orders cover former members.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KEATING
TALKER.ROLE: Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I also raise a matter of procedure. I notice that it has become the habit during Question Time for a member of the Opposition to take a point of order in the course of a reply by a Minister--
—Why shouldn't he? Are you trying to stop that?

—Just be quiet for a moment. Or they raise, under the guise of a personal explanation, a matter at the end of Question Time. It seems that this tactic is being employed so that the question and answer are not included in the rebroadcast of Question Time in the evening. Madam Speaker, I ask you to provide me with some advice as to what criteria are applied by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in the rebroadcasting of Question Time and whether it has become a deliberate abuse of procedures on the part of the Opposition to raise points of order for the express tactic of having the question and the answer deleted from the rebroadcast.

—Order! I point out to the House and to the Treasurer that under Standing Orders when a member of this House stands to take a point of order the Chair must hear and will hear the point of order. In regard to the point taken by the Treasurer about the rebroadcasting of Question Time, the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings sets down the standards for such broadcasts. The Serjeant-at-Arms monitors that situation daily. It is not in my hands to do that.

DEBATE.TITLE: NEW PARLIAMENT HOUSE: STATUE OF THE QUEEN

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a further point of procedure. I do not know whether this matter would be better raised during Question Time, Madam Speaker; but, as it is a matter for your administration, I ask you. If a decision is to be made with regard to a statue of Her Majesty the Queen of Australia in the new Parliament House and the siting of that statue in the new Parliament House building, will you ensure that that matter is brought to this Parliament before any decision is taken and that decision is not taken by a committee outside this place?
—This is not Question Time.

—Order! It may not be Question Time but, in response to the point raised by the Leader of the National Party, certainly notice of that matter coming before a committee meeting will be given, and I imagine that each of the party representatives on such committee will discuss that fact with the leaders or members of their parties.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KEATING
TALKER.ROLE: Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I refer again to the matter I raised with you earlier. Of course, I both accept and understand your point that the Chair has no option but to recognise an honourable member who stands to take a point of order. But if this procedure is being abused for the express purpose of having questions and answers deleted from the rebroadcast of Question Time, will you at least give me some advice as to what approach ought to be made to the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings to have the criteria for deleting questions and answers amended?
—Order! I point out to the Treasurer that I do not consider it is within the prerogative of the Chair to make such judgments.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-1986 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
Implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experimentations on human embryos.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ian Cameron,Mr Ian Robinson and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: Post Office Agencies
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that many post office agencies are to be closed. They provide a network of offices with postal and agency services to residential areas and small communities.

They serve a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced if forced to travel further to purchase postal items or collect parcels. It would be an unnecessary expense particularly for pensioners without their own transport. We maintain that the purpose of Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer. They are a community centre particularly in country areas and if necessary they should be subsidised to retain them.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that The House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of post office agencies and that the network should be extended, with the Agency services they offer expanded.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
