And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Treatment of Sun Damaged Skin and Warts
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned shows that the petitioners are concerned that the Minister for Health proposes to delete from the Medical Benefits Schedule those item numbers covering the treatment of sun-damaged skin and warts by specialists. They fear that those patients suffering chronically from these problems cannot always be treated successfully by a general practitioner. They protest that they will be financially disadvantaged. They also realise that their problems require early detection and expert treatment, if the petitioners are not to be exposed to increased risk of skin and other cancers.
Your Petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should recognise our concern and permit the abovementioned items in the medical schedule to be reinstated.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows-
We object to the proposal of Telecom to charge for each three minutes of a local call, as we feel this would disadvantage the elderly and people who are unable to leave their homes.
The telephone is often the only contact relatives can have to check on the safety and well-being of those they care for.

The inordinate time span which elapses between connection to a business premises and speaking, as the caller holds the line or is transferred between departments, would also disadvantage subscribers who can ill afford it.
Your petitioners therefore pray that Telecom abandons the proposal to time charge local telephone calls as we believe that the charges Telecom makes at the moment are quite adequate.

PETITION.TITLE: Opportunities for the Young
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:
We are concerned that-
(a) the proposed changes in legislation to Unemployment Benefit for young people adds to the already ill-conceived and over-bureaucratic welfare system and
(b) the abolition of CEP and the inadequacy of other training programs and
(c) cuts in funding for education, public housing and other welfare areas mean that young people's needs are being neglected by the Government.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Commonwealth Government immediately takes steps to:

(a) establish an anti-poverty level of income for all young people regardless of whether they are in training, retraining, education, employment or unemployment. The first step in achieving this is the full reinstatement of Unemployment Benefit for sixteen and seventeen year olds with automatic indexation linked to CPI increases.

(b) increase educational opportunities for all young people. The first step in achieving this would be to create 120 000 new places in higher and further education. This would make up for the 100 000 people turned away from TAFE courses and 20 000 people from universities and CAEs this year.
(c) establish a long term job creation program. The creation of 53 100 jobs for those young people who have been unemployed over 12 months is required immediately.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

This humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that they are totally opposed to any change in the present Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change in any way the Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia sheweth that whereas:
They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Give a speedy passage to the Flags Act Amendment Bill which provides that the Australian National Flag can only be changed by a referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Gymea Bay Post Office, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that the Post Office at Gymea Bay be closed. The Post Office serves a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced by having to travel to another centre for our postal requirements, or even to collect registered letters and parcels, cash Pension cheques and transact banking. Many of us are Pensioners and the cost of such travel would be an unnecessary imposition. The nearest Post Office is 2.3 kms away with no convenient transport.

We maintain that the purpose of the Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer, and that they should not be closed merely to save money or help Australia Post make a profit.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of Gymea Bay Post Office.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kurnell Peninsula
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker, and the members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sayeth.

Your petitioners humbly pray that your honourable house direct that the existing 4 (C4) zoning on the Kurnell Peninsula, in New South Wales, be removed and that this be replaced by a zoning more appropriate to the unique ecology of the area and to the historical significance of the Kurnell Peninsula, being the birthplace of the nation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Service Homes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:

That we consider the replacement of the $25,000 defence service homes loan with a grant of $10,000 to be a serious erosion of an established condition of service and the government has induced an unnecessary penalty on all serving and ex members of the Australian defence forces in order to help balance the September 87 Budget.

We believe that the reorganisation of this scheme will create a resignation rate that will accelerate the already depleting level of expertise in the ADF. We strongly oppose the government's actions on this matter but unlike the public sector unions we are unable to defend ourselves against this blatant disregard for our welfare.
Your petitioners therefore strongly urge the government to consider the following options.
1. Extend the termination date of the loan to June 88 to enable long serving members to avail themselves of this benefit.
2. Retain the scheme in full to allow eligible personnel who enlisted prior to May 85 to continue to apply for what we believe was a condition of service on enlistment.
3. Increase the amount of loan to encourage retention of personnel.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the government to consider the options before a final decision is made.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear-Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows-

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we consider the 2% discounting of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme pension adjustments on 10 October 1986 to be a serious breach of trust by the Government.
This cut has reduced the base for future adjustments. The Government has promised to restore the base as soon as economic circumstances permit.

Having regard to the state of the economy as portrayed by members of the Government in recent months and the interaction between Social Security pensions and the above mentioned adjustment, your Petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should urge the Government to restore the pension base for the calculation of future adjustments and that the restoration be effected in conjunction with the Social Security adjustments in November 1987.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:

That we consider the 2% discounting of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme pension adjustments on the 10 October 1986 to be a serious breach of trust by the Government. The Commonwealth has reneged on an established commitment as incorporated in Commonwealth legislation and benefit promise pensions are not being paid in full. In particular we resent the long-term effect of the discounting. The pension loss is compounded throughout the life of a pensioner and surviving dependants-into the 21st century for many. We consider this Government-induced penalty to be out of all proportion to the short-term ``extraordinary circumstances of the economy'' given as the reason for the discounting.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the parliament assembled, should urge the Government to:

1. limit the pension discounting effect of the Superannuation and other Benefits Legislation Amendment Act 1986 to the period 10th October 1986 to 1st July 1987 so that pensions are restored to the 9th October 1986 level as a base for the 1987 pension adjustment; and
2. consult with organisations representing pensioners before changing the terms and conditions of the Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, your petitioners, humbly pray, that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to legislate for the Australia Card Bill, and your petitioners, in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Closure of Macksville Army Reserve, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that:

The decision by the Department of Defence to close down the Macksville Sub-Section of 41 Battalion, Australian Army Reserve, is of grave concern to the unit members and citizens of the surrounding districts. The decision to direct unit members to Coffs Harbour, some 60km distant, would impose sufficient hardship to prevent many continuing in the reserve and be a major deterrent to potential members.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled urge the Parliament to:
Intervene to stop the proposed closure and sale of land at Wallace Street, Macksville, and initiate action to have a permanent Depot built on the Army's Macksville land.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The Government by persisting with the Australia Card Bill has wilfully rejected the advice and recommendations of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia's ``Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card'' which unequivocally rejected the Government's proposal in these words:

``The majority believes the creation of a new bureaucracy of 2000 public servants within the HIC (Health Insurance Commission), with the sole task of identifying every man, woman and child in Australia, is a wasteful exercise which will not address the problems of tax evasion and social security fraud but will provide the mechanism by which the very fabric of our society will be irreversibly altered, opening the way for the greatest attack on the privacy of individuals as the `Identity Bureau' identifies, monitors, and updates information on every person in Australia.'' (Report, 4.55, page 148)

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government now withdraw the Bill as being contrary to the Common Law and traditional freedoms we have hitherto enjoyed in Australia, and should the Bill be nevertheless re-introduced, that the Members of the House without regard for party should unanimously reject the Australia Card Bill as being contrary to our personal liberties and the national interest.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Veterans' Affairs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Any proposals to abolish the Department of Veterans' Affairs gravely concern ex-servicemen, ex-servicewomen and their families, because they renege on clear and unequivocal commitments from various Commonwealth Governments to properly care for Australia's Veterans.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Parliament to:
Ensure that the Department of Veterans' Affairs continues to exist as a separate and distinct Department of State servicing the needs of Veterans and their families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned, call on the Federal Government to give notice to terminate the lease of the US base at Pine Gap before October 1986.
We believe that in the interests of world peace and the Australian people, this lease should be terminated and the base closed because Pine Gap is a spy base and a war base:

Since it was opened in 1969, it has eavesdropped on Australian telephone and telex communications. Information obtained in this way was used by the CIA to destabilise the Whitlam Government in late 1975.

It provides communication facilities for CIA activity in countries throughout the world, much of which is connected with overthrowing other country's governments. Last year it became clear Pine Gap was spying on Greece.
The electronic and photographic information its satellites receive is used to select nuclear targets in the territory of the Soviet Union and its allies.
Many US military activities short of nuclear war are also co-ordinated by Pine Gap. These include the war against Vietnam and the invasion of Lebanon by US marines in 1984.
Pine Gap spends only a tiny percentage of its time monitoring arms control agreements, and even then the data gathered is so top-secret Australia has no access to it.
Pine Gap's role will be expanded under Reagan's Star Wars scheme to extend the arms race to outer space, threatening the existence of our planet.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Pornography: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned, being appalled that the Government has set no penalty for importing unclassified child pornography, do ask that Parliament urgently legislate to:
Make the importation of child pornography, and the possession of child pornography, and all tapes and goods banned by Customs, to be a criminal offence, with deterrent penalties, and

Close the Customs barriers to pornography in the A.C.T., in respect of X-rated videos, (and ER) and end the shameful Canberra trade, and the Mafia connections. Because 98% of Australians in other States have banned X-rated videos.
Because the trade is still flourishing, and it's availability escalates sexual crime.
Because importers of child pornography face only a fine for lying.
Because child pornography pedlars are safe if they cross a border, and cannot be extradited for a summary offence.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Spectacle and Snapper Islands, Sydney Harbour
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth:

1. Naval and defence equipment including ammunition stored on and in the waters around Spectacle and Snapper Islands in Sydney Harbour are a potential danger to residents of and property on the foreshores of Drummoyne and Hunters Hill and also to pleasure and commercial craft that use the waterways near the islands.
2. All naval and defence equipment and ammunitions should be removed from on, and in the waters around, Spectacle and Snapper Islands.
3. In celebration of Australia's Bicentenary, Spectacle Island and the naval museum housed thereon should be opened to the general public of Australia.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Prescription Drugs for Pensioners
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
1. We the undersigned are totally opposed to the introduction of a $2.00 fee on prescription drugs for pensioners;
2. The impact of such a fee will be particularly felt by the chronically ill elderly who will be faced with a $2.00 burden with the purchase of each Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme drug;
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Ensure that prescription drugs continue to be provided to the pensioner population without the $2.00 fee on each prescription.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Industrial Relations Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government's Industrial Relations Bill will increase industrial disputation, bankrupt companies, and give the union movement total and absolute power over the Australian community.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject Labor's Industrial Relations Bill to save Australia from the actions of militant unions and give our economy a chance of recovering.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth:
1. We reject in principle the need for a national I.D. card on the basis that it will be a gross violation of individual liberty.
2. We reject the notion that the government can claim a mandate for the proposed legislation and state categorically it does not reflect our will.
3. We believe that, as with the proposed Bill of Rights legislation, the government's methods and arguments in promoting this legislation have been under-handed and undemocratic.

4. We believe as a matter of faith and judgment that the proposed legislation will result in further attacks on individual freedom and responsibility, the family and the Church and that the real intent is the promotion of a powerful secular humanist ``big brother'' government.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, together with the Senate, take action to reject this proposed legislation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Destruction of Parkland and Recreational Areas, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in the Parliament.
This petition of certain residents of the Australian Capital Territory shows the attention of the House:
To the erosion of City Hill for car park construction.
Your petitioners therefore request that further destruction of parkland and recreational areas within the city cease.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—I refer to an article in the Australian Financial Review of Tuesday, 3 November headed `Some home-grown truths on black, white and sepia' which refers to the phrase `non-Aboriginal people', terminology which I used. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: One assumes, however, Miles is not overly concerned that the Aboriginal Affairs opinion meisters will overlook the country's Vietnamese citizenry on their interrogatory rounds.
No, we're talkin' 'bout white folks here.
I was talking about all other non-Aboriginal Australian people, not just white folks.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The culpable negligence of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer in allowing the Australian economy to become so vulnerable to external economic shock.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOWARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has frequently said that one of the besetting criticisms of this Government is its supreme arrogance and complacency. No better is that epitomised than by the behaviour of both the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Today we had Nero's brother returning to grab hold of the fiddle. The Prime Minister came back and sat with the Treasurer and the two of them represented the pinnacle of smugness, complacency and arrogance about the Australian political scene. But every so often, when one is arrogant, one trips oneself up. This has happened with the present Treasurer. Let me take honourable members back a mere six weeks to 18 September 1987. The Treasurer, when he was on the Midday Show, had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: This is the great coming of age of Australia. This is the golden age of economic change.
When asked `How much credit do you take?', the Treasurer stated:
Oh, a very large part.

I want to say that, for once, I agree with the Treasurer: he can take a very large part of the credit for the mess that Australia is in at present. He will have played out in front of him, week after week and month after month, the stark economic and political reality that the policies he has followed over the last 4 1/2 years have left this country more vulnerable and more exposed than it otherwise should have been. I am not surprised that the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy) is in here to deal with today's matter of public importance after the mess that the Treasurer made yesterday of the difference between the money supply and capital outflow. We have had Banana Republic Paul and the other things that we could call the Treasurer on occasions, but yesterday we had Professor Paul. We had a lecture from the Treasurer.

After 4 1/2 years as Treasurer, with all the vast resources of the Treasury and the Reserve Bank of Australia at his disposal, he still does not understand the way in which a floating exchange rate operates. He came into this House yesterday and purported to give a lecture to me and Senator Stone, the former head of the Treasury, about the way in which capital outflow affects the level of the Australian dollar. He said that Senator Stone and I were the dinosaurs of the economic debate in Australia. All I can say, after listening to his answer yesterday, is that if we are the dinosaurs on the subject he is the amoeba of the economic debate in Australia. He demonstrated a total and chronic misunderstanding of a very simple fact-that the dollar goes down if there are more sellers of the Australian dollar than there are buyers. That is normally associated with a capital outflow. What the Treasurer did not understand was that everything he said yesterday related to the effect of fluctuations in the Australian currency on the money supply.

Our complaint about the Government's handling of the economy is not that we blame it for the fall in world stock markets. No rational opponent of this or any other government would dare or presume to do that. But what we do blame the Government for is that it has left this country more exposed than it should have. We blame it for the fact that this country now owes the rest of the world 42 per cent of her gross domestic product (GDP). Yet, in June 1983, just after this Government came to power, the figure was only 21 per cent of GDP. Before this Treasurer goes around the world lecturing President Reagan, Margaret Thatcher or anybody else about economic policy, he ought to put his own house in order. He ought to realise how exposed he is. I notice now that not even one Government frontbencher is in the House. That is a measure of the Government's supreme contempt. I see that the Minister for Trade Negotiations has returned.

Our complaint is twofold. The Government has left this country exposed; our situation is deteriorating; and we are suffering more severely, as a result of the changed economic circumstances, than just about any other Western country. I say to the Prime Minister, Senator Walsh and the Treasurer that we will go on pointing that out. The Prime Minister has a great double standard. He wants a one-way bet as an opposition. If everything is going swimmingly, we have to stand up and applaud the Prime Minister, but if everything is going badly we have to keep quiet because to criticise him is to be un-Australian and unpatriotic. That has been so time and time again, on all sorts of issues.

I have an even greater criticism of the Prime Minister and the Government. I see that the Treasurer has entered the chamber. The amoeba has returned! Not only has this Government left this country more exposed to the economic turmoil the world is now experiencing but on top of that it is now showing all the signs of sitting on its hands in the hope that it will not have to take any action because it might damage the electoral prospects of its right wing mate in New South Wales, Barrie Unsworth.

There are a lot of people who want to know how is it that a Treasurer who says he is in favour of fiscal rectitude can pronounce benediction on a State Budget that increases expenditure by 3.3 per cent in real terms. How can he look approvingly on the New South Wales Budget which was given the lemon of the year award by the Institute of Public Affairs? How can he look with equanimity on a State government that is responsible for 40 per cent of the economy of this nation bringing a Budget down which is inimical to the national and State economic interest of Australia and New South Wales at present? One is left with the suspicion that this Government is now going to compound its neglect, its delay, its benign-even malicious-neglect of the last 4 1/2 years by sitting on its hands to try to save Barrie Unsworth's hide. That is what the Government is now facing the judgment of people on.

If the situation is as bad as the Treasurer claims, if we are all for fiscal rectitude, why have the Treasurer and Prime Minister said that the New South Wales Budget is appropriate for the circumstances? What circumstances-the re-election of Barrie Unsworth or the national economic interest of Australia? What is the Treasurer's responsibility? He is no longer the Sussex Street king; he is now the Treasurer of this country and he has to apply the requirements and the standards of that office to the responsibilities with which he is now faced. After hearing that incredibly inept lecture about the exchange rate yesterday all I can say is that prior to that lecture I was worried about the economic stewardship of this country but after hearing that lecture I am plain scared, because anybody who after 4 1/2 years as Treasurer does not understand the difference between the money supply and capital outflow is more inept in the job than even his fiercest critics on this side of the House would allege.

The criticism that this Opposition has bears repetition because it is the crucial point of the economic debate: although the whole of the world is suffering from the fall in international stock markets and although I would be the last person in this Parliament to blame the Prime Minister and the Treasurer for that fall having commenced, we are doing worse than we should be. We are doing worse than most other countries because the Government's policies for the last 4 1/2 years have not been the right policies. That is the simple fact of economic life. There comes a time for any government when it runs out of external excuses. It cannot blame all of its problems on its predecessors and the rest of the world but when conditions get a bit better say that it is all due to its brilliance, and when conditions become worse again go back to blaming its predecessors and the rest of the world. Yet that is the cop-out, that is the one way bet that the Treasurer wants at present.

The Australian people are not that gullible. They remember the rhetoric. They know that this Government has now been in office for 4 1/2 years. They know that from the beginning of 1985 until it was dragged screaming to action in the middle of 1986 it sat and watched our external position burn in front of its eyes. It did absolutely nothing about it. The Australian public knows that we are running an inflation rate which is more than double that of our trading partners. The Australian public knows that the Government can blame the rest of the world for a certain time but in the end it has to take some of the responsibility itself. The Treasurer has to explain to the Australian people why it is that our stock market has been discounted by 44 per cent; why it is that our dollar is now valued at 91 or 92 yen and yet at 99 yen a tightening of fiscal policy was necessary.

The Treasurer pretends to this Parliament that one can continue to see the value of our currency fall, and that that is a costless thing. No currency devaluation is costless. Every time our currency falls, our overseas obligations go up. I remind him, by way of comparison, that in 1981 the overseas debt of the Argentine was 29 per cent of her gross domestic product and it is now 67 per cent. In 1983 our level was 21 per cent and it is now 42 per cent. That is all his own work. He cannot blame anybody else for that, because he presided over the policy. This is the golden economic age that the Treasurer talks about.

One can look at all the indices-our overseas debt, our inflation rate, our interest rates, our unemployment level which is locked at 7 1/2 per cent to 8 per cent, our level of bankruptcies, and our current account deficit which was the worst in the industrialised world in 1986 and which will be the second worst in the current year. Yet this same man travels around the world, lecturing the Reagan Administration. He goes to the United Kingdom and says, `You have to get your house in order'. Britain is only the second largest creditor nation in the world, after Japan, but she must get her house in order. They are not up to the Keating mark. The United States has an external debt of 13 per cent of GDP, but it must get its house in order. Its current account deficit is about half of what ours is, but it must get its house in order. Presumably, it will not be long before he tells the Japanese and the Germans that they have to get their houses in order.

I agree that Budget action by the United States Administration is required. Nobody could seriously argue against that. But the Treasurer, the Prime Minister and this Government have engaged in the ultimate cop-out of saying that all of our problems are the fault of the rest of the world. The Treasurer has a lousy economic record, and he will leave this nation a debt-ridden legacy when he ceases to be Treasurer-a debt-ridden legacy that will dog the children and grandchildren of this and future generations. It is an insult to the intelligence of the Australian public for him, day after day in this Parliament, to blame the rest of the world and wash his hands of any responsibility for the economic stewardship of this country.

The Australian public is entitled to hold both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer accountable for their supreme complacency and their indifference to the effect of their neglect and delay between the beginning of 1985 and 1986. The Australian public is entitled to say to the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, `You have now been in power for 4 1/2 years and we are going to hold you accountable for what you have done and for what you have neglected to do, which has left our economy in a supremely vulnerable and exposed situation, and will further reduce our standard of living as a result of the changes that are now occurring'. They are the two guilty men of the last 4 1/2 years and the Australian people realise it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KEATING
TALKER.ROLE: Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard some lacklustre performances in recent times but that really takes the cake. It establishes that the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) is all ambition, but he has no structure, no thought, no thought process and no framework. It is all about a manic determination to be Prime Minister and nothing else. Never was this revealed so clearly than in the last election campaign. The great myth about J. W. Howard is that he has a thought-through position. The great myth that he sold the Press Gallery and anyone else who would listen was that he was the man with the serious agenda, he was the man with the structure and he was the man with the framework. To him would fall the proper mantle of leadership from his predecessor who, he said, lacked these things and he-the man with the structure-would lay down the framework for Australia's economic salvation. He had the conservative but rational alternative to Labor. He had the framework. The fact of the matter is we now know he had no framework. We know he now has only one reservoir left to draw upon-that is, his own rampant ambition to be Prime Minister of this country without the slightest understanding of the reason why.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the fact that the honourable member for Bennelong had been Leader of the Opposition for almost two years before the election, and that when he went to the Press Gallery before September 1985 and laid down his serious agenda and a serious framework, what did we see in the election campaign? Nothing except opportunist waffle and the jettisoning of all decent tenets of economic policy. It was a manic run to the wire with an unfunded tax cut-the oldest trick in the political book. Now we have a noisy, cheap throwaway matter of public importance, a noisy, cheap speech from a politician who is not interested in developing a framework for economic policy or a framework for government. He is interested in nothing; he just makes cheap attacks on the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and puts forward no thoughtful alternative, no serious response to Australia's condition, and no serious conservative framework for addressing it.

It is no wonder that Malcolm Fraser was stung by this charge that he was some great ogre sitting against all change while this earnest tearabout was trying to put all these great changes on to the statute book. What do we find in the writing of history from someone who has had all the documents available? We find no great thrust for deregulation, no great thrust for market orientation. Fraser's point is a strong one. He says we should look at what was put up and look at what was accepted by Cabinet. Not much was put up but what was put up was accepted by Cabinet. Where was the generator of this change, this great burning crucible of change? He was in a little meltdown on the lower ground floor where he had been for the previous few years, not knowing where to go but making predictions on the state of the economy every day, like a radio commentator. He was no force for change. When I inherited this job and went to the Treasury, there were no burning embers of deregulation left there. I had to ask Mr Martin from the Commercial Banking Co. of Sydney Ltd whether he would please chair a body to freshen up the recommendations of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System as they were so dead and there was so little support for them from within the bureaucracy. There were no expectations.

This is the record of change of the former Treasurer. Of course he is stung by the remark about the golden age of change. But it is. The total orientation of the country has been changed from an inward, protected place-a country looking at itself, protected by tariffs, managed exchange rates and closed financial markets-to one that now looks outwards, looks at the world as its market and places its currency and its financial markets on the world market. Of course it is a period of great change, and it gives Australia its only hope to be competitive and make its way in the world. Of course the Leader of the Opposition is stung by it. He keeps coming back to that point. He hates it, because he thinks he squandered his opportunity-which he did. He now wants history to treat him more kindly than he is entitled to be treated. He wants to be able to say he was really a force for change but Fraser would not let him. The truth is he had no guts and he would not push. He had no ideas, no heart, no belief and no passion. He got nothing through because in the end there is not much to him.

That is what comes through in all these debates-there is not much to him. He is now using hollow words. I have been here 18 years and I have heard a thousand of those speeches-a thousand useless, empty bits of rhetoric about what the Government should do. He had the sheer hide to raise this proposition concerning the culpable negligence of the Prime Minister in allowing the Australian economy to become so vulnerable to external shock. Who bet everything on commodities? Who left this country totally vulnerable to commodity prices? Malcolm Fraser and John Howard did. They said that coal would save us.

The capital stock started running down in the middle 1960s. It was in a state of deterioration but nothing was done to repair it. There was no sensible policy on wages. The attitude was, `Attack the unions. Put out a Press release; a cheap throwaway in the Press boxes-that will handle it'. When the big test came, in 1982, on the metal trades case, when the monetary aggregates were running all over the place, haemorrhaging and financing this, the former Prime Minister was prepared to jettison the discussion to clear off to Prince Charles's wedding. The then Treasurer, who was left holding the bag, dropped it very quickly. That wage response went into place. Our inflation rate went up and our economic sovereignty was blown to pieces.

That is the record of the former Government on shocks to the external economy. We had a managed exchange rate. One would think that the penny would have dropped. When the wealth of the Arab states increased dramatically when oil went up in price, and our oil and oil substitutes went up in price, why did we not get wealthy? If we were laden with oil substitutes, why did we not become wealthy? One of the reasons was that our exchange rate was manipulated and overvalued and that is one reason why our agricultural producers suffered in this period and were robbed of the decent incomes they were entitled to get for their produce. It is one of the reasons why the country was never allowed to adjust.

I stung the honourable member for Bennelong yesterday by calling him a dinosaur-which he has come back to today. He is a dinosaur, along with Senator Stone. I remember the debate in the early days of my period as Treasurer. We would find out what the banks had bought in their foreign exchange dealings each day. When the price is a set price the central bank takes all that comes. It buys all the foreign currency at the price. Then it sterilises that with bond sales. This is the framework those opposite are in-a fixed rate of capital income and capital outflow. They see transactions with traders buying and selling the Australian dollar to settle their accounts around the world as evidence of some sort of capital flight. The immaturity of it is rooted in the practice of the 1970s; that is, a fixed exchange rate. Those people have never moved out of that model.

Senator Stone in the 1970s told us for a long time that we needed more imports. Remember his famous speech that what Australia needed was more imports? Those imports were just decimating our secondary structure, tearing it to pieces. This is their thinking. Now the gang of three is back. It was not content to destroy the place in 1982. Only members of the coalition could get together and propose, as a management group again, the mob that wrecked us last time round-Mr Howard, Mr Stone and Professor Hewson. That is the gang of three, the 1981-82 squad. They are back. They are now meeting in some room to see whether they can do it all again.

Those opposite really have to make a great effort as a party to say, `We got kicked out in 1983 because we made a total mess of it. Can we possibly make certain that everyone understands that we will do it again by getting the same three people involved again?'. We know about Senator Stones's description of Professor Hewson as a meretricious player, his contempt for the honourable member for Bennelong, and the contempt of the honourable member for Bennelong for Senator Stone. They are all back together, all back in place, ready to kick the place apart again. The fact is that they will not get the chance. They may feel good saying, `You will not be the Treasurer or the Government for long'. We will be here for a long time-those opposite had better believe it-because the people will not take them. Why would the people take them? What proposition do they have?

Yesterday I talked about the supply-side focus of the policies of those opposite and what that has done to ruin the rest of the world in terms of the imbalance of the United States fiscal position, which everybody has agreed is now underpinning a lot of the uncertainty in the markets. The honourable member for Bennelong made a personal explanation-the usual performance after Question Time. He said, `No, there was only $1 billion, in my calculation, in the election campaign put down to supply-side effects'. Therefore, that is all right; he is not a supply-sider. Apparently, all the rhetoric, all the language about incentivation, about cutting taxes to lift incentive, to get everyone out there producing because the 38 per cent tax rate has been dangled in front of their noses is to be forgotten. The Opposition says, `How dare the Government say that we are interested in supply-side economics'. It is not only that one-seventh of the proceeds to the Commonwealth of such a tax cut were attributed to the supply-side, but also that a large part of the other six-sevenths was illusory. That is why I say with utter conviction that the Opposition's tax cut proposition at the election campaign would have had the effect of haemorrhaging our fiscal policy seriously, dramatically and catastrophically.

Given what has happened, one can just imagine the financial market response to a country like this doing that sort of thing-paying ourselves more through a tax cut at a time when the world sliced $10 billion off our commodities. This is the truth of the Opposition's position. There is no policy. The Opposition talked about our malicious neglect; that was the expression used. Was the dramatic overhaul of our fiscal position from 4 1/2 per cent of gross domestic product to zero malicious neglect? Was the floating of the exchange rate to restore our competitiveness a malicious neglect? Was the 10 per cent reduction in real unit labour costs in four years malicious neglect? Was the deregulation of our financial markets malicious neglect? Was the restoration of parts of our industrial base under the Government's industry plans malicious neglect? This is the sort of cheap claptrap, cheap argument, that is thrown around by the Opposition without its addressing a serious framework and saying, `This is what we would do in the circumstances'. We hear none of that.

The Leader of the Opposition says, `Our policies at the election were right'. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), as the shadow Treasurer, attempted to say that the policies were wrong. He was hauled back very rapidly by the Leader of the Opposition who said, `Listen, our policies were right'. If the election policies are right, the Opposition has no bases for any attack upon the Government at all, it having campaigned on the most incredible and disreputable policy. If, however, the view that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition would like to be associated with prevails, it means that from that day hence the Leader of the Opposition's position is in tatters and the only course left for him is resignation. That is the position, and that is the position the Opposition is caught on. It does not have a policy. It has not had a policy for years.

I ask the House to remember the political assassination of the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) at the hands of the Leader of the Opposition on the basis that he had the serious agenda, that he was the burning heart of change, that he was the one who would map out the future. It did not happen. There is no agenda for change. There is not going to be an agenda for change. The only changes taking place come from over here. That is why we got support at the last election. The Government will keep up the changes. As I have said, the Government will make the appropriate policy responses as it sees fit but it is not going to be pushed and shoved into panicky measures by an Opposition that does not understand where it has been or where it is going.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HAWKE
TALKER.ROLE: Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In the period 9 to 26 October, I visited the United States of America, Canada, Ireland, Switzerland and Yugoslavia. In making this report to the Parliament on my visits, I will focus most closely on four themes. First, a central element of my activities abroad was the continued advocacy, in a number of important forums, of the cause which stands as essential to Australia's long term prosperity; that is, trade liberalisation. Second, at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting (CHOGM) in Vancouver, I pursued a number of issues of importance to Australia including, most particularly, the situation in Fiji and Southern Africa. Third, my visits to Ireland and Yugoslavia allowed me to cement even more firmly the close and productive ties of kinship that link Australia and those countries. Finally, I engaged in constructive talks with the United States Secretary of State, George Shultz, relating to Australia's vital alliance with the United States.

SPEECH.PARA: TRADE LIBERALISATION

There should be no dispute with the statement that the interests of both Australia and the world would be best served by the freeing up of the international trading system. Yet the political will needed internationally to translate that logically unassailable truth into effective reform of the trading system, and to defy the rising tide of protectionism, still needs bolstering-and, of most immediate impact for Australia, there needs to be the political will to phase down and ultimately eliminate the high and growing levels of agricultural subsidies.

Accordingly, I took every opportunity during my trip to argue the merits of trade liberalisation, to marshal support for that goal, to demonstrate Australia's active commitment to it, and to help show the way forward towards it. In particular, I addressed the issue of trade liberalisation in public speeches in San Diego and Geneva, and at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. It was also an important element of my bilateral discussions, to which I will return later.
San Diego

The chief purpose of my visit to San Diego was to deliver a speech to the Australian-American Chamber of Commerce on bilateral and multilateral trading issues, and their impact on the close relationship between Australia and the United States.

San Diego was an especially appropriate venue for my address, for two reasons. First, because San Diego is on the Pacific Rim, it is part of the fastest growing and most dynamic region in the world. The fortunes of the countries of the Pacific Rim, including Australia and the United States, will depend crucially upon the success of the new round of multilateral trade negotiations and upon the ability of the major economies to remedy their structural imbalances through the right macroeconomic and industry restructuring policies.

Second, San Diego is the home base of the United States Pacific Surface Fleet and the site of significant defence-related manufacturing. Australia is the second largest cash purchaser of American defence equipment-a fact which contributes significantly to the favourable United States balance in trade with us.

The theme of my San Diego speech was that world economic tensions, reflected in massive external imbalances, could be resolved satisfactorily only if the major economies implemented appropriate domestic policies coupled with open trading policies. I noted that there is some evidence that domestic policies and the external imbalances had begun to adjust appropriately in certain countries but that much more needed to be done. Subsequent events in the financial markets have dramatically underscored the latter point.

I noted with particular concern, however, that in some quarters in America, protectionist pressures had been intensifying. Australia has a first class alliance with the United States, which we value, and we are a nation of significant strategic value to the United States. Our alliance is firm and secure, yet Australians may be the victims of the mounting protectionist pressure within the United States Congress. We are also concerned at the possibility that the United States may seek to resolve its trade imbalance with Japan at Australia's expense through non-commercial deals. In short, I told my American audience that Australians would not tolerate being regarded by the United States as first-class allies but second-class friends. I noted that the Administration had shown great determination in resisting those pressures to date and called upon it to maintain that resistance in protecting Australia's legitimate trading interests and with it, the strength of the Australian-American relationship.
Vancouver

The Commonwealth, as an association of nations ranging in size and wealth from the populous and the economically powerful to the debt prone and the minuscule, speaks with a unique and powerful voice on world economic issues. It was my honour to lead the CHOGM discussion on the world economy. After outlining major developments on the world economic scene since the Nassau meeting of CHOGM I identified the main challenges for the future. In examining global economic prospects I repeated my message of San Diego that the enhancement of world growth depended upon the commitment of governments to steady rectification of fundamental domestic and external imbalances, coupled with an open trading system. Owing to their size and influence, the major economies had a special obligation to rectify their structural imbalances and I called on the Commonwealth to use all its influence to encourage those major countries to accelerate the processes of adjustment and to maximise low inflation world growth.

In turning to the particulars of international trading problems I acknowledged one important step forward that had been taken since Nassau-the launching of the Uruguay round of multilateral trade negotiations. Nevertheless, protectionist pressures are still grave, especially because of the trans-Atlantic agricultural subsidies war and the increasing strength of calls for bilateral solutions to trade deficits. I suggested that the Commonwealth could make a valuable contribution by supporting the momentum for trade reform. Consequently, I supported Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's idea of a Declaration on World Trade by Commonwealth Heads of Government. I proposed that the Heads of Government declare that we remain gravely concerned by and firmly opposed to protectionist measures; that we stand for trade liberalisation; that we support a strong, credible and working General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT); and that we agree on the crucial need for reform of all distorting and indefensible agricultural policies. Such a declaration was drafted and was adopted by the Commonwealth leaders. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a copy of the Vancouver Declaration on World Trade.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
THE VANCOUVER DECLARATION ON WORLD TRADE

The Commonwealth leaders representing a wide range of both developed and developing countries note with grave concern rising global protectionist pressures. Continuing implementation of protectionist measures would be counter-productive, would increase the risk of further exchange rate instability and would exacerbate the problems of development and indebtedness. Trade restrictions affect particularly the exports and growth prospects of developing countries and their ability to service debt all of which in turn impact adversely on the economies of the industrial countries.

We welcome the progress of negotiations in the Uruguay round covering a range of important subjects. We will work for a balanced outcome to develop a more open, viable and durable multilateral trading system to promote growth and development. We recognise the growing importance and the asymmetrical position of developing countries in the trading system. This underlines the need to give special consideration to their interests within the agreed framework of the Uruguay Round. It is essential that the Punta dal Este commitments on ``standstill'' and ``rollback'' be fully respected and implemented.

We agree on the crucial need for reform of all trade distorting agricultural policies, both domestic and international. We urge early action on agriculture in the Uruguay Round so as to reduce the uncertainty, imbalances and instability in world markets. This will benefit both developed and developing countries.

A strong, credible working GATT is essential to the well-being of all trading countries and is the best bulwark against mounting protectionist pressures. The function of the GATT should be improved through enhancing its role in maintaining an open multilateral system and its capacity in the area of dispute settlement. We hope that the negotiations will make sufficient progress on agriculture and other key subjects to enable a mid-term ministerial review of the Uruguay Round as allowed for in the Punta del Este Declaration.

We welcome the assistance which the Commonwealth Secretariat is providing to member governments in the trade field, including the re-establishment of a Trade Adviser's Office in Geneva and increased levels of technical support, and we request the Secretary-General to continue to give priority to work in this field. In addition, the larger states of the Commonwealth undertake to assist developing countries, including smaller states, through regular consultations and trade policy training programmes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. It is entirely consistent with the thrust of the Government's policies on international trade and will serve as a useful reference point to reinforce the pressure we will be seeking to maintain on this vital issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Geneva

My visit to Geneva was primarily for the purpose of addressing representatives of the contracting parties to the GATT. That address allowed me to do two important things. First, I announced that Australia was prepared to negotiate a broad package of measures to reduce overall levels of effective assistance to Australian industry-including tariffs-as part of a broad-based multilateral approach. I said that in this context Australia was prepared to eliminate, over an appropriate implementation phase, all quantitative import measures designed to protect domestic industry. This means we would phase out all our quantitative restrictions, including tariff quotas, licensing and embargoes. I stressed that we would be looking to our trading partners to reciprocate this offer by making similar reductions in their effective rates of industry assistance-not only tariffs but also the range of non-tariff measures and subsidies.

Second, I had the honour on behalf of the Cairns Group of Fair Trading Nations to present the Group's proposals for agricultural trade reform. Honourable members will recall that the Cairns Group was established following a meeting, held in Cairns in August 1986 under the chairmanship of the then Trade Minister, John Dawkins, of representatives of 14 fair trading nations. Cairns Group members were frustrated by the slow process towards freer trade being made by the major economies-in particular the United States, the European Community and Japan. Since that meeting the Cairns Group has established its credentials as the vital third force in agricultural trade negotiations.

The Cairns Group's proposal which I launched contains three elements: a long term objective of the elimination of subsidies and market barriers, within 10 years at most; a framework for the rules and parameters necessary during the phase down period and a set of priorities for change; and immediate relief from the worst subsidies and market distortions, in recognition of the crisis facing world agricultural trade. Unlike the proposals of the United States and the European Community, the Cairns Group proposal focuses in detail on the reform period and the mechanisms required to achieve a free and open agricultural trading system. It gives priority to phasing out those measures that most disrupt trade and provides for the greatest distorters to make the greatest contribution to reform.

In my address I also noted the importance Australia attaches to developing rules and procedures to encourage freer trade in services. This is an area long neglected by GATT which needs to be addressed in the Uruguay round. My address was the first in the GATT's 40 year history made by a head of government, and I trust it will have augmented the prestige and influence of that organisation. I believe the speech was well received and gave Australia, and the Cairns Group, new prominence in GATT at a crucial stage of the negotiations about the future of world trade.
COMMONWEALTH HEADS OF GOVERNMENT MEETING

The Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Vancouver from 13 to 17 October addressed a very wide range of issues and also provided a valuable opportunity for bilateral discussions with many of the other 44 countries represented. In describing the outcome I shall not attempt to be comprehensive; I draw the attention of honourable members to the communique of the meeting.

CHOGM provided the first opportunity for the Commonwealth to consider the tragic events which have taken place in Fiji this year. It permitted those countries which, like Australia, are members of the South Pacific Forum, to carry forward the consultations held in Apia in May. Our discussions were frank and intensive. Without in any way detracting from the admirable commitment and steadfastness of the Governor-General through the crisis, it was clear by the time CHOGM convened that Ratu Sir Penaia Ganilau no longer exercised authority in any other than a purely formal sense. Therefore, we recognised the need to address the situation in Fiji as it was, rather than on the basis of wishful thinking or a fiction about who exercised real authority in that troubled country.

This was clear to me from the outset of the gathering in Vancouver and was accepted by virtually everyone to whom I spoke. Some who were either unable, or refused, to grasp this fact, and in consequence made a number of quite silly observations at the time, were quickly exposed in the light of immediate developments. On 14 October, Heads of Government were informed that the Governor-General of Fiji had advised the Queen that his endeavours to provide constitutional government had proved in vain. He had requested the Queen to relieve him of his appointment with immediate effect. We were informed, as background for our discussion, that a republic was now to be regarded as in being in Fiji and that the Queen had ceased to be Head of State in Fiji. Importantly, Her Majesty expressed the hope that Heads of Government would have uppermost in their minds the question of how best the interests of all the people of Fiji, of whatever race, could be safeguarded under a republican form of government. The discussions at CHOGM proceeded on that footing.

Notwithstanding differences of nuance, in particular national positions, a common view was evident at Vancouver on a number of key propositions. All those present at CHOGM considered the principal challenge in the period immediately ahead to be the need to achieve a new political structure in Fiji which was satisfactory in terms of the legitimate aspirations and rights of all the people of Fiji. A fundamental point of agreement was that the problems confronting Fiji were ultimately for the people of Fiji themselves to resolve. Above all, I consider there was an agreement on the key objective which now needed to guide our thinking: encouraging those in authority in Fiji to adopt policies of moderation, and to chart a course offering the hope of a republic, decent and democratic in character, rather than oppressive and authoritarian.

Accordingly, there was a willingness in Vancouver for the Commonwealth to offer to help Fiji, during the critical formative period in which the new political structure will be fashioned. Heads of Government attached importance to foundations being laid which were consistent with the Commonwealth principles which I have described. It was clear, furthermore, that the character of the future government in Fiji will influence views taken by Commonwealth countries on the question of Fiji's readmission to the association. This, then, was the thinking which informed the statement made by CHOGM on Fiji and which I quote:

Commonwealth leaders acknowledged that on the basis of established Commonwealth conventions Fiji's membership of the Commonwealth lapsed with the emergence of the Republic on 15 October. They viewed with sadness the developments in Fiji and hoped for a resolution of the problem by the people of Fiji on a basis consistent with the principles that have guided the Commonwealth. They agreed that the Commonwealth would, if requested, be ready to offer its good offices towards such a resolution and, on such basis, if the circumstances warrant, to consider the question of Fiji's membership of the Commonwealth if asked to do so.

This outcome is entirely consistent with my Government's own policies. Indeed, it reflects the initiatives which I took at the meeting of South Pacific Forum leaders at Vancouver preceding CHOGM, and in the lengthy discussions at and during the conference. Australia deplores the overturning of democracy in Fiji. We believe we can speak for all Australians in saying that the friendship of Australia towards the people of Fiji is undiminished. We are deeply concerned, not only about the political uncertainty now facing Fiji, but about the economic costs and the disruption to Fiji's international relations which have resulted. We recognise, as a matter of fact, that the future political system in Fiji will be different from the one existing before the military intervention. But we attach high importance to the evolution of a political structure which represents a return to basic democratic principle and which recognises and protects human rights. We hope that all those leaders in Fiji capable of exerting influence and playing a role to that end will do so.

We consider it to be a matter for the people of Fiji to determine their political path. Inevitably, however, Australia's relationship with Fiji-both in terms of its general quality and in terms of specifics such as aid and defence co-operation-must be affected by the direction Fiji takes internally. Put bluntly, we could not have the same relationship with a military dictatorship as with a representative civilian government. We support the Commonwealth, as we earlier supported the South Pacific Forum, in the offer to assist Fiji in its present political difficulties. Those offers are on the table and I believe deserve close consideration by the authorities in Fiji.

I turn now to southern Africa, the political issue of greatest importance for the Vancouver meeting as a whole. Aside from the meeting in London last August of seven Commonwealth countries, Australia included, Vancouver provided the first opportunity for Commonwealth leaders to assess events since the major decisions taken at Nassau in 1985. In the intervening period the situation within South Africa itself had deteriorated; instability and violence had increased; the Government had become more oppressive; the efforts by the Commonwealth Eminent Persons Group to facilitate dialogue and negotiation had been rejected by the South African authorities; South Africa had put increased pressure on neighbouring states; the southern African region as a whole had faced a combination of military and economic destabilisation; and the root cause of all of this, the abhorrent system of apartheid, remained fundamentally unchanged.
At Vancouver we discussed the issues against that background, and Heads of Government issued a Statement on southern Africa and Program of Action. This document makes the important judgment that:
In spite of the Pretoria regime's increased intransigence since Nassau, we remain convinced that only through negotiations can catastrophe be averted.

It calls for the South African Government to accept the negotiating concept developed by the Eminent Persons Group, which remains as valid today as it was when the Group put it forward. The decisions of Vancouver, including on sanctions, need to be seen in that context: not as contradicting dialogue and negotiation but as promoting them. The approach adopted at Vancouver was to secure the universal adoption of the measures which have now been put in place by most Commonwealth countries and others, including the United States and the Nordic countries. At the initiative of Australia an expert study will be undertaken of South Africa's relationship with the international financial system, a system which has itself imposed significant pressure on the South African economy in the past.

I wish to comment briefly on the effectiveness of sanctions, since clearly this was an issue which, at Vancouver as in the past, divided Britain from the rest. Ironically, and most uncomfortably for those who deny that sanctions are effective, at the time CHOGM was meeting the South African Government itself conceded that sanctions were hurting. On 15 October the South African Finance Minister, speaking at the National Party's Natal Congress, said that the negative economic effect of sanctions should not be underestimated. South Africa had, he said, accumulated billions of dollars worth of non-productive assets, such as oil, which had to be stockpiled because of sanctions. He asked his audience to imagine what could be done if, for example, South Africa had certainty regarding supplies of oil and other strategic commodities and was able to release these reserves to finance development and infrastructure.

Moreover, critics of sanctions tend to have a simplistic view. They seem to be saying that unless the measures adopted bring an economy to its knees then they have failed. But the Government has indicated frequently that the aim is not to bring South Africa to its knees but to bring it to its senses. Changes in public attitudes and in the attitudes of a government as locked into the past as are South Africa's may well take time. Far from helping this process, easing up on external pressure would be utterly counter-productive. As the Eminent Persons Group report says:

If the South African Government comes to the conclusion that it would always remain protected from such measures the process of change in South Africa is unlikely to increase in momentum and the descent into violence would be accelerated.

Nor can the view be sustained that the Commonwealth is not in a position to exert significant pressure. That ignores the catalytic role of the Commonwealth in raising the consciousness of the international community and in encouraging measures on the part of the major economic powers. Opponents of sanctions also seem to ignore the fact that some situations are so abhorrent that it would be inadequate simply to declare them wrong, without making a tangible expression of that abhorrence. They would leave the Western countries with no concrete means of demonstrating support for those striving for change in South Africa, support which they have every right to expect from countries espousing liberal democratic principles. But it is also a matter of self-interest. To refuse to lend forthright support is a recipe for alienating from the West the future leaders of the post-apartheid South Africa. It is to undermine those leaders of the struggle who have the moderate objective of political equality, social justice and economic prosperity for all citizens regardless of race.

CHOGM also addressed what the Eminent Persons Group appropriately called `the external face of apartheid', the security and economic problems of South Africa's neighbours. We decided to initiate an enhanced program of co-ordinated Commonwealth assistance. This will be directed towards the front line and neighbouring states, particularly Mozambique. I note in this context that the Government in the last Budget provided for an increased program of assistance to the southern African region amounting to $55m over three years. Another important element of the CHOGM decisions was a new effort to reach into South Africa through, among other measures, the provision of assistance to the victims of apartheid such as detainees and their families and support to the trade union movement.

I draw attention also to the establishment of a mechanism by the Commonwealth to provide high level impetus and guidance on the southern African issues between meetings of Heads of Government. This will take the form of a committee of Foreign Ministers which will meet periodically. Australia will be represented on that committee. As I said at the outset, CHOGM addressed many other political and economic issues of interest to Australia, ranging from the welcome improvement in East-West relations, through prospects for progress in arms control to such important regional issues as New Caledonia and international economic questions such as debt. Our decisions are reflected in the communique.

Finally, I note that reaffirmation at Vancouver of the value of functional co-operation between Commonwealth countries. It is important to recognise that of course there is a limit to how much the Commonwealth should do or how widely it should spread its activities, particularly at a time of tight budgetary restraint. My Government does not take the view that Commonwealth programs should forever expand. But equally we do recognise that there are areas where the Commonwealth can and does play a valuable role. In that connection I mention the steps which the Vancouver meeting decided to take to facilitate distance education. This has real promise and potential. Australia, with our experience in distance learning, should be able both to contribute to and benefit from the co-operative arrangements which are to be established. In closing this section, I pay tribute to Brian Mulroney, the people of Vancouver and the province of British Columbia for their hospitality during what was a very well-run and friendly meeting.
Ireland and Yugoslavia

My visit was also devoted to the task of forging closer links with two European nations which are of particular importance to Australia: Ireland and Yugoslavia. About one in three Australians today claim Irish ancestry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you include yourself?

—No, I am a fringe dweller; but a devotee, I can assure the honourable member. About one in three Australians today claims Irish ancestry, since there has been a steady flow of immigrants to Australia from Ireland dating from the first day of European settlement of this land. More recently, significant numbers of Yugoslavian people have chosen Australia as their new home. These links of kinship with Ireland and Yugoslavia were reflected in the warmth of the welcome I received in both countries. Nor are our ties with these countries merely of an emotional nature. We share a number of valuable commercial interests and we are affected by the broad range of pressing global political issues. I took the opportunity in my discussions with leaders in both countries of exploring Australian concerns in these fields.

SPEECH.PARA: Ireland

Nobody who has ever sung an Australian folk song, become involved in Australian politics or participated in Australian sport could have done so without recognising the profound and generous contribution of the Irish people to the development of our nation. Outside Ireland itself, there is no country more Irish than Australia. As I told the Irish Taoiseach, Mr Charles Haughey, on my arrival at Dublin Airport, I felt as if I had arrived home, so friendly and familiar was the atmosphere.

As Australians approach our Bicentennial, it is appropriate that we look back over 200 years of Irish involvement in the broadest spectrum of our economic, political, religious and cultural life. And as we continue in the creation of a truly multicultural society, it is appropriate that we recall the struggle for equality of opportunity and cultural freedom fought by the Irish, who constituted our first and largest ethnic minority.

On my visit to Ireland, I discussed these links of kinship in an address at University College, Dublin. This college is the home of the Keith Cameron Chair of Australian History, a professorship jointly funded by the Australian Government and Mr Tony O'Reilly, a generous benefactor of Ireland and Irish culture.

I also had the pleasure of witnessing contemporary manifestations of the Irish-Australian heritage at Croke Park Dublin-namely, the first test match between Irish and Australian footballers. Although Australia lost by a narrow margin, it was a highly enjoyable game of football. I was pleased to note that the Australians have since gone on to win the series. I wish the organisers well in their continuing efforts to seek a compromised form of rules to allow the unique Australian and Gaelic codes to be contested at the international level.

The Irish Dail, or Parliament, gave me the honour of an invitation to address them. This was only the third time the Dail had extended such an invitation to a foreign head of government, my two predecessors being President Reagan and the late President Kennedy. As I told the Dail in my address on 21 October, their choice of two Americans and one Australian reflects the historical truth that, though Ireland is the most anti-imperialist of nations, it is the head of a spiritual empire-an empire of Irish kinship, character and commitment-of which Australia and the United States are the principal provinces.

Australia's historical links with Ireland are particularly important as we approach our Bicentenary. I thanked the Irish Government on a number of occasions for its generous involvement in our bicentennial celebrations which will include the gift of microfilm records of the 40,000 Irish men and women transported to Australia from Ireland in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries.

However, it would have been inappropriate if my speech to the Dail, or indeed my entire visit to Ireland, dwelt solely on the historical elements of our relationship. As medium-sized industrial economies which share and nourish the same commitment to democracy, Australia and Ireland can bring important perspectives to resolving the range of pressing contemporary issues we face.

Australia has chosen the path of a firm alliance relationship with the United States and is in the process of enmeshing itself in the dynamic Pacific rim, while Ireland has chosen neutrality and membership of the European Community. But both countries share the same aspirations for peace, arms control, human rights, the principles of national self-determination and the elimination of apartheid. Just as successive Irish governments have been committed to enhancing the prospects for international peace-through, for example, their contribution to United Nations peacekeeping forces-they have been dedicated also to the achievement of peace on their own borders.
