I told the Dail that Australia supported the efforts of the Irish and British governments, through the Anglo-Irish Agreement, to end the communal strife in Northern Ireland. And I know all honourable members would support me in giving an assurance to the Irish Government that we would do all within our power to discourage any Australian citizen from adding in any way to the violence in Northern Ireland.

On economic issues, the Taoiseach and I discussed strategies of consensus and co-operation through which our nations could create the self-discipline needed to meet the economic challenges we face. We found common ground in the observation that countries like Australia and Ireland cannot afford to live beyond their means. Governments must take the hard decisions to reorder our priorities, reduce deficits, attack indebtedness, tighten spending and question the assumptions of the past in order to secure long term economic health.

In my speech to the Dail, I added that all these hard adjustment decisions would avail a nation little if it faced a hostile international environment-particularly one which damaged the international trading system. Consistent, then, with the overall thrust of my trip, I told the Irish, as members of the European Community, that the EC's policies of agricultural subsidisation were damaging not just countries like Australia but ultimately the perpetrators of protectionism as well.
Yugoslavia

Australia and Yugoslavia have an active and constructive relationship based in particular around Yugoslavia's pivotal position in East-West relations and its prominent role in the non-aligned movement and, on a bilateral basis, around the 300,000-strong community of Yugoslavian descent now living in Australia. My discussions in Belgrade with Prime Minister Branko Mikulic focused largely on economic and trade matters. They were frank, informal and very friendly. I outlined to the Prime Minister the Australian position on international trade and the efforts we had been making in a number of fora, including my address to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, towards liberalising world trade. The Prime Minister indicated that Yugoslavia shared Australia's concerns and supported our efforts to free up world trade, especially in agriculture, since Yugoslavia had been suffering from the United States-European Community's subsidies war.

In the area of domestic economic policy, the Prime Minister and I discussed our respective policies of economic stabilisation and economic reform. I was particularly indebted to Prime Minister Mikulic for his extremely frank and detailed exposition of the reforms being pursued in Yugoslavia in an effort to remedy the very significant economic problems facing the country. The reforms it is undertaking are clearly market oriented. They are designed to overhaul the economy and, particularly, to ease the country's significant external debt problem. In my judgment the Prime Minister's exposition reflected a sound understanding of the nature of the problems and the remedies that are necessary. The explanation consisted in part of saying that Yugoslavia had been living beyond its means during the 1970s and that inevitably, therefore, adjustments had to be made. He referred to the fact that during the 1980s real wages had fallen in the order of 25 per cent.

Prime Minister Mikulic expressed his frustration and that of Yugoslavia that many Western countries seem still to regard Yugoslavia as part of the Eastern bloc. He pointed out that it is not; it is non-aligned. He explained, for example, that for 1987 to date more than half of Yugoslavia's trade was with the West. Yet this perception, he said, had been damaging for the prospects of economic co-operation between Yugoslavia and the West. I undertook to the Prime Minister that I would do all I could to dispel the misconceptions held by Western countries. In particular, I undertook to talk to our friends in the United States to the effect that it would make sense for them to be more forthcoming in economic relations with Yugoslavia.

Prime Minister Mikulic and I agreed to formalise our bilateral economic relations to seek to enhance trade, and to extend joint ventures-building on the success of Rudi Cajavec's enterprise with the Telectronics company of Australia to assemble and to manufacture Australian designed heart pacemakers for use in Yugoslavia and for export from Yugoslavia. We also will be looking at ways of promoting scientific and technical co-operation. We have agreed that there will be an initial meeting of officials to be held at the earliest practicable opportunity. That meeting of officials will then seek to formalise the form that the annual meetings between our two countries will take. The presence in Australia of so many people of Yugoslavian origin is overwhelmingly a positive link between our two countries. But as I told Mr Mikulic, it would be foolish of both sides not to recognise that on occasion it can create some awkwardness in our bilateral relations.

People, in exercising their right to free speech in Australia, may say things which touch old wounds and scrape sensitive nerves. We are determined to maintain this right of people to speak freely even if they may say things with which we disagree. That is their right as free Australians as long as they do not move towards violence, which the Australian Government will not tolerate. Although this is a problem that is, thankfully, diminishing with time, it still occasionally occurs. What is encouraging is that, in recent instances, the recognition by both of us of the strength and importance of our friendship, together with the discretion and common sense shown by the respective governments, have enabled us to find solutions. Yugoslavia's leading role in the non-aligned movement and its strategic position and independent approach give it a particularly interesting perspective on issues of importance to Australia.

In Belgrade, I had the opportunity to exchange views on foreign policy issues of common interest with President Lazar Mojsov, a distinguished international statesman. We had useful discussions on East-West relations, the Middle East, the Persian Gulf and Indo-China.
THE AUSTRALIAN-AMERICAN ALLIANCE

Honourable members will recall that the United States Secretary of State, George Shultz, and Secretary for Defense, Caspar Weinberger, visited Sydney in June for bilateral ministerial talks with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden), the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and myself. Those talks confirmed the strength of the alliance between our two countries and the close and friendly nature of the Australia-United States relationship. On my recent overseas visit, I had the opportunity to spend several hours in discussion with Mr Shultz, in and around San Francisco on 10 and 11 October.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who won the golf?

—We won. I found these talks particularly useful. They took place against the background of important developments in East-West relations, the Asia-Pacific region, the Middle East and the Persian Gulf, and the world economy. I drew Mr Shultz's attention to the speech I had made in San Diego on United States trade policy and Australian-American relations, to which I have already referred. We discussed developments in the Persian Gulf and, in the light of the forthcoming visit of the Secretary of State to Egypt and Israel, which has since of course taken place, the prospect for an international conference on the Middle East. We exchanged views about the Philippines and reiterated the firm support of both our governments for President Aquino. I gave Mr Shultz our appreciation of developments in the South Pacific. Without seeking to exaggerate the situation, I expressed the view that the overthrow of parliamentary democracy in Fiji and France's insensitive policy in New Caledonia were among the factors which had made it a less stable region than was the case at the beginning of the decade.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Shultz previewed for me his visit to Moscow, which took place two weeks ago. From Australia's point of view, I expressed the importance we attach to the conclusion of an intermediate range nuclear forces agreement, both for its own sake and as a step towards reductions in strategic nuclear arsenals and other areas of arms control. The Secretary of State very kindly offered to send a member of his delegation to brief me on the outcome of his talks with Mr Gorbachev and Mr Shevardnadze, immediately they were concluded. Accordingly, Mr Tom Simons, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State, a Soviet specialist, flew straight from Moscow to Dubrovnik and gave me and my party a detailed and very informative account of the meetings and some interesting impressions of the important developments now taking place in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. Overall, my visit confirmed very clearly that Australia's relationship with the United States is in excellent shape.

Australia must continue to push hard on the issue of trade liberalisation. I am happy to report that my efforts overseas to make progress on this front were well received. Although negotiations will inevitably be slow and painstaking, I believe Australia has established the credibility of its voice in urging an early harvest of results. I am also pleased to report that our role remains a prominent one in that valuable global association, the Commonwealth. Our alliance relationship with the United States remains soundly based. Our friendly bilateral relationships with Ireland and Yugoslavia have been put on a new and even more constructive footing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOWARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I welcome the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has made this statement to the Parliament about his recent visit overseas. I have some positive things to say about the statement and the visit, and I also have some negative things to say.
—That would not surprise us.

—And neither should it. I say to the Prime Minister, firstly, that I welcome the fact that his Government no longer regards the Commonwealth with the same scorn as did the then Leader of the Opposition and present Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) in 1979 when he described the Commonwealth as a rather useless body to which Australia should not belong. The Liberal and National parties have always regarded the Commonwealth's association as important. It brings Australia into contact not only with countries sharing a very strong historical affiliation with Australia but also with a multiracial world. That is very important to the future of this country and it is very important as far as our strategic position is concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister, to the extent that he, on behalf of his Government, pursues overseas the cause of trade liberalisation, will have the total support of the Opposition. To the extent that he argues, has he must as Prime Minister of Australia, for a fairer trade deal for Australia and for agricultural exporters generally, he will have the support of the Opposition. To the extent that he says to the United States Government that our relationship entitles us to speak frankly and sharply to the Americans and he emphasises our concern, even our anger, at the way in which we have been treated on trade matters, he will also have the total support of the Opposition. He is acting in those matters as a trustee for the interests of so many concerned Australians. However, to the extent that the Prime Minister, either by his own silence-I note that it was not referred to in his speech tonight-or by the statements of his Ministers allows the issues of trade and the strategic position of Australia to be mixed in any way, he will have the total opposition of the Liberal and National parties.

Under no circumstances would we ever support a policy that put the maintenance of the American joint facilities on the table with trade matters. We have joint facilities in Australia because they are beneficial to Australia. We do not have them in Australia predominantly because they are beneficial to the United States. Those in the Australian Labor Party and elsewhere who continue to question the existence of those joint facilities make the fatal mistake of assuming that in some way we are doing a great favour to the rest of the world. In fact, we are doing a favour to ourselves and we are making a major contribution to the strategic position of the entire Western world.

I say to the Prime Minister that all Australians, both of his political persuasion and of mine, welcome the remarks that he made about the association between Australia and Ireland. It is a very deep, a very important, a very emotional and a very profound relationship. I know that many people who have come to Australia from Yugoslavia since the war will welcome the fact that an Australian Prime Minister has gone to Yugoslavia and, I hope, contributed a little towards improving the links that exist between our two countries. Having said that, I must say to the Prime Minister that many Australians resented the supercilious, contemptuous remarks that he apparently made about the British at his Press conference as reported on 27 October 1987. It does nothing for his reputation or for the reputation of this country for him to say, in answer to a question:
Because I don't give a stuff about the Brits.
The story then says:
Mr Hawke spat, turned on his heel and walked off.

TALK.START.PARA: —Inaccurate.

—If that is inaccurate, something should have been said about it before now. I have to say to the Prime Minister that that kind of behaviour does him no credit, his Party no credit and this country no credit. Just as many Australians will welcome what he had to say about the Irish and the Yugoslavians, an enormous number of Australians regard that kind of remark as absolutely absurd. The reason is that the Prime Minister has allowed the British Prime Minister to get under his skin and has made the fundamental mistake of allowing his personal dislike of somebody else to colour his political judgment. To that extent, that is one of the negative things I have to say about the Prime Minister's visit overseas.

SPEECH.PARA: A lot of what the Prime Minister had to say about Fiji was unexceptionable and we would agree with it. I think the Prime Minister was engaging in a bit of retrospective whitewashing of his role in predicting what Her Majesty might do in relation to Fiji. I think the Prime Minister has been guilty-I will come to this matter in a moment-of a touch of double standards in relation to trade sanctions and in relation to his attitude towards the takeovers in Fiji. If the Prime Minister is adopting an attitude of pragmatism and realism towards Fiji, that is understood. However, the Prime Minister will recall that when one of my colleagues, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), adopted the same attitude at the time of the first coup he was called everything under the sun by the Prime Minister and was denounced as being out of sympathy with democratic principles.

The overthrow of the Bavadra Government in Fiji remains nothing other than a military coup. In character, it is no different from the overthrow of other democratically elected governments. It is inevitable that there will be erected in Fiji a constitution and a form of government based on racial discrimination. However much they may colour that and however much they may think it is a little more benign-because we all have a benign, amiable, rather sentimental attitude towards Fiji because of its nature and character and the character of its people-the Prime Minister and the Government ought to understand that, in essence, there are no substantial differences between the way in which the Bavadra Government was overthrown and way in which other governments have been overthrown and regimes established in their place.

That brings me to the question of southern Africa and the remarks that the Prime Minister made about South Africa. It is here where we disagree most sharply with what the Prime Minister had to say and where the Government stands. We do not disagree in our attitude towards apartheid, but we do disagree in our attitude towards the imposition of economic sanctions. The Prime Minister in his statement misrepresents the case against economic sanctions. It has never been my argument, nor has it been the argument of the Opposition, that economic sanctions do not have an effect; they do have an effect. Our argument is that they have the wrong effect. The effect that we want any action taken against South Africa to have is to bring about a convergence of action and view between the moderate blacks and the liberal whites and a state of affairs where their attitudes and their desire for change and reform will gradually gather sway and come to the fore in South Africa, replacing the present extreme dictatorial attitudes of the extremist whites.

It is for that reason, because we do not believe that economic sanctions are having that effect, that we are opposed to those economic sanctions. Of course, if we impose sanctions against a country it will have an enfeebling effect. Of course, the South African economy would now be stronger if it were not for economic sanctions, but unfortunately those economic sanctions are having the effect of driving more and more whites in South Africa into the hands of the extreme right wing Afrikaner political movements. The results of the recent South African elections are a condemnation of the political wisdom of imposing economic sanctions.

The Prime Minister talks and exhorts about the need to have regard to moderate voices in South Africa. I remind him that on 5 September this year, a bare six weeks ago, Chief Buthelezi, the head of the largest black nation in South Africa, said:
It is we blacks who are paying the price for sanctions and disinvestment which have not had the effect they were designed to have.

That was not P. W. Botha; that was not some mad right wing Afrikaner ratbag; that was Chief Buthelezi, the head of the Zulus. He was saying that the Government had got it wrong. He was saying that sanctions are strengthening the hands of the extremist whites and that they are hurting the blacks. It is on that basis that we are opposed to economic sanctions.

The sheer moral bankruptcy of the Government's position on South Africa was revealed this afternoon when the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan) admitted that there was a cooked up deal between Qantas Airways Ltd and South African Airways (SAA) to ensure that we get a bigger slice of the action via Qantas. Where is the morality in that? The Prime Minister gets up here and says, `Oh, we have all got to make some sacrifices in the name of fighting apartheid'. Yet he admits there is some sleazy deal between SAA and Qantas. That is a morally bankrupt policy. Yet he will sit on a podium with the leaders of Zimbabwe and Zambia, who have not participated in democratic elections for a long, long time, and presume to lecture on the motives of the leader of one of the most democratic countries in the world. I think the Prime Minister's policy on South Africa is politically misplaced. I do not think it is on firm moral ground. The case against sanctions has been condemned not only by people such as Chief Buthelezi; it was condemned recently by Helen Suzman in the following words:
The imposition of sanctions and other punitive measures such as disinvestment have not only been ineffective but actually counter-productive.
Alan Paton, the author, said at the same time:
A second and lesser reason for the recent election results in South Africa-
the first being security concerns-
was the ill-advised sanctions campaign of the West.

Those remarks were made not by an extreme Afrikaner, a spokesman for the British Government or Margaret Thatcher but by Alan Paton, Helen Suzman and Chief Buthelezi. They are there. They speak with more authority, more feeling and more understanding. Instead of listening to this shrill, ill-advised campaign that is conducted on sanctions, I think that we would be reacting with a great deal more common sense on this subject if we understood that the case against sanctions is not so much that they do not have an effect but rather that they are having the wrong effects.

The real tragedy of South Africa is that the more we drive the whites into isolation, the more we will drive them upon themselves. Those honourable members who believe the sanctions will work fail to understand the enormous military might of the whites and the enormous manic determination of many of those people to preserve their way of life, which I detest and do not support. My great fear is that this isolation process of the West will eventually bring about the very conflagration, the very bloodbath and the very reaction of a contained ghetto which down through the years have been the experience when men are treated in that fashion. I think the Government is hopelessly wrong and I think those who support sanctions, on whatever side of politics, are hopelessly wrong on this issue. I think that they will bring about the very tragedy that all of us hope will never occur in that country.

The Prime Minister's statement dealt at very great length with trading matters. I return to what I said at the commencement of this speech: to the extent that the Prime Minister, in going to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade meeting, in talking to the United States and so forth, is arguing a case for freer trade, a better deal for our exporters and, to the extent that he is genuinely committed-and I hope his Government is-to the kind of staged reductions in industrial protection that he put on the table at the GATT meeting, he will have the support and the goodwill of the Liberal and National parties.

Of all countries, none is more in need of a liberal trading environment than Australia. I know from my own experience some years ago, as Minister for Special Trade Negotiations, in dealing with the European Economic Community, that no group of countries over the years has been more insensitive in trading matters than the European Economic Community. The present Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy) has not only my goodwill but also my sympathy in dealing with the countries of the European Economic Community.

I say one other thing: when we are apportioning and balancing blame so far as trade matters are concerned, whilst, understandably and properly, we vent criticism and, on occasions, our spleen at the attitudes of the United States Congress and, perhaps, of the United States Administration, I believe that the real culprits in the agricultural protection issue are the members of the European Economic Community. I do not believe that they have made a serious attempt over the last 15 years to bring about any substantial dismantling of the protective barriers. Their predatory trading practices have, in large measure, provoked the reaction of the United States.

I conclude by saying that whilst I unqualifiedly welcome the speech of the Prime Minister, because I believe it is important that the Prime Minister report to the Parliament on his visit, like the curate's egg, it was good in parts, but in many parts I found not only his policies to be misplaced and his explanations to be self-indulgent, but also his strategic vision absolutely absent.
Sitting suspended from 6.33 to 8 p.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: FAMILY LAW AMENDMENT BILL 1987[COGNATE BILL:FAMILY COURT OF AUSTRALIA (ADDITIONAL JURISDICTION AND EXERCISE OF POWERS) BILL 1987]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate was adjourned some hours ago I was concluding my remarks by asking the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) for the reasons why the Government would not agree to what the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), has proposed, which is that the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill be referred to a committee set up by this Parliament so that it can be examined and that the committee have until June to report and that the Family Law Amendment Bill also be referred to the same committee and that the committee have one month to report. By that means the Government's legislation program and the Family Law Amendment Bill will be met because the legislation will then go to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: If we do not use committees for Bills of this importance, what use are they? The Government set them up. Every honourable member knows that the Bills before the House are of profound importance to ordinary Australians because one-third of the marriages in this country ends up before the courts. If there were ever a case for sending Bills to a committee, these Bills are such a case. I therefore ask the Attorney-General, who I think takes a very sensible view about the use of Parliament's time, why these Bills should not be sent to a committee. If they were, we would have the opportunity, through the committee, of properly examining this legislation.

Honourable members should bear this in mind: last week I tried to get hold of a copy of the Family Law Amendment Bill, which is over 40 pages long. A copy was not available. So I have seen it for the first time this week and almost everybody else is in the same position. Either we treat the Parliament as an important forum or we say, effectively, that it is not more than a place for grinding through legislation on a sausage machine basis. We either treat the committees as important, as having a real function, or we say, `These committees are so much window-dressing. They were set up for one reason only, and that was to appease some of the factional problems within the Australian Labor Party'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Whip for allowing me to enter into this debate tonight on what I consider to be very important legislation. I also approach the Family Law Amendment Bill and the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill with a sense of sadness because I am in agreement with some of the comments that were made earlier in this debate by the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster). He looked very closely at the breakdown that is occurring in society that has led to the need for legislation of this type to be put into the statutes.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) in his contribution a few moments ago alluded to the fact that it is a very sad state of affairs that the rate of marriage breakdown in the Australian community is not diminishing but increasing. At present something like two in every five marriages end in divorce. A very sad corollary of that fact is that currently more than 250,000 lone parents are on some sort of benefit attempting to care for 450,000 children. For most of these households, the pension or benefit is their only source of income. For years we have talked about Australia being a lucky country but we have to reflect upon the very sad fact that we have to have legislation that establishes precedents in the family law courts for people who, for one reason or another, suffer from family breakdown and who have no other recourse than to seek divorce.

In marriages where there are children divorce obviously has lasting psychological and sociological effects, not only on the parents but also most certainly on the children of those marriages. What we have seen in society in recent times often is a reflection of that sad state of affairs. We have seen an increase in violence, particularly in child violence. Quite often this is a factor that has led to the necessity for divorce laws to be put in place, to enable people living in those horrendous conditions to get away from them. As I have indicated, it is my belief that the social and psychological scarring that emanates from that is very distressing.

The high proportion of marriages throughout Australia ending in divorce has also meant the growth of an industry which, again, I would rather not see occur. I refer, of course, to the marriage counselling industry. In my area of the Illawarra, a number of these agencies have operated most effectively over a period of time. I am not suggesting for one moment that the work they do has in any way not been good or necessary; my concern is that that work has to be done because of the problems society has caused which have led to the breakdown in marriages and problems for children. There are a number of these marriage counselling services throughout the Illawarra region. I can understand that because of budgetary constraints and the broad fiscal concerns this Government has been faced with, unfortunately funding levels for some of these marriage counselling services have not been able to be sustained to the degree the services would want. That is one of the big problems we are facing.

I know that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) shares the concerns I have because I have spoken with him at length on this issue. It is an unfortunate fact of life associated with the budgetary processes within government that the provision of certain services has been affected by the necessary decisions of government to prune expenditure across the board. Hopefully, in the future, there will be a reconsideration of funding for those services. I hope that the support of other members on both sides of the House might be forthcoming, as I know it is from the Attorney-General.

One of our major concerns is that, with the number of marriages that end in divorce and the fact that 450,000 children may be affected because they have only a single parent, more than 70 per cent of parents no longer living with their children will not pay any regular form of maintenance. I commend the Attorney and this Government for taking the steps necessary to ensure that those children who are affected by these sorts of situations are catered for by this legislation. Not surprisingly, therefore, we find that sole parenting is becoming more and more recognised as the most serious poverty trap in our society. Following extensive consultation within the community the Government has devised a strategy for child support reform with the primary and overriding goal of lifting Australian children out of poverty, as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) indicated recently in the Government's policy speech.

Given that inadequate support by non-custodial parents contributes to the poverty of their children and that it also contributes to the heavy demand on our social security system, the underlying concept of child support reform is that the responsibility of both parents to maintain a child takes priority over all the other commitments in terms of income. The House will be aware that, unfortunately, such a concept is novel for something like 70 per cent of non-custodial parents. I give one particular example, which ably illustrates the concern that I have here. Recently a situation was drawn to my attention where a professional person was contributing a pittance to the maintenance of his two teenage sons, who were living in a household largely dependent on a pension. This was because of a marriage breakdown. He justified his lack of financial support for his two children by arguing that he and his working second wife were paying off a house, a swimming pool, their cars and so on and could not afford the maintenance of his two children from his former marriage.

I have listened to some of the arguments put by people, both in debate in the House today and in other forums, where people have argued that when marriages break down and remarriages occur, it should not necessarily be the responsibility of the new parents to pick up maintenance. There is some degree of truth in that, but there is also a very strong degree of truth in the fact that many parents simply walk away from their responsibilities for children of former marriages and are not prepared to pay any maintenance whatsoever.

I conclude with what I began by saying: It is a sad reflection on Australian society today that legislation of this type is necessary. I would hope that all honourable members are concerned-obviously they are, from what has been said in the debate so far-about where Australian society is heading. There are no miracle cures for the problem of divorce in Australia, but as legislators we have to be sure that we are making allowances for those people who are affected by divorce, that we are making it as painless as we possibly can and that we are making adequate compensation available, particularly for the children of divorced parents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has moved an amendment on the grounds that we believe that the legislation should be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for inquiry, and we object to the way that this very important and complex legislation is being pushed through. No doubt it will go to the Senate, which will go through the procedure of referring it to a committee and the immense amount of work that it has before it will slow down the legislation. As the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), said, had we been returned to power in 1983, many of the things that are being implemented now would have been implemented some years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), in his second reading speech, said:
The Bill makes substantial changes to the Family Law Act with respect to the maintenance of children.
Further on he said:

The Minister for Social Security said in his statement that the Government would consider changes to access laws and the enforcement of access orders after it received the reports to be made by the Family Law Council on access and the Law Reform Commission on contempt of court. Those reports have now been tabled in the Parliament and the Government will be assessing the public reaction to the reports. Further amendments may be made to the Family Law Act in the light of that consideration and of the Government's consideration of the separate report on matrimonial property by the Law Reform Commission.

For starters, the Attorney-General said that the Government will be waiting for a public response on the two reports, one of which is Access-Some Options for Reform, a report hurriedly put together by the Family Law Council and its access sub-committee. That is a 40-page report and no doubt will sell for about $3, so it will be within the financial reach of most people. However, we have the other report on which the Attorney-General expects the public to comment and it has 642 pages. I know a lot of Australians have the capacity to lie awake in bed at night reading reports such as this, but most of them could not afford the $39.95 price. I suggest to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, with respect, that to be waiting for public response to these reports is a little unrealistic. I suggest that the report by the Family Law Council titled Access-Some Options for Reform should be compulsory reading for every member of the Parliament. That does not mean that I agree with every recommendation it makes. The report canvasses, in a fairly substantial way, the problems which exist in the field of access.

As we know, this legislation is an attempt to tighten up the laws covering maintenance. As an experienced politician I know that a considerable degree of seething unrest is displayed, particularly by males, on the question of access. The report by the Family Law Council goes to great lengths to say that maintenance and access should not be seen as one, but the reality of life is that it is often seen as a hand in hand affair. A lot of the avoidance of maintenance payments has arisen as a result of the antagonism and bitterness often displayed between parting couples when the custodial partner frustrates access provisions which may have been stamped with approval at the time of the dissolution of the marriage. Whilst the Law Council might go to great pains to try to emphasise the need to keep maintenance and access apart, I know that there are many parents-fathers in particular because they are the ones who seem to suffer in terms of access-who have been frustrated and locked out because of broken arrangements and their former spouse continuing to seek revenge. These people say, `To hell with it. If I'm not going to gain access to my kids, I'm not going to honour any maintenance obligations'. I am not for one moment suggesting that where there has been cruelty or abuse the person responsible should have the right to access. It is not a God-given right. Access is something that has to be decided by the courts because some people are simply unsuitable to be entrusted with children; they are cruel or have a history of sexual abuse.

The question of access is almost a volcano in the community. It has been bubbling under the surface for a dozen years now and I do not think we can continue to ignore it. Even the Government's request to the Family Law Council to prepare a report was met with a qualification. The report states:
The Council's committee was hampered in its enquiry by a lack of adequate research and statistical information relating to access to children in this country.
The report goes on to say:
The Council believes that action to rectify these deficiencies-
meaning the lack of material that has been collated over the years-
should be taken as a matter of urgency and has made many recommendations on it in the past together with statements in its Annual Reports about the inadequacies of Family Court statistics.

I have known the Attorney-General for a long time and I have considerable respect for him. I ask him to go to Cabinet, as Deputy Prime Minister with all the persuasive power he possesses-when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is well again-and say to his colleagues that it is time we bit the access bullet. The situation is volcanic and if we continue to ignore it we will see more mass suicides and more murders and the judiciary will share the brunt of the ill-will existing in the community. I thank the Attorney-General for the courtesy he has extended to me in allowing me to speak tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) for allowing me a few minutes indulgence in this matter. The changes proposed in the Family Law Amendment Bill are very far-reaching and affect an extremely complex and emotional area of the law. It is for this reason that the Opposition believes that greater discussion is essential on the many issues contained in the legislation which have been highlighted by my colleagues this evening. I, too, am concerned that the public and the Parliament have been given far too short a time to consider the ramifications of these most fundamental changes.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Attorney-General is well aware, family law traditionally has been bipartisan. In fact, in many cases there has even been a free vote on these matters. Therefore, the Opposition believes that on issues of such fundamental importance as the difficulties which arise from breaches of marriages and the problems relating to the children of those marriages, the Parliament should have been much more involved in the examination of the implications of these proposals than has been the case. It is principally for that reason that we have moved the reference of this matter-which I support-to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs to examine its full implications.

The whole problem of breakdown of marriage and child maintenance, which is at the bottom of the amendments proposed, is of fundamental importance. There is an increasing number of single parent families and their poverty and the growth in government expenditure demand a fundamental reassessment of private and public roles in providing support for these families. As a proportion of all families in Australia, the number of sole parent families rose from 9 per cent in the mid-1970s to the current figure of 14 per cent. This was due in part to the increased number of divorces-39,417 cases in 1986. The proportion of sole parent families on social security has also risen, with the result that some 85 per cent, or 250,000 people, are now on pensions or benefits in this category. The expenditure estimate in the 1987-88 Budget for the widow's pension class A was $1,011.5m and that for the supporting parent's benefit has risen from $1,509.8m to a total, combining pensions in both class A and class B, to $2,521.3m. Obviously this is an extremely serious financial problem. For that reason the number of recipients of the supporting parent's benefit, which was introduced in 1974 and which then cost $40.6m, has escalated from 26,000 in that year to about 180,000 today.

The evidence gained by various organisations and universities throughout Australia demonstrates clearly that many single parent families are living in poverty, with 15 per cent earning less than average weekly earnings. The Joint Parliamentary Committee on the Family Law Act reported in 1980 that a maximum of nearly 40 per cent of Australian maintenance orders were fully complied with and another 40 per cent were never paid at all. Statistics show that only 25 per cent of sole parents in receipt of pensions are receiving maintenance from the non-custodial parent. Therefore, for this reason the proposals in this Bill are of fundamental importance. We are telling the courts that it is now their responsibility to ensure that in the determination of maintenance orders they do not consider whether people have access to social security benefits. Over the years the evidence has been quite conclusive that because the courts have taken into account supplementary forms of finance, the effect has been that less pressure has been brought to bear on non-custodial parents, in particular, also to make a financial contribution to the maintenance of their children.

The whole basis of this set of reforms, which, as my colleague the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) pointed out earlier, we agree with in principle, is to ensure that parents, irrespective of what the relationship may have been in the past, who have brought children into the world are responsible for their maintenance. To say, as so many have obviously done, having broken a marriage and having taken the approach that there has been a clean break-to use the expression which was rather familiar back in the 1970s-that that automatically entitles them to assume that they have no further financial responsibility whatsoever, is a view which the Opposition and, I presume the Government simply do not accept. That is one reason why this legislation and these amendments are being put forward this evening.

In that particular context I should also pay tribute to the work of Senator Peter Durack whose own private member's Bill last year, and again quite recently, was really the basis of some of the reforms contained in this legislation. He not only referred to the first point which I have just made in relation to preventing the courts from taking account of access to benefits, but also he required that the courts should consider the costs of maintaining children. Again, that is a worthwhile reform contained in this legislation.

The Institute of Family Studies claims that the costs of maintaining children today are in excess of $50, and yet the average maintenance rate, if I recall, is somewhere around $23. Clearly, therefore, there is a fundamental problem ahead of us as to how we are going to be able to get non-custodial parents to be prepared to bridge the difference between $23 and the actual cost of maintaining children. I have not the slightest doubt-no doubt the Minister has not either-that many people will be concerned about this and there will be various arguments as to their financial capacity to pay. For that reason one of the other very worthwhile amendments in this proposal is the introduction and the application in law of what are known as the principles outlined in the Mee v. Ferguson case. The substance of that particular case is very relevant in this case. That was simply because the judgment laid down that this Act now provides that non-custodial parents must put the financing of the welfare of their children over all other supplementary costs. All children, whether from a first or subsequent marriage, are to be treated equally for this particular exercise, but the need to maintain those children takes precedence.

There have been cases before the courts involving the need to pay off loans on fast sports cars, bigger houses, yachts and goodness knows what else. The importance of this reform is that the court now knows quite categorically, as directed by Parliament, that the primary responsibility in the determination of maintenance will be that that financial responsibility takes first priority over all others. That is something which the Opposition strongly supports.

The fact of the matter is that at present one-third of marriages in Australia are failing. I think one has to ask whether it is adequate for us simply to put so many resources and so much effort into trying to make a family law system work when so many people, especially those who have gone through the courts, clearly find that it is deficient. I think we need to ask through this Parliament some very basic questions: for example, whether we should not be requiring greater consideration by potential married couples of the responsibilities of marriage. We have in law at the moment that under the banns of marriage concept there must be a delay of a month before the marriage can actually be carried through. One would suggest perhaps that while it is not practicable to talk about a compulsory system of counselling, nevertheless there is, quite clearly, a need for people from the time they are at school onwards-I do not think that is too early-to start to realise that it is no good going into marriage expecting that it will be the key to nirvana. Marriage, like any other contract in this world, needs two parties and they have got to work very hard at it to make it successful. I think there is a tendency to believe that marriage is easy to get into and there is a perception that it is equally easy to get out of. I think more effort needs to be made at the initial stage to make sure that prior to marriage people are much more aware of the implications of the decisions they are taking and that they are also aware of the legal constraints which will be upon them in terms of what their responsibilities will be for the maintenance of the children of that marriage. These are fundamentally important questions. Australia now has a birth rate of 0.8 per cent. In other words, we are not able even to keep up with our death rate. Yet we talk about a nation with a future. If it were not for immigration, the Australian population would be going backwards.

One of the fundamental reasons for the institution of marriage is not just friendship and the association between man and woman but the mechanism by which it is possible to bring children into the world and give them a reasonable status. Whether the relationship be de facto or de jure is a wider issue. The fundamental concern of this Parliament must be that we should not take legislation such as this purely in vacuo. It is not just a case of amending an existing Act, whatever its weaknesses may be. There is a need to look more deeply at the fundamental problems facing marriage today.

Why are so many families breaking up? What are the impacts on those children? What will be the ultimate social cost to this nation because of the failure of those marriages? Above all, what can we do through our social and economic policies, as well as through legal legislation such as the Family Law Act, to try to build an environment in which more marriages will succeed and, consequently, more children will be able to live in a happy and economically secure environment? As I said earlier, the biggest weakness in the Family Law Act today is that over 230,000 Australian children are now living either on or below the poverty line. We cannot allow that situation to continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
TALKER.ROLE: Attorney-General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all honour- able members for their contributions to the debate on the Family Law Amendment Bill 1987 and the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill 1987. It has been a debate of some length. Fifteen members have spoken. They have all mentioned the problems of the family and the problem of divorce, which is what this legislation basically is about. Many of the good speeches have been about preserving the family, but we have to have law for divorce. I do not want to criticise anybody who has spoken, but this is not the first time it has been suggested that family law legislation be sent to a committee. There was such a committee, the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act. The honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) was Chairman of it. I was on it. We sat for some time. We were looking at the problems of the Family Court of Australia. We furnished a report in 1980. It was able to identify some of the problems.

SPEECH.PARA: This evening we are in unanimity on the question of maintenance. It became very clear in those days that something had to be done. In 1980 the Committee recommended that something be done about maintenance. I say with the greatest of humility that I suggested to the Committee that one way to enforce maintenance orders would be through the tax deduction system. That may be introduced soon. I do not want it to be thought that anybody is criticising Senator Durack. We are not. It was felt early in the 1980s that something had to be done.

As the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) has just said-it may have been the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson)-over 220,000 people now receive some form of supporting parent's benefit. The statistics are not quite accurate. Some of those people are widows and, therefore, they should not be part of that total. But it is clear that about nine-tenths of them should. Is it any wonder that the Committee of which I was a member started to take interest in the matter? We were sitting during 1979. The cost had escalated by that stage from about $500m to $900m.

I say to the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), who is handling this matter on a non-party basis, that it was very obvious to me, even when I was in opposition, that something had to be done because, as I said, the figure had risen by then to $900m and was escalating. We were making recommendations on that basis. With the greatest of respect, by 1983-the dear old government of the day had been in office since 1975-the figure had gone up to $1,500m. We did not see any legislation, though, because the problem is difficult. But it is not a new problem. It is not a matter that needs to go to another committee which will say, `My God, what are we going to do now?'. Honourable members might not have known that somebody in the Department of Social Security produced a guideline so that we would not need to ask an applicant whether efforts had been made to collect maintenance. That was a real weakness. We do not need a committee to do that.

I can tell honourable members now that that guideline has been removed. In future, any applicant will be asked, `What about pursuing the maintenance route first?'. It was not habit. It was deemed to be out of fashion, even though that obligation was in the Social Security Act. I am saying to all honourable members, `We have not handled the passing of laws in this matter too well in this Parliament'. Even though we knew about the great leakage in the maintenance area we still have not done anything about it. This is not a criticism but it is not much good for honourable members opposite to suggest that a distinguished senator thought of it only recently. It was thought of in 1979 and 1980, a report was made and nothing was done. So it is unfair for the rest of the taxpayers to have to be weighing in $1.7 billion.

Honourable members all agree that this is a good approach. For the first time now there has been some suggestion that there should be support for dependants and this is what this legislation is about. I say that to honourable members with the greatest of confidence and I am sure that they will appreciate what I am saying. The big problem here this evening is that we are all agreeing on something but honourable members opposite are saying, `We still want to take it away and have a look at it'.

TALK.START.PARA: —We just want to read it. It is not asking for the world.

—With great respect, the worthy honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) had no difficulty comprehending within a week any legislation I introduced here and he did a brilliant job with it. I do not want to criticise the honourable member for Flinders, but he had not only the week but also my staff for four hours. If he does not understand the legislation now he should listen to me. We can encompass this debate very quickly this evening. We all know that there has been a massive haemorrhage in the maintenance area and nobody has done a thing about it until now. That is the important thing.
—It is a long time coming.

—I agree; since 1978. How about that? The next question is a reference of powers. The distinguished honourable member for Dundas got up and said, `It must go to a committee because, obviously, if it has been simmering for 11 years, it must be important. Because it has taken 11 years to get here we had better have another look at it'. The reason it took 11 years to get here is that the States would not give it to us. In 1975-76 I was at a constitutional convention where we passed motions stating this very fundamental thing: `Why can we not look after ex-nuptial children that are part of a marriage partnership, even though they are not necessarily the children of both partners?'. Do honourable members think the States will give us that power? Even now I can get it from only four States. So what is the great concern about the 11 years? The concern is that the States will not hand over the power. In Queensland we have the ridiculous situation where an unfortunate child, who is not part of a marriage, cannot be dealt with under the Family Law Act. Tonight nobody is criticising the fact that at least some States have shown an initiative. I want to congratulate the Tasmanian Attorney-General. At least he has said, `Let us be sensible about this thing'-that is, the reference of powers. Those are the two fundamental matters.

SPEECH.PARA: When some of the speeches that were made with a fair amount of eloquence go over the air waves it will cause no end of trouble to this poor unfortunate Court. I am not criticising honourable members but it has been said that the Court is a failure and there is something wrong with it. These judges who have had to bear the brunt of this for 11 years were established in premises that most often were not courts. I have had to build courts in Parramatta, Brisbane and Newcastle in a very short time. I am trying to get a site in Sydney. Honourable members may ask why. It is because people from the Sydney Court have been out in the street 25 times this year because of bomb threats. As honourable members know, one judge has been murdered and the wife of another judge has been murdered. We have this enormous heat where everybody who goes into the building obviously is concerned about this issue which all honourable members have identified; that is, the anger and revenge of dissolution. Everyone who goes into these buildings is body searched. It is costing millions of dollars for security. There is no need for honourable members to tell these judges that they are failures. They are not real happy about it. They are sitting in premises that are not good; the staff are threatening strikes.

Honourable members opposite have to recognise the fact that at least these members of the legal profession have accepted the difficulty of being Family Court judges and are working very hard indeed in this very difficult jurisdiction. To their credit-and this applies to the counsellors as well-94 per cent of people dealt with solve their own troubles. We are dealing with the remaining 6 per cent. So there is not a failure in terms of what we are trying to do for people. The problem is that some people, in their own terms, will not accept the fact that there will be a breakup of the marriage on terms that are unacceptable to them. They will accept a breakup if they get the children and the property; they will not accept it any other way. Honourable members opposite have identified this problem.

We in this Parliament passed the Family Law Act on a non-party basis. We took the approach that if there is a breakdown one files for a dissolution-and that is what people do. So, in my view, the concept of family in respect of the Family Court has misled these people; it is the divorce court and the document has been filed. But some people do not understand that. They may hold the view that, if someone has left them and they feel they have done nothing wrong, they should get the children and the house. That is where the anger builds up. They do not understand our view of the law-that one party can say that a marriage has broken down and therefore there will be a separation. They will not accept that. That is why we have all the anger and heat.

I will tell honourable members my own point of view. I think it would be an excellent idea if before too long we set up mediation centres to which these parties go along and first discuss their problems and then file for dissolution. I am impressed with Noble Park-which I have seen once-because it is attached to a court, Dandenong Court. If we want to talk about what we should be doing in the future, perhaps we ought to be saying: `Before you start your dissolution, let us get you to a mediation centre where there could be some marriage guidance or discussion as to what will happen with the children. You will talk across a table. You will not have this problem of having to litigate the situation-of getting in the witness box and being examined and cross-examined while the lawyers are there using their skills'. This litigation does not help these people. Bearing in mind that we are dealing with only 6 or 7 per cent of people, I think this idea has a lot of merit and it will save us a lot of money. It will take money to establish these centres, but I would think that that would be a much more constructive position to take the heat off these judges.

Honourable members opposite should not regard them as failures. We would be the failures if, while talking about families, we were not able to understand what a family needs when it is under pressure-and it does not need litigation. It needs conciliation and mediation. Maybe we could get the marriage guidance groups to join in the mediation centres so that people could go there at an early stage and talk about their problems. I think that is the point. We could talk here about this legislation until we are blue in the face about this. I just want to say this: it is also known-and this is no criticism of the present judges-that the most talented members of the legal profession will go nowhere near being appointed to the Family Court because they regard it as having no more law in it. They will not be saddled with this threat to their lives or those of their families by people who feel that they have not had justice. The whole concept has lost its importance in the minds of some people with marriage problems; they think the Family Court in somewhere they can go and have a discussion-and it is not; it is the divorce court.

What we are doing tonight is really non-contentious. Honourable members opposite all agree with the fact that we are going to collect maintenance from those who should pay. Surely they would all agree that the ex-nuptial child should be dealt with--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the presumption?

—I will save the best until last. The point I want to make is this: I was anxious to lift the status of this Court. I have spent an enormous amount of time talking to the Federal Court of Australia judges about whether there could be a meld. They say no, for reasons that we will not go into at any length here, but they are concerned about having judges who can cope with a number of other matters. Honourable members opposite know that as well as I do. So this Court has been orphaned off; it is subject to all the abuse and all the wrong media. It is working very hard indeed in an area that is a no-win situation. I can understand why the judges are concerned and why the legal profession does not want to be involved.

SPEECH.PARA: If we give the judges an additional jurisdiction, such as bankruptcy, taxation or trade practices, which is remitted by the Federal Court, some of the judges would say `I'd love it' and some would say `I can't do it; I'm no good at that'. That is fine, it would not go to those who cannot do it. But at least it would be a start in giving the Family Court status somewhere near that of the Federal Court so it is not deemed to be something that is so inferior, because it is deemed to be a failure-though it is not-that nobody wants to be associated with it. That is the rationale behind trying to say, `If we can get the right sort of people on the Bench, people with wider skills, they will do first-class Federal Court work'. The Federal Court is a top court. It is one of the best courts in Australia. That is because of the people on the Bench and the way in which they are able to handle the business. The Jackson report on the Australian Judicial System-Jackson was a member of the Federal Court at the time-talked about renovating the Court, building it up and making it acceptable in terms of it being able to do other work.

A lot of progress has been made in educating people to look after their own troubles. Figures which I have before me show that in 1986 about 33 per cent of people appearing before the Court appeared for themselves. That was a good effort. They did not need the lawyers; they had probably solved most of their troubles. That is the way the Western Australian Family Court operates. Mr Justice Barblett uses the concept of pre-trial conferences. About 60 per cent of people before the Court in Western Australia appear in person. The other point I make is that if two parties can solve their troubles, they should be dealt with speedily rather than being put to the difficulty of having to file documents and wait their turn in the problem areas which I have outlined-such as being searched as they enter the premises. Why should they go through all that when the matter could be dealt with by consent at the court of summary jurisdiction? Such a system would also give people in the bush a chance to have their matter dealt with more quickly as they would not have to wait for the often infrequent circuit court sittings.

It has been said, quite unfairly, that magistrates are the lowest card in the pack and why would we let people go to a magistrate. Let us look at the work that the magistrate is now doing. He or she is dealing with 85 per cent of all maintenance cases now, as well as domestic violence cases. He or she deals with all the issues--

TALK.START.PARA: —Paternity.

—Yes, even paternity. We should not be saying that the magistrates court is the wrong place to go. Magistrates might have more knowledge of a particular family than anyone else. For instance, a magistrate could have dealt with a family in cases involving domestic violence, truancy, juvenile delinquency, interim maintenance and even interim custody. Surely he should be able to deal with these matters when the parties say, `We are happy about the situation; we merely want to put evidence before you that there has been an irretrievable breakdown'. I do not know that magistrates would want to take on that jurisdiction readily, but if it is able to be arranged with the States why should they not do so? They are doing so now; they are dealing with most maintenance cases.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank honourable members for their contributions. The honourable member for North Sydney, as usual, raised a couple of interesting matters. I am happy to say that I think we have an answer for him which probably he will not be too happy about. The honourable member gave the example of a man who had cohabited with a woman for 10 months before the birth of a child, but the woman's subsequent cohabitation with a different man led to the conception of a child and the first man thought that it was not right that he be presumed to be the father. I know that the honourable member is a married man and understands all the problems, but they tell me that sometimes people get the dates wrong. I know that the honourable member's precise legal mind says `You can't have a variation in this', but you can. Somebody might muck up the first day and, also, a baby might not readily come down at the time one wants it to come down. Sometimes babies delay their arrival for four weeks. If the honourable member has that right, we have solved the problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell him to stick to the law, hey!

—Yes, it would be better to stick to the law. The honourable member for North Sydney also raised the issue of a conscientious objection to undergoing a medical test procedure. I am advised that under proposed new section 66w (5), the court may draw inferences from the failure to undertake a medical procedure. The court is also able to accept other evidence which would refute any such inference that may be drawn from the failure to undertake the medical procedure.

SPEECH.PARA: This evening I have been trying to approach this matter on a non-party basis. If anybody ever wants the job of Attorney-General, I will tell him that he will spend most of his time dealing with issues relating to the Family Law Act and the problems of the Family Law Court. This is not because there is anything wrong with what we have, but because it is not complete enough. What we have is not complete enough when we look at it from the point of view of custody in particular. It might be far better if the issue of custody were continually reviewed by some sort of group that would determine whether a child is neglected, and that has happened. Sometimes when judges are forced into making a decision they can make it the wrong way. Problems can be caused if a party tries to beat the system by moving the children to another State. I think we can solve the problems in respect of maintenance if this legislation is passed and enforced.

In terms of custody, I remember a High Court judge saying that it is always interesting that the people who fight the hardest are the ones who love their children the most. They fight because they do not want to part with them. Luckily the children grow up and make their own decisions. But we are dealing with a small group of 6 or 7 per cent. This legislation will certainly help the court and it will not hinder the litigants.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Attorney's time has expired.
—Give him a few more minutes.
—It has been suggested that the Minister's time be extended.
—I think I have spoken for long enough.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I echo what was said by the Opposition. It was a most interesting speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DAWKINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

On 22 September 1987 I released the guidelines to the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission (CTEC) for 1988. The Commission responded with detailed recommendations on higher education. I now table the Commission's report Higher Education Recommendations for 1988. The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill 1987 has been prepared following consideration of the Commission's recommendations. It also gives effect to the Government's Budget decisions on Commonwealth assistance for technical and further education (TAFE) in 1988. The purpose of the Bill is to provide the legislative basis for the distribution of Commonwealth funds for tertiary education in the States and the Northern Territory for 1988. A total of $2,708.1m will be legislated for.

As I explained to the House when I delivered my statement on higher education on 22 September, the Government is treating 1988 as a year outside the normal funding process. This deferment of the next funding triennium will enable the Government to reassess the overall direction of higher education policy and to develop new funding programs to take effect from the beginning of the 1989 academic year. The Bill provides $2,423.8m for the higher education sector for 1988. This represents an increase of 2 per cent in real terms on the previous year. The allocation of additional resources reflects the Government's resolve to increase participation, particularly among young people, and to make the higher education system more responsive to the needs of the national economy.

The Government has accepted the Commission's recommendations on the detailed allocation of student places and financial resources with one exception. The Commission had recommended that planning funds be provided in 1988 for the proposed relocation of the Sydney College of the Arts and the rationalisation of facilities at the Western Australian College of Advanced Education and the University of Western Australia. However, this recommendation made no provision for a firm forward commitment of funds against these projects. The Government agrees that these projects should proceed and they will be supported within the future Commonwealth capital programs. In these circumstances, the $500,000 `planning' funds recommended by CTEC will not be required and will be used to support a student residence project at the Darling Downs Institute of Advanced Education, which is important for future student growth.
Key features of the allocation of higher education funds for 1988 are:
An additional $23m in general recurrent grants to fund an extra 3,500 to 4,000 intakes for school leavers;
An increase in capital grants of $12m to allow for the continuation of 35 projects and the commencement of 13 new major works projects;
An additional $3m in equipment grants;

The redirection of $5m from general recurrent grants to universities to fund an expansion of special research centres and key centres of teaching and research as well as targeted research activities in the advanced education sector; and
Unallocated amounts totalling $42.7m for equity projects, superannuation and the special assistance scheme for students to be distributed after further advice from CTEC.

In arriving at its funding decisions for 1988 the Government has been conscious also of the need for effective forward planning of physical facilities to support expected future growth in enrolments. Accordingly, since the Budget, it has examined further the likely capital needs of higher education over the next few years, and decided that the higher level of capital funding approved for 1988 should be maintained into 1989 and 1990. This measure will not only add significantly to the funds available for new capital projects in 1989 and 1990, but should also assist institutions in the longer-term planning of their future capital programs. Subject to appropriate agreements with the States concerned, the two projects deferred from the 1988 capital program recommended by CTEC will have first call upon the additional capital funds to be made available in 1989. Further commitments against these funds will be made during 1988 following completion of the Government's Policy Discussion Paper on Higher Education and the satisfactory resolution of the issues raised in the paper.

The Bill also provides $284.3m for expenditure on TAFE programs. As announced in Skills for Australia, the Government believes that considerable restructuring of Commonwealth grants for TAFE is required to meet a number of objectives, including:
Further increases in vocational education and training and an expansion of total training capacity;
Improvements in the relevance of TAFE provision;
Productivity improvements and efficiency gains in the use of existing resources;
Greater industry involvement in TAFE;
An enhancement of the labour market prospects of the unemployed and other disadvantaged groups, especially among the young.

Under new funding arrangements set out in this Bill to apply from 1 January 1988, the Government will continue to place a strong emphasis on the national development of technical and further education, through both an infra- structure and a general recurrent program. The existing capital grants, special equipment and minor works and equipment for traineeships programs will be combined into a single TAFE infrastructure program. An amount of $174.8m is provided for this purpose in 1988.
The existing fees reimbursement and designated purpose recurrent grants are largely replaced by a general recurrent program which will be subject to resource agreements with the States covering:
A commitment to pursue improvements in productivity in 1988;
Agreed target growth rates in designated courses of high priority to meet skill shortages, equity objectives, or of strategic importance to future economic development; and
Changes in administrative arrangements to enable TAFE colleges to retain revenues from entrepreneurial effort.

An amount of $103.1m is provided under this program in 1988. Achievements against program objectives will be subject to regular monitoring and evaluation. The level of funds to be provided to the States for TAFE in 1989 and future years under the general recurrent program will be dependent on achievements in 1988, particularly in relation to productivity. Three existing special purpose programs for which funds are currently available under the designated grants programs are to be maintained. Grants for advanced English language courses for migrants will continue to be administered by the Commonwealth, as will the allowance paid to participants in such courses. Grants for adult literacy and for non-government adult education will be maintained and rolled in with funding to be allocated under the national language policy for adult literacy purposes. A total of $6.4m is provided for these programs in 1988. The processes of allocating these grants will be reviewed during the year. The Bill also provides for continuing Commonwealth assistance to non-government business colleges.

This Bill gives effect to the Government's decision to permit a limited relaxation of the prohibition on fees in higher education and TAFE in 1988 and beyond. Higher education institutions will be able to seek my approval to charge fees for specialised post-graduate award courses catering for students already in employment who are seeking to upgrade their vocational skills and income. The Government's decision has been taken in response to requests from sections of the higher education community itself and there will be no compulsion on institutions to charge these fees for these courses. The revenue raised by this measure will be retained by the institutions concerned, and the Commonwealth will not reduce its grants on account of revenue generated from these fees. Institutions will also be able to exempt certain students or categories of student from the payment of the fees.

Similarly, the relaxation of the TAFE fees prohibition is not intended to affect the great majority of TAFE courses which involve the initial acquisition of skills by young people. It is intended to apply to courses undertaken for the purpose of upgrading skills and income by students well established in employment. The aim of this new provision is to provide a further basis for industry and individual contributions without threat to the public financing of TAFE. The Government will not reduce the level of the general recurrent grants on account of any fees revenue generated under these arrangements. Incorporated in the Bill are the changes made to the higher education administration charge which were announced in the Budget. The categories of needy students exempt from the charge have been extended. These further exemptions cover almost 9,000 students, which will bring to around 139,000, or almost 35 per cent, the number of students who will be exempt from, or reimbursed for, the charge in 1988. The Bill has been tightened to make students withdrawing from a course after teaching has commenced liable for the charge. In line with the Government's commitment not to increase the charge beyond the effects of inflation, the charge will rise from $250 to $263 in 1988.

In its latest report CTEC has reiterated its views on a number of topical issues in higher education, including those publicised in its recent Press release on portfolio advisory arrangements and structures. The Government's position on these issues was set out in my statement of 15 October 1987 announcing the findings of the task force chaired by Mr Charles Halton. As I foreshadowed at that time, an extensive process of consultation is now under way with interested parties, and I expect to announce final decisions on the new advisory framework towards the end of the year. The Government welcomes the very positive reaction to its proposals to date and notes that the views expressed in the CTEC report are sharply at odds with majority opinion. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Porter) adjourned.
