The main purposes of this Bill are to amend the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act 1984 to implement decisions in the recent Budget on Commonwealth programs for schools in 1988 and to supplement for cost increases grants already appropriated for schools programs.

There are detailed appropriations in the Bill for specific purpose and capital programs for government and non-government schools in each State and the Northern Territory. The principal Act already contains the per capita grants under the general recurrent program for government and non-government schools for the period 1985-88. This comprehensive long term program continues to provide authorities with stability and security in the planning of school operations.

Most programs are being maintained at the same real level as in 1987 while a few will increase in real terms. The general recurrent grants program will increase by an estimated 4.8 per cent in real terms to $1,339m. The per capita amount for the new arrivals element of the English as a second language program has been doubled and the special education program will receive an additional $0.7m in 1988 for the support services element. Funding of the participation and equity program and basic learning in primary schools program will not continue beyond the end of 1987 in accordance with the period set for those programs.

The Bill also provides for the full implementation of block grant funding arrangements under the non-government schools element of the capital grants program. The legislation was amended earlier this year to provide for the approval of block grant authorities. These amendments will enable capital grants for non-government schools in 1988 and subsequent years to be allocated as a block grant for distribution by approved block grant authorities. Block grant arrangements, by providing greater involvement by school authorities in the delivery of the capital grants program, offer an enhanced capacity for the achievement of Commonwealth objectives. The Government is not, however, forcing schools to join block grant authorities. Non-government schools which do not wish to participate in block funding arrangements will be able to compete for funds from a national pool in a similar way to existing arrangements.

There are also several amendments of a minor nature. Firstly, benefits under the English as a second language program and ethnic schools program are being restricted to students having permanent resident status. Established administrative practice has restricted benefits in that way but an amendment is required to put beyond doubt the authority for doing so.

Secondly, an amendment provides for the inclusion in the Act of a definition of a `full fee paying private overseas secondary student' that had been made by regulation. Definition by regulation was an interim arrangement pending full incorporation in the Act.

The financial impact of this Bill will be to appropriate an estimated $1739m for 1988 programs and an additional $9m for 1987 programs. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (EDUCATION ASSISTANCE-PARTICIPATION AND EQUITY) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DAWKINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1987 seeks to amend the Student Assistance Act 1973, which is the legislative basis for the provision of student assistance under Austudy and for the grant of post-graduate awards. The proposed amendment to section 10 of the Act relates to the range of institutions at which courses are approved for Austudy. Approved institutions currently include secondary schools, technical and further education colleges, colleges of advanced education, universities and a limited number of tertiary institutions in the private sector providing courses funded by the Commonwealth. These private tertiary institutions mainly comprise denominational teacher training colleges and certain business colleges.

The Bill responds to a decision of the Federal Court of Australia in Darwin earlier this year, in a certain case, which established that students attending the University College of the Northern Territory could be regarded, for Austudy purposes, as undertaking study at the University of Queensland-by virtue of an agreement between the two institutions under which the university, for a fee, allows the college to teach the university's courses. The amendment is needed because the wide interpretation the Court has given to section 10 opens the way to a range of wholly private institutions-including private universities, academies of dance and art, cooking schools, chiropractic colleges, receptionist and beauty colleges and non-approved business colleges-to gain access to Austudy contractually, by-passing ministerial screening. The decision also enables those private sector institutions that have gained Austudy approval for certain of their courses to expand their Austudy offering.

Section 10 allows the Minister discretion to approve or revoke approval of courses. The proposed amendment will allow a further discretion to determine the particular institutions in the private sector which are not appropriate institutions for Austudy purposes. The discretion would be exercised where institutions that have made contractual arrangements seek Austudy approval of a course. It is not intended that this discretion should be exercised so as to deny Austudy to students who currently benefit under contractual arrangements. Students at the University College of the Northern Territory will not therefore be affected. An amendment is being sought to the Student Assistance Regulations to classify the college as a `university' for the purposes of the Act, thus allowing the college equal standing with universities in the States, and the right to seek Austudy approval of any course that it may wish to offer independent of the University of Queensland.

Where teaching arrangements are shared between public-funded and private institutions, it will continue to be possible for the courses concerned to be considered for Austudy assistance. Non-government secondary schools will not be affected, since those that currently have State or Territory teaching certification are, and will continue to be, approved for Austudy in their own right. As the law now stands, an ever-increasing flow of Austudy funds into private sector tertiary institutions must be expected. Although the financial implications for the Commonwealth are not at this stage quantifiable, they will become significant. The proposed amendment is needed to restore to the Commonwealth the right to determine those institutions where Austudy should be provided and to maintain existing Austudy policy that limits the provision of Austudy to students undertaking courses that are wholly or substantially funded from public sources, whether Commonwealth, State or Territory. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Porter) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mountford Mr J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Procedure, I present the first report of the Committee entitled Improved Opportunities for Private Members: Proposed Sessional Orders, together with the minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This report, the first report of the Procedure Committee for the Thirty-fifth Parliament, recommends the adoption of sessional orders which will have a significant effect on the House and will substantially enhance the role of private members. In particular, the sessional orders proposed provide for:

SPEECH.PARA: The allocation of at least 1 1/2 hours to private members' business every Thursday morning;
A grievance debate of 1 1/4 hours be held every Thursday;
The allocation of 15 minutes to members' 90-second statements each Thursday;
Revised procedures for the presentation of petitions; and
The allocation of a set time for the presentation and consideration of parliamentary committee and delegation reports.

There are other proposals that I will refer to shortly but, first, let me refer briefly to the background to the proposals. In May 1986 the Procedure Committee's second report, Days and hours of sitting and the effective use of the time of the House, was presented to the House. A motion to take note of the report was debated in November 1986 and, following discussion with the Committee earlier this year, the Leader of the House (Mr Young) tabled the Government's response to the second report on 15 September. The Government accepted some of the recommendations of the second report, accepted some with modifications and rejected others. This, the report I have just tabled, recommends that the House adopt a set of sessional orders prepared within the framework of the Government's response to the earlier report.

The most significant recommendations concern an altered routine of business on Thursday mornings. I draw the attention of honourable members to the diagram at page 8 of the report which sets out the proposed routine of business from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. each Thursday. The routine, following prayers, is the presentation of petitions, the presentation and consideration of committee and delegation reports, private members' business, grievance debate and members' statements.
Petitions

It is proposed that the announcement of petitions lodged for presentation be made on Thursdays only. The announcement will include the aggregate number of signatories to each petition and it will be the responsibility of each member to certify the numbers of signatures contained in the petition. There are a number of other changes proposed to the petitions procedure and I direct the attention of honourable members to the detailed notes in Appendix I of the report.
Committee and Delegation Reports

As recommended by the Committee in its report into days and hours of sitting, it is proposed that a set time be set aside each week for the presentation and consideration of committee and parliamentary delegation reports. It is proposed that, following the presentation of petitions each Thursday, this item of business will have precedence up until 11 a.m. The order of presentation and consideration will be determined by the proposed selection committee and members presenting reports and one other committee or delegation member will be accorded priority in making statements.

Following the presentation of reports orders of the day for the consideration of reports presented earlier will be called upon for consideration. Should there be a limited number of reports or no reports set down for presentation and consideration, the House would proceed to private members' business.
Private Members' Business

The most significant changes proposed are the improved procedures for private members' business. These are the ones that will be of interest to honourable members. Private members will be allocated 1 1/2 hours every sitting Thursday for consideration of motions and Bills. This compares very favourably to the 1 hour 15 minutes currently allocated to General Business each alternate Thursday.

The order and timetabling of business will be determined by a selection committee composed of 11 backbench members who, it is proposed, will be experienced members who enjoy the confidence of their peers. The general principles the selection committee adopts for the according of priority to items of business will be subject to adoption by the House and it is proposed that the order of precedence and times allotted to debate on each item will be published on the Notice Paper on the first sitting of each week. For the information of members, the selection criteria adopted by the Canadian House of Commons Standing Committee on Private Members' Business is appended to the report.

It may well be that certain motions will be allotted only limited time for debate and this could well be in accord with the wishes of the sponsor and the House generally. Other motions or Bills may be debated over a number of Thursdays. Could I point out that if a Bill passes the second reading it is proposed that the remaining stages will take precedence over other private members' business. For the purpose of these sessional orders a private member is any member other than a Minister and the Speaker. As explained in the report, this Committee expects that the general principles adopted by the selection committee for the allocation of precedence will include the principles that priority be allocated in accordance with party strength and that the Opposition executive or any individuals do not dominate. In other words, the Opposition executive will just have to take its chances with the rest of us.

Details of the procedures are set out in the report but could I point out that one provision novel to this chamber is the proposal that divisions called for in the House, unless upon a motion moved by a Minister, will stand postponed until 12.30 p.m. It is hoped that this provision will enable members and Ministers to plan their Thursday morning duties knowing that they will have a division free morning. Another provision that is novel to this chamber is contained in sessional order 102d. The Committee was concerned that members rising on controversial yet legitimate issues might be subjected to disruptive tactics. It is therefore proposed that the Chair be given certain discretionary powers to deal with these situations.
Grievance Debate and Members' Statements

At the suggestion of the Government, grievance debate has been retained and it is now proposed that it be held every sitting Thursday rather than on alternate Thursdays, as is the current practice. Again, this is a significant gain for private members. Members' statements will be called on following the conclusion of grievance debate and will conclude prior to Question Time at 2 o'clock. The practice of members having the opportunity to make short statements to the House for a set time each sitting has been a feature of the proceedings of the Canadian House of Commons since 1982. I trust that the procedure will be as popular here as it is in Canada. It is proposed that members may make statements for not more than 90 seconds on matters of concern and importance during the 15-minute period prior to Question Time. The Committee's views on the operation of the procedure are set out in detail in the report.

In its recommendations, the Committee has proposed that the revised procedures for Thursday mornings operate from the second sitting week of 1988. It is therefore proposed that the selection committee be established quickly to enable this to occur.
Matters of Public Importance and Reading Speeches

There are recommendations in this report to alter the public importance procedure and to reimpose a prohibition on reading speeches in the House as earlier recommended by the Committee. In its response the Government stated it was not opposed to the altered procedures for matters of public importance but would be influenced by the Opposition's reaction to the proposal.

The Government considers the question of reading speeches to be one on which members should be free to express an opinion. The Committee of the last Parliament believed that the prohibition on reading speeches would improve the standard of debate in the House. In the sessional order proposed there are certain exceptions to the rule and I direct members' attention to these in proposed sessional order 62.

The Government has made it clear to the Procedure Committee that the implementation of the changes will be on trial and subject to review in the light of experience in the new Parliament House. This Committee also will be monitoring their operation closely.

Before concluding, I thank all members who served on the Committee in this and the preceding Parliament. I especially mention Len Keogh, the former chairman. These reforms, if implemented, will in no small measure be a tribute to his patience and perseverance. I would also like to thank the secretariat, particularly Mr McRae, the secretary, for expert assistance, and the Clerk and other officers of the House for the work they performed in drafting the sessional orders for the Committee.

Finally, I thank the Leader of the House for the support he has given the Committee in his willingness to support such significant changes to private members' opportunities. I urge all members to put the interests of the House first and give the new procedures a fair go. I believe the potential for future reform rests in the successful adoption of these changes. I thank the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As Deputy Chairman of the Standing Committee on Procedure, I join with the Chairman in recognising the contribution of the former member for Bowman, Mr Keogh, who, until the last election, was responsible, as Chairman, for the progress that was made. I will be very frank: when I was appointed to the Committee I was extremely cynical in that I believed that no government had the capacity to agree to change in any area such as this; but I have been proven incorrect. I also acknowledge the co-operation and even to a degree the assistance and guidance of the Leader of the House (Mr Young). It is a pity he is not in this chamber to hear me saying something pleasant about him for a change.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has recommended reform. Some of the recommendations are simply waiting for approval by the Parliament. I guess that some recommendations will cause some controversy. The recommendation of the abolition of reading speeches in this chamber will cause some heartburn and probably some opposition. I clearly recall my maiden speech, which I did read. I am glad I was able to read it. Perhaps some of the speeches I have made since then would have been better had I read them. But the reality is that the homespun speech, the one that is made extempore, is more of a speech that should be part of this place. I assure those honourable members who spend their lives dotting the i's and crossing the t's so that Hansard looks good that if they think that Hansard is one of the nation's best read publications, they are totally wrong. The only people who ever read Hansard or the speeches of any of us in here will probably be our grandchildren, who will reach for the Hansard to find out what grandpa or grandma was really like. That would probably be the extent of it. I say to those who are fearful of the proposal, `Be brave. March forward'.

TALK.START.PARA: —But I read your speeches.

—The honourable member for Barker reads my speeches. He gets some of his greatest inspiration from reading my speeches. My view is that the Chairman of the Committee has really left very little unsaid in outlining this report. I recommend it to the entire Parliament. I thank the Clerks, and the former members of the Committee who were fallen soldiers at the last election. They included not only the former member for Bowman, Mr Keogh, but we also had a QC on our Committee-none other than the former member for Denison, Mr Hodgman. The other night his ghost came back to haunt us when, for some reason, some proposal that we had dismissed a couple of years ago as being impractical was reintroduced. It concerned the approval of legislation by the Senate and the Governor-General, and that was on its way; but just through quickness of mind someone retrieved that legislation only three or four nights ago.

SPEECH.PARA: Very few members of the public would have any reason to wonder about it, but the number of hours that would have been put into the work of the three reports would probably be well into the hundreds. Meetings were held in Sydney and here at Parliament House, sometimes late at night and early in the morning, to get this job done. I congratulate the Government for its rare display of generosity and for being open-minded. I am positive that the title of the report, which is Improved Opportunities for Private Members, will be a reality. I suggest that this Parliament is probably on the verge of becoming the most generous parliament in Australia in terms of the rights which it extends to non-government members. That is a step in the right direction and I hope that it is an example that will be followed--

TALK.START.PARA: —You mean non-ministerial members, not non-government members.

—`Non-government' means that one forgets about the Ministers, which is quite pleasant for four hours of the week; it makes it more worthwhile. I hope that the example we are setting in the Federal Parliament will be followed by the State parliaments, because I am led to believe that in some of those institutions unless one is a government member one has absolutely no rights whatsoever. What we have done is an example to everyone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I want to dwell on the matter which my colleague the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) spoke to. I have spoken about this before. I make no secret of the fact that when it suits me in this chamber I shall read speeches. I shall read speeches because, given the time made available to us by the Government to speak in this chamber, it is very often necessary to prepare thoroughly for speeches in this place. To get them out and to get the points made in the time that is available to us as backbenchers it is necessary to prepare thoroughly. I concede to the honourable member for Moreton, and to my colleagues on either side of the chamber, that they may be able to make the points they want to make on complex legislation within the speaking time of 20 minutes which is allowed in general debate. I do not have that ability and, I suggest, most honourable members do not have that ability either.

SPEECH.PARA: If Ministers, with all the resources that are available to them to prepare and present their case, came into this place and made their second reading speeches off the cuff, I would happily come into this place and debate them on the same basis. The truth is that that is not the case. Given the erosion of and intrusion into members' speaking time, it is a nonsense to propose that we should cop the suggestion that we should not read our speeches.

On occasions in this chamber matters are of such complexity that we need to refer either to written speeches or copious notes. Having been a Western Australian senator, which I am very proud of, I know of the charade that goes on in the other place where a similar standing order exists that there shall be no reading of speeches. Senators cop the plea-it is not quite the fifth amendment-when they are challenged by senators opposite, or occasionally by your equivalent in the chair, Mr Deputy Speaker, that they are reading from copious notes whereas, in fact, they are reading from prepared speeches.

It is all very well for the Government to say, `We support this proposal; it is a great idea, because reading speeches might detract from the quality of debate in this place'. I suggest that no honourable member could debate, logically and in detail, complex legislation such as the tax Bills that are coming up or those that have been debated in the recent past. It is a fact that honourable members need to refer to notes and to prepare thoroughly. Mr Deputy Speaker, if you, I, or other members do not prepare thoroughly, we might as well not start because we cannot contribute to government legislation, we cannot criticise it and, even if we disagree with it, we cannot contribute in a way which will enhance it and eliminate errors. If I get the opportunity to debate a particular omnibus Bill which is coming before the Parliament very soon I will point out that it is impossible, in debating legislation which amends 87 separate Bills and repeals 24 other Bills, to make a sound contribution unless one is thoroughly prepared and that preparation, in large or small part, should take the form of a written presentation.

I will never accept the proposition that members in this place cannot read their speeches. Mr Deputy Speaker, I suggest to you that if such a standing order were introduced it would be subject to the same abuse and it would place the same terrible decision-making onus on the Chair as it does in the Senate-the other chamber in which I was proud to serve. The day that that happens it will make your job and my job impossible. I know that I should be in the chair. I am sorry to have to make you sit there for another five, six or eight minutes, but I will correct that in a moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —One minute.
—The Whip, who is standing over me, tells me that I have one minute. There must be some arrangement. It will be an impossible situation if that condition is imposed on members in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: I happen not to be reading right now. I can talk and waffle for 20 minutes. I suspect that I am starting to do that now so I will sit down shortly. But that is the very thing that happens. Members who have not prepared, pad their speeches, muck around and fill them up with all sorts of inconsequential nonsense. They play the political game when making speeches in second reading debates and they forget about the legislation. That occurs for a whole range of reasons that I will not go into tonight, but I will do so, if I get the opportunity, on the omnibus Bill which I mentioned earlier.

I strenuously oppose this nonsense. My former colleagues in the Senate and some of my colleagues on either side of this chamber have said that if people cannot debate legislation off the cuff they are not worth their salt. That is a load of rubbish. First and foremost we are legislators and, secondly, we are politicians. We play the political game in this chamber but it is overemphasised because of a certain attitude in this place. Because a government-whichever government it happens to be-has the numbers in this place we tend to play the political game. This is a political chamber. It has become less and less of a legislative chamber for a number of reasons which, again, I need not go into. I do not intend to add my name to these proponents of making it worse than it already is. This should equally be a legislative chamber as is the Senate. I think we are going too far with this sort of nonsense. It is nonsense and I will never support it.
Ordered that consideration of the report be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

DEBATE.TITLE: TELEVISION LICENCE FEES AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1987[COGNATE BILLS:RADIO LICENCE FEES AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987BROADCASTING AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1987]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 October, on motion by Mr Duncan:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Television Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987 concurrently with the Radio Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 and the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1987. There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is pleasing finally to get the call to discuss some very important legislation. Whilst I realise that honourable members regard the procedures of this House as also being important, I think that the public of Australia should hear during the broadcast of the proceedings of this chamber just how incompetent the Government is in terms of broadcast policy. It is interesting to note that there are actually more ministerial advisers in the chamber than there are Government members. The benches are nearly empty-and well they might be, because Government members are all embarrassed about the Government's incompetence and about its inconsistent, inequitable and rapidly changing policies in this area of broadcasting.

SPEECH.PARA: We have three Bills before the House tonight-the Television Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 3), the Radio Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 4). The Broadcasting Amendment Bill represents the complete abandonment of a measure announced in the Budget. When the Budget came down the Government said, `We will auction new radio licences'. The Budget came down in September of this year. It is now early November and the Government has abandoned that proposal-that is how well thought out it was. Another Bill we have before us tonight is the Radio Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 2). That provides for conversion fees for the change from AM licences to FM licences. In the Budget the Government said that the fee would be 30 per cent of gross annual revenues. The Bill before us tonight provides for 50 per cent-another change on the Budget. The third Bill relates to television licence fees. As is symptomatic of this Government's approach to everything, it proposes to increase the revenue that is to be gained from television licences. No wonder this Government has increased its revenue by 75 per cent in five years.

Let me briefly run through the major provisions of these Bills before I address the Opposition's views on them in some detail. As I said, the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 4) abandons a measure announced in the Budget-evidence of the Government's deep thought on its broadcast policy. It made a statement in its Budget; about eight weeks later it is out the window. It is out the window because of factional problems and because someone told the Government that there would actually be some problems in going ahead with the auctioning of these licences. The Bill sets up establishment fees, which are approximately 100 per cent of gross revenue for radio stations. It is evidence of the appalling administrative capacity of this Government. The proposal for auctioning the licences was in itself retrospective. The change, again, is retrospective because some people who have made application for these licences did so on the basis that there would not be an auction or an establishment fee.

Later in this debate the Opposition will move an amendment to the second reading motion which has been circulated in my name. We will also seek leave to suspend so much of Standing Orders as would prevent my referring this entire Bill to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure-because it is about time that someone gave some serious consideration to the implications of what the Government is trying to do in communications. Government members are not allowed to do so in Caucus. Every time Caucus has a good talk about the matter someone waltzes in and says, `Listen boys, we know what is going on in this country. We are running the Australian Labor Party. You are just here to make up the numbers. You come in when the bells ring and vote, because that is all you are good for. We who are running the place run the show and you do not have a right to make any contribution'.

In fact, it will be very difficult for some members of the Labor Party even to get the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) to make a reference on communication to the various House standing committees, because the last thing this Government wants is a decent inquiry into communications policy-and we all know why. We know what the views of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) are. We know what he said around the Cabinet table, because some members of Cabinet who were at that table leaked what he said. We know whom the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) goes fishing with on occasion. We know exactly what is going on in the Labor Party. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) recently made reference to the embarrassment caused to those genuine members of the Labor Party by the preparedness of some sections of their party to fawn over the so-called wealthy people in our community.

At the committee stage of this debate we will move amendments to exempt four applicants for new licences-applicants for licences on the Gold Coast, at Gosford, at Geelong and at Shepparton. We will be doing that because these people prepared their applications in good faith on the basis that there would not be an auction and that there would not be establishment fees. Perhaps more importantly than that, the people who live in those areas have been waiting for new radio licences for heaven only knows how long. This Government, because of its inept approach to broadcast policy, and because of its continual changes of mind, has delayed the bringing about of choice or variety of radio broadcasts available to those people. To put those applicants for licences through another administrative procedure will, again, only delay the granting of new licences and, again, delay the provision of alternative services in those four very large areas. It is an absolute disgrace that, after nearly five years in power, this Government has done nothing to provide a second radio licence on the Gold Coast. The sixth or seventh largest city in Australia has only one radio station. That is not because people have not applied to get a licence but because, in five years, this Government has not been able to get its act together.

TALK.START.PARA: —Seven years in Mildura.

—Seven years in Mildura. Gosford, which is on the Central Coast of New South Wales, still has no local radio station variety because-notwithstanding the tremendous efforts of that soon to be retiring member for Robertson (Mr Cohen)-this Government has done nothing to provide the services that the people of the Central Coast of New South Wales deserve.
—Are you still looking after Doug Anthony?
—Order! The honourable member for Grayndler knows better than to interject from a place other than his chair.
—I do not mind the interjection.
—But I do. The honourable member for Richmond will not respond in that way. The honourable member for Grayndler knows better. I call the honourable member for Richmond.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I appreciate your protection. The Radio Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 2) provides for a fee for conversion from AM to FM. That is quite significant because FM is the latest technology in radio broadcasting in Australia. The Bill also formally imposes an establishment fee, as I said earlier regarding another Bill. But, again, there is a variation of a Budget decision. The Government, in the Budget, said that it would charge 30 per cent of gross annual earnings or revenues-however it defines the term, which is the advertising revenue of the radio station-for the conversion. When the Bill hit the House, notwithstanding the Budget statement, the rate had gone up to 50 per cent. It is up to 50 per cent not because the Government has done some detailed analysis and has to move it up to 50 per cent because it is equitable-presumably it set the rate of 30 per cent on the basis of that analysis-but to compensate for the drop in revenue that will arise from the abandonment of the auction process. If it did it for any other reason I would be interested to hear the Minister's justification. If the Government has got it right now, it got it wrong before. It cannot have it both ways.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us hear where the mistake was made, or whether it was just a grab for money to give the Treasurer his balanced Budget, which he has Buckley's of achieving right now. The sooner he admits it and tells the Australian people that this country is in trouble, that his Budget done with mirrors is not going to work, the better we will all be. Then we can all get on with the job of paying back some of his grossly inflated overseas debt. The Opposition will also be moving an amendment to the motion that the Bill be read a second time. The Television Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 3) again is nothing less than a revenue raising exercise. It was announced in the Budget and it is so typical of this Government grabbing every dollar it can get at any point.

As I have said, the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 4) is a backdown on the Budget decision. It means moving away from the auction principle to the implementation of establishment fees. How did we come to have the auction proposal in the first place? It was a knee-jerk reaction to the sale of a certain Perth television licence. Some people in the Labor Party said, `Oh my goodness, we are handing out licences for broadcast facilities in this country and they are going out gratis. People make solemn undertakings that they will not do anything with them and then they sell them. We've given them away for virtually nothing-just the cost of the application and all the procedures involved-and then they sell them for millions of dollars. What shall we do about that? We'll auction them. What a great idea'. But they really did not think about the implications of that auctioning process. It has some very significant implications for who will be able to operate the licences.

Tonight we are debating radio licences. One of the impacts of auctioning radio licences is that it could effectively price out of the industry local applicants for regional licences, particularly in view of the Government's announced intention to set new ownership limits for radio stations in this country which will facilitate networking. If one has the capital backing to establish a radio network in this country, one has the capital backing to go to an auction for a radio licence and buy the plum licences. One can set up the best network and leave the not so attractive licence situations to those who do not have the big capital backing of the big networks. Few people in the Australian Labor Party are aware of that. The industry, local interests and we on this side of the House are aware of it. We are concerned that the Government did not bother to think it through before it made the announcement. That is why it has backed away from it. This decision is ill-conceived and the Government has given no consideration to the practical problems that will arise from it either for current and prospective licence holders or the range and quality of broadcasts that will be available to the communities, particularly the regional communities, of Australia.

I think it is fair to say that the Government has backed away from its auction proposal strictly as a result of factional pressure. It is pleasing to see that the Caucus is flexing its muscles and has actually achieved a victory. What has happened is probably symptomatic of the state of the Labor Party. The Caucus has even nailed Keating to the wall. It is about time Caucus did something. What it has achieved in regard to the auction proposal is very much a pyrrhic victory at this stage, but let us see how the Labor Party goes on the really tough issues that will come up in a few months time. We all know what they are and we will see how much guts there are in the Labor Caucus when they come up.

The Government has whipped in establishment fees to replace the auction. The auction system was introduced not only to stop the Perth television licence proposal; it was also going to enable the Government to collect a lot of money and help balance the revenue. The fee payable on the grant of a new licence is going to be considerable. The fee will apply to four very significant large and rapidly growing areas where people have been applying for licences for years without any auctions or establishment fees. Those areas are the Gold Coast, Gosford, Geelong and Shepparton.

By any standards, the Government's proposal in this area, be it auction or be it establishment fee, is retrospective. I know that when it comes to dollars the Treasurer does not concern himself about retrospectivity. He is quite happy to grab money any way he can. But there have to be some principles in government. We have seen examples of this Government's commitment-its real genuine commitment to the principles of the Labor Party. We have seen this in its communications policy and we have it in its transport policy; we have seen who runs the Labor Party. So we have an establishment fee. Someone should have a good hard look at the implications of what the Government is doing. That is why we are proposing that this entire Bill be referred to the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I am quite amused by the antics of the honourable member for Grayndler. In fact, I think that his behaviour is typical of the Labor Party's double standards. I know what the honourable member's attitude is when he sits in the chair. I invite him to continue to act in that way but I might remind him of the way he has behaved the next time he takes the chair. Mr Deputy Speaker, I think that is a valid point and I think the honourable member for Grayndler recognises it as such. He cannot claim as an excuse the fact that it is now 10.10 p.m.

SPEECH.PARA: As I was saying, it is about time someone had a good serious look at communications policy. This ought to be done in public, not behind the closed doors of Caucus which means that we have to rely on leaks to find out what was actually discussed. These matters should not be discussed as part of the factional brawling that goes on in the Labor Cabinet, in which case we again have to rely on leaks to find out what has happened. We ought to have a good open inquiry. We ought to be able to see what has been done and the position that this Government has put us in in terms of communications policy. We ought to know about the position that the Department of Transport and Communications has put us in terms of what it has done with the frequencies. I think it has a bit to answer for in that respect. No doubt some of the advisers are squirming over this question. Perhaps they could be asked why radio on the far north coast of New South Wales does not have access to the FM band. Let me tell the Government that this is because spots on the band were granted to television stations without the whole thing being thought through. That is the sort of mess that we have got ourselves into in terms of communications policy in this country and that has happened because no one has sat down and taken a comprehensive view of it. The Opposition will move at the committee stage an exemption for the four existing application areas that I have mentioned from the establishment fees to facilitate the granting of licences in those areas without further delay.

I would like to spend some minutes looking at the impact of establishment fees on the operations of a new applicant. That impact will be quite considerable. The establishment fees will relate to estimated gross annual earnings in a particular area. The cost of servicing that fee, which is a capital payment up front, is going to be considerable. I have received a submission from a group associated with this industry which knows what it is talking about. It mentions an establishment fee of about $2m. The assumption is that interest on the $2m will be at the rate of about 18 per cent. Under the current Government, that is probably fair: interest rates may be a little below that rate now but I wonder whether they will be below it in the not too distant furture. To service $2m at 18 per cent per annum the station would have to sell 277 commercials a week at $25 each just to pay the interest on the establishment fee-not to repay the principal, not to pay the operating costs of the radio station, but just to pay the interest on the establishment fee. We can see the impact that that would have on the subsidy of a regional operator-we are not talking about big city operators; in most cases we are talking about fairly small regional areas-to provide quality programming for the people who live in the area.

Another thing that has been drawn to our attention in the submission is the concentration of ownership that is likely to arise as a result of this establishment fee. Just as at an auction where people who have capital backing can afford to set up networks, the same people with capital backing can afford to pay the establishment fees in the better areas. The Government has not thought this through. The eyes can be picked out of new radio licences and the interests of the local community, the commitment to making sure that broadcasting is relevant to the local community, can be overridden by the power of large capital resources. That is a very significant consideration and it is one which should be examined carefully by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure.

The submission also refers to payment procedures. The legislation proposes that the establishment fee will be paid within 30 days. But let us look at what the legislation provides for in terms of the granting of the licence in practice. The licence will not be granted, effectively, within 30 days of the announcement. Twenty-eight days from the announcement as to who will be granted the licence is the term of the appeal procedure, so there is a 28-day delay before one starts. Then, of course, the successful applicant has to negotiate the final technical conditions of the licence with the Department, and that will take time. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal normally refrains from the formal issuing of the licence until close to the on air date to ensure that the applicant gets the maximum five-year operational period out of the licence. So some time will be involved there because no one applying for a licence would go ahead and set up the studios and buy all the equipment until he has actually been granted the licence. So once the licence is granted there will be the lead time actually to set up the facilities. It is about at that stage that the Tribunal would grant the licence. But under the provisions the Government has introduced which we are dealing with tonight the applicant will have actually paid several million dollars and will have been paying the 18 per cent interest on that amount so that will compound the servicing cost into the future. Another important point is that the proposal requires a substantial payment for the licence up to 12 months before the licensee could hope to create a cash flow to service the payment. Consideration should be given to varying the requirement to pay this establishment fee.

As I mentioned earlier, the Government's motive in this area is to raise revenue because it brought down a balanced Budget, so called-with a $26m deficit-and in that Budget are figures for revenue from the auctioning of radio licences. Now that proposal has been dumped in favour of establishment fees but the establishment fees have to go ahead and the money has to be grabbed very quickly to go into this year's Budget, irrespective of the commercial impact of that decision on the new applicant. That is typical of the approach of this Government to communications: it has to balance the Budget so damn the impact on the applicant, it wants to get on with getting the money into Treasury as soon as possible. There is one other thing that should be mentioned in terms of the Government's approach to granting new licences.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.15 p.m., the debate is interrupted. I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.
Mr Staples-I require that the question be put forthwith without debate.
Question resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILLS:
RADIO LICENCE FEES AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987
BROADCASTING AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1987]
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one other issue that should be considered in terms of the first Bill, the Television Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 3), to which I am referring tonight, and that is the rather cavalier approach of the Minister. The Minister is renowned for sending an F111 aircraft to take spy photographs of Tasmania at some stage, and I know he is infamous for introducing the Australian Bill of Rights Bill, or for saying something about it. But let us have a look at what he says when it comes to commercial considerations. On 18 March of this year he wrote to the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and asked for certain information which related to the advertising revenues of existing radio operators. In that letter, in which he asked for this fairly confidential and sensitive commercial information, he implored the Chairman of the Broadcasting Tribunal not to make this information public. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: In view of the commercial sensitivity of this information, it will not be published or divulged in any way that would enable identification of any individual station's advertising revenue.
He said, `Give me the information and I will not make it public'. Of course, if we look at the Minister's Press release of 28 October, he had this to say:
Based on the revenue of the incumbent licensee in the most recent year for which figures have been provided to the ABT-
I remind the House that in the letter to the Chairman he said this would not be divulged-
the relevant individual amounts are expected to be $4 million for the new Gold Coast licence, $3.2 million for Gosford, $2 million for Geelong and $1.8 million for Shepparton.

They were the estimated amounts he gave for the new licences. I think the Minister should apologise at the very least for that flagrant breach of an undertaking to the Chairman, and he should apologise to the existing licence holders. If this Government had any real commitment to ministerial competence and responsibility, the Prime Minister would sack him. But the Prime Minister has not sacked any one of a number of transgressing Ministers, so I guess it is a forlorn hope that he will do anything about the Minister for Transport and Communications. But that standard of behaviour is a disgrace and should not be countenanced. The very least the Minister should do is publicly apologise for what is a disgraceful breach of confidentiality, compounded by the fact that he gave an undertaking that it would not happen. Either he does not read his Press releases or he deliberately set out to do it-one or the other. If he deliberately set out to do it, it compounds the error. If he does not read his Press releases, he ought not to be the Minister.

Another Bill we are considering here tonight is the Radio Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 2). The most notable feature of that Bill is the increase, from 30 to 50 per cent, of the conversion fee for AM to FM licences. As I mentioned earlier, it represents a change from the initial statements made by the Government in the Budget. It said it would be 30 per cent; it is now 50 per cent. As I said before, it has been increased because the Government needs the money. It backed away from the auction proposal and it is going to get less money out of establishment fees for new licences, so it needs to raise the cost of conversion of AM to FM. There is nothing wrong with establishing a conversion from AM to FM. Limited spaces are being allocated on a frequency band. Again it is indicative of the lack of consideration and detailed thought and analysis that has gone into this whole question by the Government. We have a limited number of spaces on this band. It really does not matter where the operator comes from, whether he is a new operator or an existing industry operator moving on to the FM band-a space is a space is a space, and one space is as valuable as another. There may be some technical differences, but one space is equivalent to another.

Under this proposal we have an inconsistent and, dare I say it, an inequitable method of allocating those spaces between two types of applicant-a new applicant and a converting applicant. Again, it is further evidence of the lack of analysis that has gone into this area by the Government and further support for the need to have a public detailed inquiry into communications policy in Australia.
In regard to the Television Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987, I move the following amendment to the motion for the second reading:
That all words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

``whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House notes the need for the maintenance of localism in broadcasting and the proper representations of local interests in the ownership of television licences''.

The amendment will be seconded by the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran). I return to the Radio Licence Fees Amendment Bill. The whole question of FM licence policy is very important. Earlier I alluded to the fact that the Government has been in office for nearly five years and we are still waiting to see its policy on FM conversion and FM licences in metropolitan areas. There are many AM operators in metropolitan areas who would give their eye teeth to convert to FM. But for five years the Government has been mucking around and we still do not have a policy. I wonder when we will see a policy in this area. Again, it is something that should be considered by the parliamentary committee. There should be a public inquiry into that aspect.

The Government is, quite frankly, making a mess of its media policy. It does not know where it is going. It is inconsistent. It is scared of what is going on. It is not prepared to have a public debate on it. It tries to gag Caucus. There is tension within the Government, within the Cabinet. There is tension between the Executive of Government and its back bench. The Minister is, I believe, reluctant, to put it mildly, to allow either the Senate Standing Committee on Infrastructure, which is to deal with communications, or the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure to have a genuine inquiry in this area. It is for that reason that we will refer this Bill to the House of Representatives Standing Committee. I know that the Government probably will not allow the referral, but there is a very good chance that the Senate will agree to it. So the people of Australia will get an inquiry into communications policy. They will get some opportunity to look at the consequences of recent legislation that has affected their television stations and radio broadcasts, that has had implications that have flown through to their daily newspapers-who owns what papers in what States, who owns what television stations and in what areas of Australia, and who owns radio stations and who will establish the networks in these new mediums.

It is an extremely important question for a country to face. The distribution of news and the provision of entertainment in a community are major determinants of community attitudes. This matter has political and financial overtones and it is something that cannot be swept under the carpet. Unfortunately, that has been the attitude of this Government for too long. It is about time that it was dragged out so that we could see it in the light of day, so that we could see with the benefit of some objective analysis what the consequences of the Government's previous decisions have been, not only for radio but also for television, and what flow-on effects there have been for newspapers. It is very important that we have an objective assessment of where we can take communications and broadcast policy in Australia in the future. Mr Deputy Speaker, at a later stage I will move the other amendments that have been circulated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment in relation to the Television Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987 seconded?
—Yes, I second the amendment, Mr Deputy Speaker.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard some humdingers of speeches in this Parliament but, by golly, the one we have just heard just about takes the cake. After 30 minutes of speaking, we have yet to discover one iota of policy emanating from the Opposition. I gather that its whole policy hinges on nothing more than an inquiry. We are all going to hold our breaths and hang on waiting for the result of an inquiry. Indeed, up until the last couple of minutes of his 30 minute address to the House, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) had spoken on the legislation only for four minutes.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, at one stage he said that the Government back bench and the factions in the Australian Labor Party were all a pack of wimps. In the next breath he was saying that the back bench had stood up to the Government and made it change the legislation. The honourable member cannot have it both ways. We cannot be wimps on one hand and be strong men on the other hand. I ask the honourable members to make up his mind because he said both those things in the course of his 30-minute address. He could have sat down after 60 seconds and have said just about everything sensible he had to say-and that is stretching the imagination somewhat.

This Government is the only government that has had a coherent policy on communications in what has been in the last few years and in what will continue to be a very rapidly evolving industry as a result of the technological advances in communications and telecommunications. Indeed, the previous communications Minister, bar one, in the conservative Government, from the same party as the honourable member for Richmond and now the present Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair), was so hopeless in this area that in fact the Prime Minister at that time, Malcolm Fraser, shifted him to the portfolio of defence.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did he do then?

—The then member for Diamond Valley, now the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), took over that portfolio. I must admit that he at least grasped some idea of what the portfolio was about. The broadcasting Bills we are debating tonight represent the start of a revolution in the radio industry, just as the Government had already moved to revolutionise the television industry earlier this year.

SPEECH.PARA: The Radio Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 2) proposes an establishment fee of 100 per cent for new licences in the regional radio areas. That establishment fee is equivalent to 50 per cent of the gross earnings of the incumbent in the service areas that the new licence is being issued for. That is the first thing. Secondly, we have the introduction of a two-year hold on the licence for the person or company that is granted the licence. They cannot be granted the licence one minute and sell it the next; they must hold that licence, except under the extraordinary conditions that are set out in the legislation, for at least two years.

Thirdly, we see the conversion from AM to FM frequencies. In other words, broadcasters in regional areas may wish to convert to FM. Not all broadcasters will want to convert and the conversion is not compulsory. I do not, in fact, see why people in some areas would wish to convert. However, if they wish to convert they can do so for a cost of 50 per cent of a new licence. If they already have a licence they will actually pay only for the cost of the conversion, in contrast to the people who are applying for new licences who pay the full fee.

This package of legislation also relates to an announcement made by the Government on 28 October in regard to various changes within the radio industry. The first change was the lifting of the ceiling on the number of radio licences that one can hold from eight licences to 16 licences. Further, there is a limit of one licence per person in a particular service area. For example, if there were two stations in the Bendigo area an individual could not hold both licences but only one. Also, there is a limit of 50 per cent on the number of licences an individual may hold in relation to the total number of licences in one State. In my recollection there is no one who has anywhere near that 50 per cent ownership of licences at this time.

Whilst we are doubling the number of radio licences one can hold, this should be looked at in the context that in 1935 when the eight station rule was introduced there were 65 licences in Australia. We estimate that in the next couple of years there will be 176 licences. Therefore, the doubling of the number of licences that an individual can hold from eight to 16 is, in fact, still a lesser percentage of the overall total than it was in 1935 when the original rules were set in place.

Part of the announcement by the Government was that there will be new cross-media ownership rules. That will mean that anyone owning a radio licence in a monopoly area will not be able to have a prescribed interest in television or newspapers in that area. The prescribed interest will be 15 per cent. I must make it clear that that 15 per cent relates to radio as against radio and television and radio and newspapers. At present the prescribed interest with regard to television as against television and print is 5 per cent. It is another debate for another time about whether the Government should move to increase that figure to 15 per cent or whether it should come up with another set of rules.

I make it quite clear to the House that the announcement of 28 October should not be seen as a precedent that we will automatically be lifting the 5 per cent to 15 per cent with regard to television. That decision has been made regarding radio because I believe that radio is a less powerful medium than television and print and it is a different basket altogether.

The lifting of the number of licences allowed and cross-media ownership are very important matters. I reiterate that cross-media ownership will mean that for the first time a person will be able to hold, in a general sense, only radio, television or print licences in the one market. From a Melbourne viewpoint-I assume the honourable member for Menzies would agree, being a Melburnian-that is a great thing because, not so long ago, one could have listened to the one organisation which had all three media in the one market. One could wake up in the morning and go to bed at night and listen to the radio, watch television and read several newspapers and yet hear the one voice. When I worked in the industry the news broadcasts for both radio and television used to be run out of the one booth. That was with the Herald and Weekly Times. That has all changed under this Government and people are only just starting to realise the ramifications of the cross-media ownership rules that this Government has been able to introduce. That debate will occur more fully when the legislation is introduced into this House, I would assume early next year, but it is all part of the package that forms part of this legislation.

Part of this legislation relates to licence fees. We heard an incredible statement from the honourable member for Richmond that licence fees are only a revenue raising item. They have never been anything different since the year dot. I and a number of members-I am sure the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson) would agree-feel that the licence fees for radio and television are too low and should be higher. They have always been a taxing mechanism such as sales tax and many other taxes.

As I have said, the honourable member for Richmond spoke for 30 minutes but I am still waiting to hear one ounce of policy. He asked what policies the Government had. That is what cross-media ownership is all about; that is what we have been debating. There have been massive changes in the industry. People have been saying that the Government has introduced too many changes into the industry yet the Opposition did not say tonight that it would change anything, only that it would have an inquiry. As a politician who has been a member of this place for a while, I know that when one does not know what one should do, when one wants to put a matter on the back burner and think about it for a while, one gets a committee to look at it or one has an inquiry. It would have been much better for the honourable member for Richmond if he had said, `We don't know what we are damned well doing so we will have an inquiry'. That would have been the most honest thing he could have said all night but he did not say anything in the 30 minutes in which he spoke. It was absolute tripe.

Our time is limited, especially at this hour of the night. I could speak at great length. I do not believe that the establishment fee will have a great effect on the entrepreneurs who are applying for the new licences or that this fee will bleed them all to death. I do not believe that the market is full of, shall we say, little Aussie battlers who are all going to the wall. Some of the fees are as follows: Gold Coast, $4m; Gosford, $3.2m; Geelong, $2m; Shepparton, $1.8m; and for most of the other companies coming on stream down the track, the cost will probably be in the $1m to $1.5m area. I am quite sure the companies will be willing to pay that goodwill as many people do in other businesses. In many businesses, such as in the service industry, people really pay that money up front, not for bricks and mortar but for goodwill, sometimes purely just for a name.

We are saying, `Here is your licence. You are able to go out and broadcast with what we have granted you. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal will grant you that licence. You can have the licence for ever if you do the right thing. You can hardly not make a profit in a good area if you run the company properly. But for all that there will be an establishment fee'. That establishment fee is set down so that they all know what they will have to pay before they apply for the licence. The package of decisions the Government has made are absolutely correct. I congratulate the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) because there was a lot of discussion on this within the Government. The package is very good. I can hardly wait for the debate on the other half of the legislation which will come in early next year. I commend this package of legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commence by saying briefly in reply to the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) that the Opposition certainly is not bereft of ideas as to what should be done with respect to communications or media policy. Honourable members will recall that the honourable member for Isaacs threw a few barbs in our direction simply because we had asked for an inquiry into this legislation. He went on from that to say, `You have no ideas; no policy; nothing to suggest at all'. Let me simply give the honourable member for Isaacs a few propositions to reflect on over the coming few weeks which I think will keep him busy and will enable him to conclude that there are areas in media and communications policy which this country should address and would be well advised to address. They are matters to which the Opposition has given consideration and will continue to give consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: The first suggestion is: why not issue some new licences? There are areas of Australia-metropolitan and others-where there is scope for new licences in television and radio. Why not liven up the industry by issuing some new licences? The second point is: why does the Government continue to set its face against cable television and radiated subscription television when, if it simply allowed the establishment of those forms of media, it could unleash enormous investment and the provision of very extensive new services for viewers. There is a very strong case for cable and radiated subscription television. The Government not only has set its face against those reforms but it seems to have done its best to rival the Luddites of the past.

With respect to radiated subscription television the Government says, `Not only will we not allow it to be introduced, but we will legislate'. Can you believe it, Mr Deputy Speaker, the Government says it will legislate-as it has done-to put an embargo on radiated subscription television. The Government says, `We do not care whether people want to invest in it or establish subscription television; we will make it illegal for four years or so'. The Government has done that by legislation. There must be few examples in the history of the civilised world where a Government has said that it will not only now allow a new scientific and technical process to be used but it will make it illegal for it to be used. Those are just two proposals which we think have merit and which the Government would do well to think about.

I want to address a few remarks in particular to the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 4) and in passing to the Television Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 3) and the Radio Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 2). The Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 4) imposes what is called an establishment fee for new radio licences that are about to be issued, and one may say at the outset that this is the latest in a whole series of ad hoc measures in communications and media, which the Government is introducing. Of course, the establishment fee which we are debating tonight is not a proposal to which the Government has given months of thought and over which it has agonised. It is something that has been plucked out of the air over the past couple of weeks. It must be remembered that, on 15 September, the establishment fee had not been heard of. When the Budget was introduced on 15 September, we were going to have an auction or tendering system, under which the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal would decide those competing applicants who were fit and proper people to hold radio and television licences, and then the licences were going to be put up for tender or auctioned and the company that could produce the highest tender for them would get the licence. That proposal lasted from 15 September until only a few days ago, when it was abandoned, to be replaced by the so-called establishment fee.

It was a good thing that the Government abandoned the auction system, because nothing could be more calculated to keep ownership of the media in the hands of the rich, and to keep out new players and new entrants in communications, than an auction or tender system. At least the Government deserves some marks for that. It has abandoned what was nothing more than a proposal to keep the rich, well-heeled big companies in media, and to exclude new players, new entrants, smaller companies and smaller businesses from the communications field. That is all out. The tender system or auction system has gone, and we have had it replaced with the latest fashion, October's fashion, which is an establishment fee. I suppose one must concede that it is at least an appropriate name, because the whole approach of this Government in communications and media has been to help the establishment in that industry as much as it can. It is very appropriate that the establishment fee should bear testimonial to that.

Then again, we really should not be very surprised that the Government now comes forward with this establishment fee, which itself will be an embargo to stop new companies, new entrants and small businesses from getting into the media field. We can note that the establishment fee itself will do its own bit to keep out of the media field potential new entrants. It will be just as effective as the tender system would have been, because the hefty fee that will be levied when new radio licences are granted will impose an enormous burden on those companies that are applying for licences. It will make it just as difficult for new entrants in communications to get into the field as the auction or tender system would have.

Of course, that is entirely consistent with the Government's approach to the media, and that approach is: help your friends, keep the rules of the game fixed so that the present players are protected and make life as difficult as possible for everyone else, particularly for those who might want to get into this new and expanding industry. We have just seen that in practice. We have just seen the whole way in which the Government's communications policy operates for the benefit of its friends and for the benefit of those in the know and against those who are on the outside but who want to get into this industry, into this field. We have seen that so clearly in the last two takeovers of groups of radio stations in this country.

Let me illustrate this point because I am putting a very serious proposition. Those two takeovers have come about as a result of and as part of the recent changes announced by the Government in the number of radio stations that one licensee is able to hold. The first of these two takeovers of groups of radio stations is quite extraordinary. It is the takeover by Wesgo Communications Pty Ltd of the eight radio stations owned by AWA. The reason it is extraordinary and calls for some explanation is this: until 29 October, not long ago, one owner could own only eight radio stations altogether. On 28 October the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) announced that the limit would be increased to 16. The number was to be doubled, so one licensee would be allowed to hold 16 radio stations. Wesgo until then owned eight stations, and, wonder of wonders, on the very day that the Minister announced that the limit would be lifted to 16 Wesgo bought the AWA company's eight stations for over $70m.

What remarkable footwork. Does anyone believe that on that one day Wesgo was able to marshal its resources, enter into negotiations and make a deal that would fit comfortably into the new rules that were announced by the Minister on the same day? Does anyone believe that it was not in the know before that announcement was made? Does anyone believe it could have done all that on the one day? Does anyone believe it did not have advance notice? I suggest that this takeover calls for some explanation. It calls for the Minister to give some answers. Clearly that company was in the know. But what a remarkable coincidence it was that Wesgo owned eight stations and bought another eight bringing its ownership to 16, which was the precise limit announced by the Minister on 28 October. How did it come about that it was in the know?

One of the interesting questions is who owns Wesgo? What do we find when we look at its shareholdings? We find that 3,400,000 shares in this company are, in effect, owned by the Australian Labor Party-3,400,000 shares are owned by 3KZ Radio Pty Ltd, the licensee of station 3KZ in Melbourne. The parent company of 3KZ is Industrial Printing and Publicity Co. Ltd. To all intents and purposes it is the Labor Party's company. It owns 3KZ. It owns the Industrial Printing and Publicity company. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) had to resign from his directorship in that company not so long ago to avoid a conflict of interest. It owns 3,400,000 shares in Wesgo which, miraculously, on the day that the Minister announced the increase in the number of stations from eight to 16 suddenly ups and does exactly that. What a remarkable series of events. If that is not a potential conflict of interest on the information that I have, I simply do not know what a potential conflict of interest is. At the very least it calls for answers. Were these people in the know? What discussions were there between the Minister for Transport and communications, his friends, his Party members and that company and other participants in the industry before that announcement was made on 28 October? Were there no discussions; were there no meetings? Was there no advance information given? Was there no inside knowledge? Was this not the `insider trading' that the socialists condemn so much, so often and so vociferously? Was this not such a case? If it was not such a case, let us be told that. Let us be told that the Minister had no discussions with the big league of the media industry before this announcement was made.

Frankly, I think that this sort of matter should be subjected to very close scrutiny. If honourable members think that the events I have described represent a miraculous coincidence, they should try this one on for size. The other major takeover we had was that by Hoyts Media Ltd of the radio stations owned by Northern Star Holdings. Mr Wheatley, who is the Managing Director of Hoyts Media Ltd, gave an interview on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's radio program PM on 12 October-many days before the Minister announced that the limit on the number of radio stations to be owned by one person was to be increased. The interviewer commented that it was very strange that there was a limit of eight radio stations for one person, yet Hoyts had just brought another nine. He asked, `How did this come about? Aren't you in breach of the law?' In reply, Mr Wheatley said:
We have discussed our position with the Department and the Minister and we are hopeful that, yes, they are going to change the laws to allow us to be able to hold more than eight stations.

If ever there were a case of advance inside knowledge, that must be it. To extemporise a bit, I must say that here is a case where the purchaser of these radio stations is saying that what he was doing was not authorised by the law at that time, but he had had a chat with the Minister in the way in which these matters are settled in the Australian Labor Party these days-with a few cigars and a bottle of whisky, a wink here and a nod there and a blind eye to the provisions of the Broadcasting Act-and he was confident enough to put up more than $100m for this new chain of radio stations. This was all done on the say so of a bit of chit chat with Senator Gareth Evans. It is not good enough for public policy and public administration in this country to be run in that way. It is not good enough to do something that it is not authorised by the law and to do it on the basis of a bit of a chit chat, a few whiskies with the Minister before the law is changed and in reliance on what the Minister says. That is not good enough and those are some of the reasons why these matters should be investigated by a committee.
Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —If I could have a bit of quiet, I will conclude by making this point: the structure of media in this country is not now as one would believe if one accepted what the honourable member for Isaacs and other Government speakers have said. This is not some new golden age of more competitors competing vigorously, free from government involvement. The new golden era in communications has not yet dawned. As a result of this Government's actions, certainly in television, we have a situation in which there are now fewer big owners than ever before. A lot of slick deals have been done. A lot of big, fast money has been made and after all this, we still have the exclusion from the market of new entrants who want to start up in a small way, whether in radio or any other area of communication; we still have barriers against them. Cable television and subscription television, for people who want to get into it, are all out, all illegal and all prohibited all so that the Government can rig communications for its fast and fancy friends with their big money. The Government has done nothing for the consumer of communications and media in this country, but it has done a great deal for the very rich and the very powerful. I suppose one day the Government will wake up to it.
