SPEECH.SPEAKER: Saunderson Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to the contribution of the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown). He has spoken about us looking after our mates and doing all sorts of deals. The very fact that people are able to buy television and radio stations and breach the current ownership laws can be sheeted home to those opposite, because when they were in government in 1981 they introduced the changes to the ownership rules requiring prior approval.
—Did you condone the breaking of the law?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Deakin should not interject out of his place.

INTERJECT.PARA: Me Beale-I will go to my place, then.

TALK.START.PARA: —And then he shall not interject from there either.

—They introduced these changes in 1981 to look after their mate, Mr Murdoch. The only other substantial thing they did about television ownership was when they introduced the two-station rule, and that was to look after their mates as well. In the 4 1/2 years that we have been in office we have reformed the whole system of television and radio ownership and we have updated and increased the number of licences available. The only contribution that those opposite can make is to say, `you are looking after your mates'.

SPEECH.PARA: Since we changed the level of television ownership there are more substantive owners. We introduced cross-media controls, which means that we have separated the link between print and television. These amendments will separate them even further so that in future we will be separating the links between radio, television and print. In the last few years people have been able to acquire licences and make substantial gains. Television and radio licences allow people to utilise the public airwaves. The most disgraceful event in the last few years was the Perth television case. The case heard by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal on whether a third licence should be issued ran for two years. The licence was finally issued to an individual who had stated the principles under which he would operate the licence. Within a short period of getting the licence, without ever going to air, he sold the licence to somebody else, making substantial profits. That is a disgraceful situation. We cannot allow such abuse of the public radio and television licences. We are introducing a two-year moratorium, which means that the people who now apply for licences must be fair dinkum and concerned about getting programs to air and providing services to the community.

Any radio or television licence issued to individuals gives them the opportunity to raise substantial amounts of money and make a substantial profit. The current establishment fee that is charged is $500. Quite obviously, that is a ridiculously low amount, given the substantial amounts of money people can earn. We are proposing a fee which will raise the amount of money collected from the issuing of licences. We recognise that the original proposition of auctioning licences had some disadvantages. We are now proposing a fee which will be clearly known to all applicants. It is not a guess game. It is not a matter of upping one's ante to try to make sure that one gets the licence. Every applicant who wants to present a case for being issued with a licence will know exactly how much the establishment fee will be. It can be added into the applicant's budgeting program. It will mean that everyone bidding will be on a fair level financially. Under the auctioning system they would have been at a disadvantage in not knowing what the price would be and, therefore, having to up the ante.

One cannot argue against that concept. One cannot sustain an argument that the current establishment fee of $500 is adequate. It is totally inadequate. One cannot argue for an auctioning system which puts one at the mercy of the wealthiest, most cashed-up individuals at the time, those who can bid more for a licence to put other contenders out of the running. We have provided a reasonable establishment fee which puts every applicant on the same basis. The honourable member for Menzies, who must be the new back bench spokesperson for broadcasting policy, said that we should be issuing new licences.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another failed Minister.

—I was not going to mention the fact that he was a previous failed Minister who was dropped from the front bench. I was going to say that he has opted for the proposal given some credence by the previous communications spokesperson, who is now no longer spokesperson. We have had quite a few Opposition spokespersons on communications. The honourable member was talking about issuing new licences. There is a crazy notion that one can deregulate the airwaves and that, if one wants a licence, one just goes along and asks for it and a licence is granted. The notion is that everyone can have a licence and that radio and television stations are just put to air. That takes no account of the fact that there is a very valid argument in this area concerning viability.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a need to ensure stability in this industry. No one is going to invest in or support local Australian television program production if the ridiculous situation exists whereby anyone who wants to set up a television station can do so when television stations go off air because they cannot sustain a profit as too many people are competing for the limited advertising market. Nobody will invest in the rest of the infrastructure. People will not be trained to operate cameras. They will not be trained in production and the things that are the backbone of the industry. So there must be some viability and stability in the industry in terms of issuing licences.

It is a nonsense argument to say that we should simply issue unlimited numbers of licences to anyone who wants them. We have looked at the question of radio licensing in regional areas. There is an underservicing problem. We have announced a program under which about 30 new licences will be issued over the next three years. We have instituted a funding program which will raise substantially more money for the Government and, at the same time, provide a fairly consistent base. I believe that there is only one area which the Government needs to address-that is, supplementary licences. Whilst I appreciate that in some areas full viability does not exist for open competition, I am of the view that in areas where a supplementary licence may be issued, we should charge a substantive fee for such licences.

We are raising licence fees this year by lifting the top rates that are paid. The current 8 per cent limit on the maximum earnings of television stations is being lifted to 9 per cent in cases where television licensees earn in excess of $100m. What we have done is a rational way to lift the earnings from television licences. I think there is still some way to go before we realise the full potential of this area. I hope that the Government continues its program of gradually increasing television licence fees over the next few years. I commend the Bills to the House. I believe that what is proposed is a new move and it provides an advantage, particularly for people in regional areas who have suffered from a lack of variety in their radio programs.
Debate (on motion by Mr Reith) adjourned.
House adjourned at 11.06 p.m. until Tuesday, 17 November at 2.00 p.m. unless Madam Speaker fixes an alternative date or hour of meeting in accordance with the resolution agreed to this day.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 15 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are Commonwealth public servants and employees of Commonwealth statutory authorities who use screen based equipment given the option to undergo an eye examination at Government expense; if so, can these examinations be carried out by optometrists.
(2) What fee is paid to an optometrist for the examination.
(3) What interval between the initial test and a follow-up test is recommended.
(4) What has been the cost to the Government for eye examinations since the inception of the scheme.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) On 28 May 1985, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters approved interim arrangements for eyesight testing of Screen Based Equipment (SBE) operators at Commonwealth expense. They apply to staff required to operate SBE for more than 25% of their time on duty; (b) Under the arrangements, testing is on a voluntary basis and comprises the following six tests:
distance visual acuity
near visual acuity
Oculomotor co-ordination
colour vision
slit lamp examination of the eye
ophthalmoscopic examination of the ocular fundus.

The last two tests are to be conducted by an optometrist. The first four tests can be administered by trained nursing staff inhouse e.g. through Regional Offices of the Department of Community Services and Health or all six tests can be conducted by an optometrist.
(2) The approved fees-for-service paid to optometrists is $15.85.

(3) Current guidelines suggest retesting after an interval of 2 years. However these arrangements are interim: Worksafe Australia has set terms of reference for an Expert Study Group on Eyesight Testing of VDU Users and this Group's first meeting took place on 29 September, 1987. The study group is chaired by Worksafe Australia with the Royal Australian College of Ophthalmologists, and the Australian Optometrical Association each providing a representative.
The expert study will investigate:
The need and justification for, and reliability of, eyesight testing and diagnosis for Screen Based Equipment use;
The nature and frequency of any tests which should be conducted in relation to SBE use;
The most economical and efficient means of conducting any tests found to be necessary; and
The categories of employees to be tested.

(4) A survey conducted by the Public Service Board, of its related agencies, in August 1986 indicated that up to that date some 60% of eligible staff had been tested and of these less than 2% were prescribed spectacles. The cost to the Federal Government has been approximately $330,000, an average of $13.00 per individual tested. No further surveys have been conducted.
